chunk_874.text:
Healthcare 2023, 11, 1637 2 of 19
To ensure safe driving for stroke patients, it is necessary to comprehensively review and
ascertain which factors can effectively predict their resumption of driving. In addition,
there is a need to analyze which approaches are used in driving rehabilitation for stroke
patients and how effective they are, and provide clinical suggestions based on the results.
This review aimed to comprehensively summarize the evidence for the therapeutic
effects of driving rehabilitation on return to driving in stroke patients compared with
non-driving rehabilitation. We also evaluated the predictors of their return to driving to
identify the main factors affecting driving rehabilitation. We conducted a systematic review
with meta-analysis to comprehensively examine the prediction of a return to driving.
2. Methods
The review protocol was registered in PROSPERO (registration no: CRD42020202830).

meta.creator: LaTeX with hyperref
meta.author: Sujin Hwang and Chiang-Soon Song
meta.subject: Driving enables stroke survivors to freely participate in social integration. The purpose of this review was to summarize the evidence for the therapeutic effects of driving rehabilitation for patients when they return to driving after stroke and evaluate the predictors of returning to driving to identify the factors impacting their driving rehabilitation. This study employed a systematic review and meta-analysis. PubMed and four other databases were searched until 31 December 2022. Our review included randomized controlled trials (RCT) and non-RCTs that investigated driving rehabilitation for stroke and observational studies. A total of 16 studies (two non-RCT and 14 non-RCT) were reviewed; two RCTs investigated the effect of driving rehabilitation with a simulator system, and eight and six non-RCTS evaluated the predictive factors of driving return post-stroke and compared the effects of driving rehabilitation for stroke, respectively. The National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) and Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores and having paid employment were significant predictors of resuming driving after stroke. The results suggest that NIHSS, MMSE, and paid employment are predictors of returning to driving post-stroke. Future research should investigate the effect of driving rehabilitation on the resumption of driving in patients with stroke.
meta.title: Driving Rehabilitation for Stroke Patients: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis

2. Methods
The review protocol was registered in PROSPERO (registration no: CRD42020202830).
The review protocol was conducted in accordance with the 2020 Preferred Reporting
Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) statement. Two researchers
independently performed the search strategy (search, study selection, and data collection);
reviewed the risk of bias, individual studies, and summary measures; and synthesized
the results.
2.1. Eligibility Criteria
This review involved randomized controlled trial (RCT) studies that evaluated the
effects of driving rehabilitation approaches on the return to driving for stroke survivors.
This review also involved cohort studies and cross-sectional studies that examined the
predictors of return to driving after stroke. We included adult participants (aged≥ 18 years)
who were stroke survivors and who had functional ability. We did not restrict participants
according to gender.

etc., (3) gray literature such as dissertations, congress or conference materials, abstracts,
etc., and (4) not focused on motor vehicle driving after stroke.

comparison, outcome measures, and summary of results in the RCT. The risk of bias for

3. Results
3.1. Literature Search and Characteristics of the Included RCTs
Based on the initial search strategies, we retrieved a total of 1229 records from ﬁve
databases: PubMed (181), Embase (283), ProQuest (571), Medline (81), and CINAHL (113).
After excluding 303 duplicate studies, 303 remained. Based on titles and abstracts, 906
of the 926 studies were excluded for the following reasons: different issues (n = 698),
different populations (n = 109), systematic reviews (n = 95), and others ((n = 4): news
(n = 1), annual science meeting (n = 2), and qualitative analysis (n = 1)). Four full-text
articles of the 20 articles were excluded owing to different populations (n = 1) and different
issues (n = 3). Finally, sixteen studies were included in the qualitative synthesis, including

meta.creator: LaTeX with hyperref
meta.author: Sujin Hwang and Chiang-Soon Song
meta.subject: Driving enables stroke survivors to freely participate in social integration. The purpose of this review was to summarize the evidence for the therapeutic effects of driving rehabilitation for patients when they return to driving after stroke and evaluate the predictors of returning to driving to identify the factors impacting their driving rehabilitation. This study employed a systematic review and meta-analysis. PubMed and four other databases were searched until 31 December 2022. Our review included randomized controlled trials (RCT) and non-RCTs that investigated driving rehabilitation for stroke and observational studies. A total of 16 studies (two non-RCT and 14 non-RCT) were reviewed; two RCTs investigated the effect of driving rehabilitation with a simulator system, and eight and six non-RCTS evaluated the predictive factors of driving return post-stroke and compared the effects of driving rehabilitation for stroke, respectively. The National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) and Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores and having paid employment were significant predictors of resuming driving after stroke. The results suggest that NIHSS, MMSE, and paid employment are predictors of returning to driving post-stroke. Future research should investigate the effect of driving rehabilitation on the resumption of driving in patients with stroke.
meta.title: Driving Rehabilitation for Stroke Patients: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis

3.3. Risk of Bias in All Included Studies for Predictors to Return to Driving after Stroke
The risk of bias arising from the selection of participants revealed concerns about
one study and its retrospective study design. The confounding variables had an unclear
risk of bias in seven studies [1,4,10,11,19–21]. Only confounding variables were identiﬁed,
and statistical correction was performed during the statistical analysis stage [ 2]. The
risk of bias for the measurement of intervention/exposure was low in seven studies in
which data were obtained from trustworthy sources (e.g., medical records and clinical
measurement tools) [1,2,4,10,11,20,21]; however, one study had no medical information,
clinical measurement tools, or questionnaire from structural interviews [19]. Blinding for
outcome measurement showed a low risk of bias in seven studies [1,2,4,11,19–21], and its

3.5. Comparison of Stroke Survivors’ Driving Performance with Healthy Controls
Six of the selected studies involved a comparison of stroke survivors’ driving perfor-
mance with that of healthy controls [3,7,22–25]. Five studies used a driving simulator to
measure intervention/exposure [3,7,22,23,25] and one used a structured telephone inter-
view [24]. The six selected studies included 169 stroke patients and 242 healthy controls.

3.6. Risk of Bias for Stroke Survivors’ Driving Performance with Healthy Controls
The selection of participants, measurement of intervention/exposure, incomplete
outcome data, and selective outcome reporting showed a low risk of bias in the six selected
studies. The confounding variables showed that one study had a high risk of bias because
it was not considered a major confounding variable (age population) [ 22], and it was
unclear whether the confounding variables resulted in a high or low risk of bias in two
studies [24,25]. Blinding for the outcome assessment showed that one study had a high
risk of bias due to different models of data collection and analysis in the two groups of
participants (see Figure 5) [24].

meta.author: Sujin Hwang and Chiang-Soon Song
meta.subject: Driving enables stroke survivors to freely participate in social integration. The purpose of this review was to summarize the evidence for the therapeutic effects of driving rehabilitation for patients when they return to driving after stroke and evaluate the predictors of returning to driving to identify the factors impacting their driving rehabilitation. This study employed a systematic review and meta-analysis. PubMed and four other databases were searched until 31 December 2022. Our review included randomized controlled trials (RCT) and non-RCTs that investigated driving rehabilitation for stroke and observational studies. A total of 16 studies (two non-RCT and 14 non-RCT) were reviewed; two RCTs investigated the effect of driving rehabilitation with a simulator system, and eight and six non-RCTS evaluated the predictive factors of driving return post-stroke and compared the effects of driving rehabilitation for stroke, respectively. The National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) and Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores and having paid employment were significant predictors of resuming driving after stroke. The results suggest that NIHSS, MMSE, and paid employment are predictors of returning to driving post-stroke. Future research should investigate the effect of driving rehabilitation on the resumption of driving in patients with stroke.
meta.title: Driving Rehabilitation for Stroke Patients: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis

3.6. Risk of Bias for Stroke Survivors’ Driving Performance with Healthy Controls 
The selection of participants, measurement of intervention/exposure, incomplete 
outcome data, and selective outcome reporting showed a low risk of bias in the six selected 
studies. The confounding variables showed that one study had a high risk of bias because 
it was not considered a major confounding variable (age population) [22], and it was 
unclear whether the confounding variables resulted in a high or low risk of bias in two 
studies [24,25]. Blinding for the outcome as sessment showed that one study had a high 
risk of bias due to di ﬀerent models of data collection and analysis in the two groups of 
participants (see Figure 5) [24].

3.7. Eﬀects of Driving Simulator Training for Stroke Patients 
The review included two RCTs that investigated the e ﬀects of driving simulator 
training on stroke patients [9,26]. A total of 152 stroke patients (experimental group = 75, 
control group = 77) participated in the selected RCT. The age of participants in the 
experimental group ranged from 55 to 58 years, and that of the control group was 54 to 59 
years. The experimental group underwent dr iving simulator training for 60 min x 15 
sessions, and the control group underwent cognitive training during the same period. The 
outcome measures were the UFOV, visual test, stroke driver screening assessment (SDSA), 
test ride for investigating practical ﬁtness-to-drive (TRIP), and the Barthel index. The

A total of 16 studies (two non-RCT and 14 non-RCT) were reviewed; two RCTs investigated the effect of driving rehabilitation with a simulator system, and eight and six non-RCTS evaluated the predictive factors of driving return post-stroke and compared the effects of driving rehabilitation for stroke, respectively. The National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) and Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores and having paid employment were significant predictors of resuming driving after stroke. The results suggest that NIHSS, MMSE, and paid employment are predictors of returning to driving post-stroke. Future research should investigate the effect of driving rehabilitation on the resumption of driving in patients with stroke.

3.8. Risk of Bias of RCT Studies of Driving Stimulator Training for Stroke Patients
Random sequence generation and allocation concealment were selected for studies
with a low risk of bias. The blinding of participants and personnel was unclear in two
RCTs [9,26]. The blinding of the outcome assessment had a low risk of bias in one study;
however, the risk of bias was unclear [26]. Incomplete outcome data also had a low risk
of bias in one study. Selective reporting had a low risk of bias in one study but a high
risk of bias in another study that did not report all pre-speciﬁed primary outcomes (see
Figure 6) [9].

The results of this review suggest three predictors—the NIHSS score, the MMSE score,
and paid employment—for return to driving post-stroke [ 1,2,11,21]. The NIHSS score
showed high heterogeneity, and the MMSE score showed moderate heterogeneity. The
results of the meta-analysis showed that stroke patients with higher NIHSS scores at six
months post-stroke were less likely to return to driving. Previous studies have reported

that the NIHSS, which measures stroke-related neurological deﬁcits, including conscious-
ness, language, neglect, visual ﬁeld loss, extraocular movement, motor strength, ataxia,
dysarthria, and sensory loss, can predict stroke outcome and be used to evaluate neurologi-
cal status in acute stroke patients [27,28]. Wouters et al. reported that the baseline NIHSS
score determined at hospital admission was a strong predictor of stroke outcomes [ 27].
Similarly, Mistry et al. found that the 24-h NIHSS score was the strongest predictor of
90-day outcomes in endovascular therapy-treated patients [29]. The results of these previ-
ous studies proved that tools are an important assessment tool in stroke rehabilitation. The
results of this review show that the NIHSS score is a major predictor of return to driving
post-stroke; therefore, the NIHSS score at admission to inpatient rehabilitation is a predictor
of return to driving post-stroke.

of return to driving post-stroke.
The MMSE is one of the most extensively used assessment tools for cognitive impair-
ment in clinical settings [30,31]. This review revealed that individuals with lower MMSE
scores were less likely to return to driving. The selected studies of predictors of return
to driving post-stroke measured various assessment tools to examine cognitive impair-
ment in stroke patients; however, these only examined a single component of cognitive
function, such as executive function, memory, and perception [3,7]. The MMSE includes
various questions on cognitive impairment; therefore, it is more sensitive in predicting the
resumption of driving following a stroke [21]. However, recent studies have shown that the
MMSE is inappropriate for predicting cognitive impairment, with other studies suggesting
alternative clinical tools, such as the Montreal Cognitive Assessment [32]. Therefore, this

chunk_925.text:
alternative clinical tools, such as the Montreal Cognitive Assessment [32]. Therefore, this
study recommends using the MMSE as a factor supporting the NIHSS rather than as the
sole predictor of resumption of driving after stroke.
Having paid employment means that daily life and functional activities necessary for a
stroke patient’s work life are smoother, and their job capabilities are properly restored [11,33].
Returning to work also improves patients’ self-esteem, social well-being, and sense of
fellowship with colleagues in a social environment [33,34]. These factors can be interpreted
as having appropriate effects on motor control, in which various stimuli, such as driving, are
simultaneously processed. Therefore, this study also recommends using paid employment
as a predictor of the return to driving post-stroke, although paid employment showed
high heterogeneity in the meta-analysis. Based on the baseline scores of these predictors at

he/she will be able to make sufﬁcient effort to return to driving within a given rehabilitative
period. This study suggests that driving rehabilitation at an early stage of the rehabilitative
period can improve the efﬁciency of social integration by encouraging more patients to
return to driving.

relatively few RCT studies on driving rehabilitation. To provide evidence-based treatment
to stroke patients and promote their return to driving and social integration, more RCT
studies that can provide evidence should be conducted in the future.
Among the selected studies, even if the study design and evaluation tools were the
same, there were cases in which a meta-analysis could not be performed because the
method of describing the examined values was different for each study. Published studies
that researchers and clinicians search for and refer to through electronic databases are
conducted in various countries; therefore, the population characteristics are also diverse.
Thus, it is desirable to obtain a comprehensive conclusion by synthesizing the results of
various studies rather than proceeding with clinical applications based on the results of
a single study. To synthesize the results of the selected studies, statistical values (mean,

a single study. To synthesize the results of the selected studies, statistical values (mean,
standard deviation, and number of events) of measurement tools are needed to obtain
comprehensive conclusions, such as meta-analyses for evidence-based practice [ 18]. In
addition, some studies had the same study design and population but different evaluation
tools; therefore, it was impossible to synthesize the results. The use of assessment tools
whose reliability and validity have been proven to represent the clinical characteristics of
patients with stroke is recommended.
This review was conducted by limiting the population with stroke to traumatic brain
injury, brain tumors, acquired brain injuries, and degenerative neurology disorders such
as Parkinson’s disease; however, it was found that studies targeting acquired brain injury,
traumatic brain injury, brain tumor, or neurological impairment were more extensive than

A total of 16 studies (two non-RCT and 14 non-RCT) were reviewed; two RCTs investigated the effect of driving rehabilitation with a simulator system, and eight and six non-RCTS evaluated the predictive factors of driving return post-stroke and compared the effects of driving rehabilitation for stroke, respectively. The National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) and Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores and having paid employment were significant predictors of resuming driving after stroke. The results suggest that NIHSS, MMSE, and paid employment are predictors of returning to driving post-stroke. Future research should investigate the effect of driving rehabilitation on the resumption of driving in patients with stroke.

chunk_944.text:
This document was developed and piloted in partnership with Federation University 
& Western Health. 
This resource has been prepared to support you as a non-driver trained occupational therapist to 
address driving with your clients. All information included in this resource is current at the time of 
publication, based on relevant and up to date research evidence. As part of usual professional 
practice, it is recommended that you continue to review the literature and seek support from 
experienced clinicians and/or occupational therapy driver assessors for further guidance as 
indicated, when addressing driving with your clients. The material presented within this clinical 
decision pathway is provided without prejudice. No responsibility is assumed by the authors of 
any injury, damage, as a matter of product liability, negligence, warranty or otherwise arising out 
of the use or application of any methods, products or ideas contained herein as clinicians own

chunk_949.text:
Driving is a valued occupation for people as it 
enables independence and freedom 
to access the community. However, there are 
various health conditions that could temporarily 
and/or permanently impact on safe driving skills 
(Moon et al., 2018). There are various health 
professionals who have roles and responsibilities 
in the field of driving such as medical practitioners, 
optometrists and occupational therapists. As an 
occupational therapist working within inpatient and 
outpatient settings, you have a duty of care and 
professional obligation to address the occupation 
of community mobility, including driving. This may 
include enabling people to return to driving when 
safe or providing counselling and exploring other 
community mobility options when driving is no 
longer safe. 
Fig
ure 2. Women Standing Beside Women on Wooden Chair 
Facing Body of Water (see attribution 2, page 59) 
The following flowchart depicts key steps to addressing community mobility, including

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_950.text:
The following flowchart depicts key steps to addressing community mobility, including 
driving: 
Step 1: Explore community mobility needs 
Step 2: Establish whether driving is a valued occupation 
Step 3: Conduct relevant screening tests 
Step 4: Conduct relevant assessments tests 
Step 5: Summarise key strengths and limitations 
Step 6: Evaluate the impact on driving skills 
Step 7: Discuss results and recommendations 
Both written and verbal communication between driving-related stakeholders are important to 
support your client to navigate their return to driving. Therefore, several letter templates are 
included in this resource to maximise effective communication and documentation practices.

chunk_954.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 7  of 84 
Objectives of this resource 
This resource was developed in response to an 
identified gap in occupational therapy practice. 
With a growing ageing population, the demand for 
specialist occupational therapy driver assessors is 
considered a public health issue (Dickerson et al., 
2014). While Australian occupational therapy driver 
assessors are supported by clinical practice 
guidelines and competency standards, there are no 
comparable practice guidelines for non-driver 
trained occupational therapists who also have a 
duty of care and professional obligation to address 
driving as an instrumental activity of daily living. 
This resource is to be used by all non-driver trained occupational therapists across the continuum 
of care (acute, sub-acute and community settings) to assist all adults with any health condition 
through the driving process. 
The primary aims of this resource are to:

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_955.text:
through the driving process. 
The primary aims of this resource are to: 
• Provide context regarding why driving is a meaningful occupation to people and the
consequences of driving cessation;
• Outline health professionals’ roles with fitness to drive practices for people including role
differentiation between non-driver trained occupational therapists and occupational therapy
driver assessors;
• Outline evidence-based literature for driving screening and assessment to assist non-driver
trained occupational therapists;
• Provide a framework to assist non-driver trained occupational therapists’ clinical reasoning
when assisting adults with returning to driving; and
• Outline resources to support clinical reasoning including templates to standardise
communication and documentation practices in this area.
Secondary aims are to: 
• Maximise road safety by appropriate identification and prevention of people from returning
to driving when unsafe;

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_956.text:
to driving when unsafe;
• Promote independence and quality of life through prevention of premature driving cessation
for people through education processes for non-driver trained occupational therapists;
• Save unnecessary expense through appropriate and timely referrals to occupational
therapy driver assessors for comprehensive driving assessment where indicated; and
• Support the occupational therapy profession as experts in providing driving and community
mobility services.
Introduction 
Figure 4. A man looking at a Datsun 240z (see attribution 3, 
page 59)

chunk_957.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 8 of 84 
Why is driving important to your clients? 
Many people view driving as a “right rather than as a privilege” (Dickerson et al., 2011, p. 64). Driving is 
important for individuals as it enables participation and access to services within the community. While 
access to the community is considered a right, driving is a privilege due to the complex interaction of 
skills required to operate a vehicle safely in the community. In 2018, the Australian Bureau of Statistics 
reported “19.2 million registered motor vehicles in Australia” (Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2018a, p. 1) 
which is expected to grow based on previous data between 2017 and 2018 outlining a growth rate of 2.1 
percent (Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2018a). This data highlights that a large proportion of the 
Australian population drive a car, and there are several key reasons for this.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_958.text:
Australian population drive a car, and there are several key reasons for this. 
Research has shown that driving is an extremely valued occupation, and this is often not because 
of the task of driving itself but more about what driving enables people to do (Dickerson et al., 
2011). For example, driving allows people to access their local shopping centre, to socialise with friends 
and access services and healthcare facilities. Driving is particularly important for those adults living in 
rural and remote areas, where access to public transport is limited (Liddle et al., 2008; Unsworth et al., 
2020). This can make independent living extremely difficult such as, accessing the local supermarket for 
food or the pharmacy for medication, and often an increased reliance on family or friends for assistance is 
needed causing significant carer burden. A study by Fricke and Unsworth (2001) explored time use and

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_959.text:
the importance of occupations among older adults. It was found that 90.9% reported transportation use 
as very important, and 87.5% reported that driving a car was also very important. Similarly, a subsequent 
study by Dickerson et al. (2013) found that 87% of people, and their carers, rated driving most frequently 
as a meaningful occupation. 
Given that driving brings significant purpose and meaning in life, the potential consequences of 
driving cessation can be shattering. Driving cessation can occur in either of two ways; voluntarily or a 
result of the licensing authority revoking the licence (Liddle et al., 2012; Unsworth et al., 2020). Research 
has shown that the cessation of driving is often encompassed by a loss of access to the community, and 
loss of various roles or identities (Liddle et al., 2012). As a result of reduced independence, freedom of 
control and loss of social interactions, high rates of serious mental health conditions occur for not only the

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_960.text:
person who has ceased driving but often their dependent carers as well (Dickerson et al., 2011; Liddle et 
al., 2012). Combined with a rapid deterioration in physical and social functioning (Edwards, Lunsman, et 
al., 2009), driving cessation has also been associated with entering into long term care facilities or 
nursing homes (Freeman et al., 2006). Edwards, Perkins, et al. (2009) linked driving cessation with 
mortality, stating that older adults who ceased driving were four to six times more likely to die over the 
subsequent 3 years. While driving cessation can impact on the person and their carer, it can also have 
an impact on wider society. Dickerson et al. (2014) highlighted that there are increased medical for older 
people due to increased mental health conditions. There is a potential loss of income and disruption to 
employment for those older adults who are unable to access the community for productivity purposes,

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_961.text:
which can result in an overall economic loss to society (Dickerson et al., 2014). Given the value of driving 
as an occupation, it is important that people remain fit-to-drive where it is safe to do so. 
Why does this matter? 
In order to address the occupation of driving, it is critical to understand why driving is so important to your 
clients. Here is a small review that will provide you with this context. 
Key Points: 
• Driving is a valued occupation, with more than 19 million registered motor vehicles in Australia
• Driving enables freedom, ease of access and promotes independent living
• Driving cessation is associated with increased rates of mortality

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_962.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 9 of 84 
What is your client’s (the driver’s) role? 
In all Australian states, the driver has the responsibility 
to notify the driver licensing authority if they have at 
the time of licensing or if they develop any long term 
or permanent injury or illness that may affect their ability 
to drive safely (Austroads, 2022). The driver 
is also responsible for adherence to all prescribed 
medication to ensure that they remain medically stable. 
When engaging in health-related treatment, the driver 
must also respond truthfully to questions from health 
professionals regarding their health status and the 
potential impact on their driving ability. 
Non-adherence with these criteria means the driver may be liable under common law. The driver 
should also be aware that they are responsible for any financial, insurance and legal consequences

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_963.text:
should also be aware that they are responsible for any financial, insurance and legal consequences 
if they are involved in an accident and had failed to notify the driver licensing authority (Austroads, 
2022) and/or their insurance company. 
What is the driver licensing authority’s role? 
The driver licensing authority (DLA) is responsible for the issuing, renewing, suspending, revoking 
and/or re-instating of licensing decisions of drivers. These decisions are made on a case-by-case 
basis and align with the national Austroads Assessing Fitness to Drive Guidelines (Austroads, 2022). 
To make these decisions about fitness to drive, the licensing authority relies on information gathered 
from a range of sources including police, medical and health professionals and anonymous reports 
from families, friends, and other members of the community. 
Each Australian state has different regulatory requirements for driver testing based on age and

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_964.text:
Each Australian state has different regulatory requirements for driver testing based on age and 
health status. See Table 1 for private vehicle drivers (Austroads, 2022). 
Why does this matter? 
As an occupational therapist, you have a responsibility to understand the driver’s role to be able 
to provide your clients with the appropriate education. 
Key Points: 
• Driver’s are required to notify their licencing authority of any long-term or permanent health
conditions
• Driver’s must adhere to prescribed medication to remain medically stable
• Non-adherence may result in the driver not being liable under common law
Why does this matter? 
Understanding the driver licencing authority’s role is important to provide perspective of 
your own duty of care and to enable you to provide the appropriate education to your client. 
Key Points: 
• The DLA is responsible for issuing, renewing, suspending, revoking, or reinstating licences

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_965.text:
• The DLA is responsible for issuing, renewing, suspending, revoking, or reinstating licences
• The DLA relies of information provided by police, health professionals, family, and others
• Each Australian state has different regulatory requirements for driver testing

chunk_970.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 P
 
age 11 of 84 
What is the medical practitioner’s role? 
Medical professionals are considered experts in 
diagnosing and treating medical conditions (Laycock, 
2010). Their role in assessing fitness to drive involves 
determining whether a person meets the national 
medical standards to hold a licence, as per 
Austroads fitness to drive guidelines. They are 
required to educate their patients, and notify the 
licencing authority if concerns are identified (Austroads, 
2022). Meeting the medical fitness to drive standards 
and being fit to drive are not the same, with the former 
being a determination as to whether there are any 
current medical conditions that may preclude a person 
from driving and the later concerned with an individual 
having adequate skills and behaviours to be able to 
drive (Austroads, 2022). 
General Practitioner’s (GP's) have a high level of authority when assessing medical fitness to drive.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_971.text:
However, there is a lack of evidence-based guidelines to support them to do this accurately and 
consistently (Laycock, 2010) and as a result evidence has shown that GP’s are often not good 
predictors of driving performance (Dickerson et al., 2018). GP training involves diagnosing and 
treating medical conditions, not determining the impact that these medical conditions may 
have on functional performance such as driving (Laycock, 2010). It has also been shown that 
GP’s often do not identify cognitive decline in their regular patients (Laycock, 2010). 
International studies have also shown that medical practitioners are not routinely discussing driving 
with their patients. In Sweden, Mardh et al. (2017) sought to determine compliance with driving 
regulations of post-stroke patients. They found that 81% of patient medical records did not include 
an entry about driving cessation despite regulations stating that it is mandatory for medical

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_972.text:
an entry about driving cessation despite regulations stating that it is mandatory for medical 
practitioners to discuss and document driving post-stroke. Similarly, in the United Kingdom 
McCarron et al. (2008) investigated adherence to driving regulatory guidelines. They found that 
very few patients received any advice regarding fitness to drive which resulted in 42% of patients 
driving within the one-month non-driving period post stroke, with four patients suffering seizures. 
In an Australian study by Sims et al. (2012) it was found that 90% of GP's completed medical 
reports only when prompted by the licensing authority, suggesting that only 10% were regularly 
Why does this matter? 
Understanding the medical role is important in being able to refer for medical opinion. 
Key Points: 
• Medical practitioners determine whether a person meets the national medical standards to hold a
driver’s licence

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_973.text:
driver’s licence
• Studies have highlighted inconsistences in medical practice with addressing driving due to a lack
of knowledge, time, confidence, and guidelines to support practice
Figure 6. Medical Doctor Fighting Coronavirus (see 
attribution 6, page 59)

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_974.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 12 of 84 
assessing driving with their patients. Other international studies have also highlighted that GP’s 
lack the knowledge, confidence and the time to adequately assess and make recommendations 
about fitness to drive (Jitkritsadakul & Bhidayasiri, 2016; Marshall et al., 2012; Sims et al., 2012). 
Additionally, in Canadian studies 80% of survey participants (practitioner’s or GP’s) reported that 
they felt that medical professionals are not the right profession to identify driving problems 
(Marshall et al., 2012; Sims et al., 2012), and highlighted the negative impact that this has on their 
patient-doctor relationship (Jones et al., 2012). These studies demonstrate inconsistencies in 
medical practice regarding assessing driving ability in medically at-risk drivers, which may result in 
prosecution for negligence due to the associated safety issues.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_975.text:
prosecution for negligence due to the associated safety issues. 
This is supported by a Coroners report (2017-2018) detailing three fatal incidents highlighting 
negligence due to under reporting of medically unfit drivers to the Victorian DLA. The first finding 
included an 87-year-old man who collided with a tree caused by an ischaemic event, which was 
identified by his GP but not reported. The second finding included an 85-year-old women who 
drove through a T intersection without braking, swerved and hit a tree which was likely caused by 
progressive cognitive decline over 7 years, which neither the GP or psychiatrist reported this to the 
DLA. The third finding included the death of a 68-year-old man riding a motorcycle who was hit by 
a vision impaired driver, which was identified but not reported to the DLA by two medical 
practitioners (Coroners Court of Victoria, 2018). These cases are not unique to Victoria, for

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_976.text:
practitioners (Coroners Court of Victoria, 2018). These cases are not unique to Victoria, for 
example a Coroners case in Tasmania described a 51-year-old male truck driver died when his 
truck veered across the road and up an embankment causing it to roll. His death was likely caused 
by cardiac arrhythmia resulting in a loss of consciousness and hypoxic/ischaemic brain damage. 
The driver was deemed fit to drive by a medical practitioner, despite his cardiac history however, 
there was no report to the DLA outlining the driving risk (Magistrates Court of Tasmania, 2017). 
Although some GP's may not be addressing fitness to drive in practice, it has been reported 
that the occupational therapy profession has been invaluable in relation to driving (Brooks et 
al., 2011; Jones et al., 2012). Often when GP's are unsure about fitness to drive, a referral to an 
occupational therapy driver assessor for further assessment is completed, highlighting the unique

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_977.text:
occupational therapy driver assessor for further assessment is completed, highlighting the unique 
skills that occupational therapists have to appropriately assess driving safety (Brooks et al., 2011).

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_978.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 13  of 84 
What is the occupational therapy driver assessor’s role? 
Within Australia, occupational therapists have been formally involved in assisting people with 
health conditions to drive for over twenty years (Unsworth, 2007). These occupational therapists 
complete post-graduate training in driver assessment and intervention to become occupational 
therapy driver assessors (OTDAs), an advanced scope of practice. OTDAs are trained to complete 
a two-phased process which includes a comprehensive off-road and a practical on-road 
assessment. 
The off-road assessment involves gathering information on driving history, the need and desire for 
driving, medical history, physical, sensory, and cognitive assessment and road law and road craft 
knowledge testing. Information gained from the off-road assessment is used to assist with 
identifying areas for further assessment during the on-road assessment. The on-road assessment

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_979.text:
identifying areas for further assessment during the on-road assessment. The on-road assessment 
is conducted with a driving instructor (in the driving instructors car) for safety purposes. Findings 
from the off and on-road assessment are then combined to make a recommendation regarding 
whether an individual is safe for driving, safe for driving with certain conditions on their licence or 
unsafe for driving. Recommendations for on-road rehabilitation are often suggested, with periodic 
re-assessments when required. These recommendations are provided either to the treating doctor 
and/or the licencing authority who makes final licencing decisions. For state-based jurisdictional 
differences regarding the OTDA role, please refer to Appendix A. 
While all OTDA's complete the same training to become an OTDA, some OTDA's will complete 
further training to specialize in certain areas for example, vehicle modifications. Therefore, when

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_980.text:
referring onto a OTDA for comprehensive assessment it is important to specify the reason for 
further assessment to ensure that the OTDA is able to address the area of concern. 
What is your role as a non-driver trained occupational therapist? 
Occupational Therapy Australia (OTA) confirm that “community mobility is a core scope of 
practice for occupational therapy. All occupational therapists understand the occupation of 
driving a vehicle as an instrumental activity of daily living enabling community 
mobility” (Occupational Therapy Australia, 2015, p.3). 
Why does this matter? 
Understanding the role of occupational therapists who have completed further training in 
driver assessment and rehabilitation is important to be able to discriminate between your role 
and when you may refer or seek further advice. 
Key Points: 
• To become an occupational therapy driver assessor post-graduate training is required

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_981.text:
Key Points: 
• To become an occupational therapy driver assessor post-graduate training is required
• A two-phased comprehensive assessment includes an off-road and practical on-road assessment
• Recommendations for safe driving are provided to the treating doctor and/or DLA
Why does this matter? 
Understanding your role is pivotal to maximising the safety of not only your clients but 
the wider community, while also addressing client-centred goals, maximising 
independence and improving the quality of life of your clients. 
Key Points: 
• Community mobility including driving is a core scope of occupational therapy practice
• Your role is imp ortant in educating and assessing the need for referral onto an OTDA
• Your role is important in exploring alternative mobility if driving is no longer safe

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_982.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 P
 
age 14  of 84 
Although all occupational therapists have the skills to address driving as an occupation, reduced 
knowledge of return to driving practices and confidence in being able to apply assessment results 
to the area of driving has led to inconsistencies in practice (Scott et al., 2021). 
Your role in addressing driving as part of your usual scope of practice includes several actions 
which can precede and help decide whether a comprehensive driving assessment conducted by 
an OTDA is required. Additionally, you also have a role in providing counselling and exploring 
alternative community mobility options when driving is deemed no longer safe (Scott et al., 2021), 
as outlined below. 
Commencement of driving discussions 
You have a duty of care and professional obligation to address all daily occupations as part of your 
usual scope of practice and this includes driving. During the initial consultations with your clients,

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_983.text:
you need to ensure that you are gathering information about your client’s driving history. 
Identification of driving as a meaningful occupation and goal 
You then need to gather information about whether your client wishes to continue driving and/or 
whether they wish to return to driving if they have ceased driving. If so, driving should be 
documented as a goal in the client’s file. This goal should meet SMART principles and include: 
Specific – Where does the client want to drive? How long does it take to get to the destination/s? 
How often does the client wish to drive? Who with? In which car will they drive? Is this automatic or 
manual? Do they need any technology to assist for example, navigation systems? 
Measurable – How will you know if the goal is achieved? What progress has been made? 
Achievable – What resources do they need to achieve this goal? Do they need an OT driving

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_984.text:
Achievable – What resources do they need to achieve this goal? Do they need an OT driving 
assessment? Considering their current medical conditions, is this realistic for the client now and in 
the future? Is driving an automatic or manual car realistic? 
Relevant – Why do they want to drive? 
Time-bound – By when? After a period of rehabilitation? 
An example of a SMART driving goal may be: 
“To able to return to driving an automatic car every day in order to independently get to/from the 
shops and my local GP, as well as drive my wife to social outings and visit my grandchildren by 
the end of October 2022”. 
Administration of physical, sensory, and cognitive assessments 
You use a range of physical, sensory, and cognitive screening tools and assessments as part of 
usual practice that can be used when thinking about driving as an occupation. For example, you 
may complete the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) (Folstein et al., 1975) to determine

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_985.text:
may complete the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) (Folstein et al., 1975) to determine 
whether the client will have issues with knowing when and whether they will remember to take 
their medication. The MMSE may also be completed to determine whether the client may have 
difficulty with remembering road rules.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_986.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 15  of 84 
As an occupational therapist, you are also skilled in conducting functional assessments which 
involves the application of observational skills to assess and analyse occupational performance. 
For example, observing a client preparing a meal to determine whether they have any cognitive 
impairments. These observations are often used to inform intervention planning for a range of 
occupations, but these can also be applied to driving. 
Provision of rehabilitation for deficits in physical, sensory, and cognitive 
impairments 
Following assessment, you provide rehabilitation to remediate physical, sensory, and cognitive 
impairments and reduce their impact on client occupational performance in a range of occupations. 
It is important to provide rehabilitation to achieve short term goals first, such as cooking a meal in 
order to work towards longer term goals such as driving. Addressing impairments in simple

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_987.text:
order to work towards longer term goals such as driving. Addressing impairments in simple 
occupations first can indirectly assist with improving readiness and potential for return to driving, as 
skills required for simple occupations are needed before more complex skills can be remediated 
such as those required for driving. 
Provision of driving process recommendations 
Driving process recommendations are defined as the processes a client pursues to return to driving 
(Scott et al., 2021). These processes usually pertain to determining the appropriate type and timing 
of referrals for further consultation, information gathering or assessment. This differs from driving 
outcome recommendations which are determined by an OTDA following an on-road driving 
assessment, with recommendations made to the GP and/or DLA. Please refer to Table 2 for 
potential driving process and driving outcome recommendations. 
TABLE 2. POTENTIAL DRIVING RECOMMENDATIONS 
Driving Process Recommendations

TABLE 2. POTENTIAL DRIVING RECOMMENDATIONS

(Completed by non-driver trained OT)

Gain further eyesight assessment

meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_989.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 16  of 84 
Education of medical clearance processes and insurance liability 
As an occupational therapist your duty of care and professional obligation involves educating 
clients concerning their responsibilities as a driver. This includes reporting any potential long-term 
or permanent health conditions that could impair their driving skills to the DLA. It is important to 
educate your clients that by reporting their health conditions to the DLA, that it does not mean that 
the DLA will automatically revoke their licence, however it is necessary to meet legal requirements. 
However, this reporting to the DLA should only occur when the client is ready to return to driving. 
The education you provide to your clients should also involve informing them of their responsibility 
to notify their insurance companies of any potential long-term or permanent health conditions.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_990.text:
to notify their insurance companies of any potential long-term or permanent health conditions. 
You should inform your clients to check with their insurance companies’ disclosure statements to 
ensure that coverage is provided despite their medical condition/s. It is important to educate your 
clients that if they fail to do this, it may result in their insurance coverage being affected if they are 
involved in an accident, as a result of not complying with their legal requirements to report 
long-term or permanent health conditions. See section 5 for client education handout. 
Provision of driving counselling when driving is no longer safe 
All drivers will have to cease driving at some point in time in their life and receiving appropriate 
counselling when driving is no longer safe is important to maintain quality of life. See section 5 for 
resources to support driving counselling conversations. 
Exploration of other community mobility options

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_991.text:
Exploration of other community mobility options 
The extensive skills you possess in supporting community mobility participation can guide clients to 
have greater autonomy, freedom and confidence when accessing the wider community. If driving is 
no longer safe, then you have a role in assisting your clients to explore other ways to access the 
community for example public transport training, scooter use, taxi, community services, safe 
walking etc. This will assist with minimising the impact of driving cessation and ensuring that your 
clients are safe within their community
.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_992.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 17 of 84 
What is the role of other health professionals? 
There are several health professionals who have roles and responsibilities in relation to driving 
evaluations in Australia (Austroads, 2022) including: 
• Medical practitioners (general
practitioners or specialists)
• Optometrists or orthoptists
• Occupational therapists (as discussed
throughout this document)
• Psychologists
• Physiotherapists
• Diabetes educators
• Nurse practitioners
• Case worker
The role of these health professionals is to advise the person regarding the impact of their 
health condition on their ability to drive. They have a responsibility to treat, monitor and 
manage the condition with ongoing consideration with fitness to drive standards, and to report 
this to the licencing authority. While all of these health professionals have a role with 
addressing driving, the occupational therapy role remains crucial in driving safety.
Why does this matter?

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_993.text:
Why does this matter? 
Understanding the role of other health professionals can assist with appropriate 
referrals to comprehensively address driving. 
Key Points: 
• Various health professionals have different roles/responsibilities regarding driving
• Their roles involve treating, monitoring, and managing conditions with respect to driving standards
• The occupational therapy role (both non-driver and driver trained) remains crucial in driving

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_994.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 18  of 84 
1.1 Austroads medical guidelines 
The Australian medical guidelines governing driving are designed to promote road safety by 
providing health professionals and driver licencing authorities with valid and consistent driving 
evaluation standards. These standards are titled ‘Assessing Fitness to Drive for commercial and 
private vehicle drivers’ which were jointly published by Austroads (Austroads, 2022) and the 
National Transport Commission. Please refer to section 5 (resources) to access the link to these 
guidelines. 
There are several medical conditions that are included in these guidelines that outline 
clear requirements for driver capabilities including: 
• Blackouts
• Cardiovascular conditions
• Diabetes
• Hearing loss and deafness
• Musculoskeletal conditions
• Neurological conditions
• Psychiatric conditions
• Sleep disorders
• Substance misuse
• Vision and eye disorders

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_995.text:
• Psychiatric conditions
• Sleep disorders
• Substance misuse
• Vision and eye disorders
As part of your practice, you should be familiar with these guidelines in order to provide education 
to your clients, and also to be able to know when to refer your clients to their medical practitioner 
for review and clearance processes. 
1.2 Ethical considerations 
Occupational Therapy Australia is the professional association for occupational therapists in 
Australia responsible for developing our Code of Ethics. The Codes of Ethics (Occupational 
Therapy Australia, 2014) requires you to balance the rights, legal obligations, and clinical needs of 
your clients. With regards to driving, you need to take into consideration your clients’ needs and 
desires for community mobility (and in some Australian states their confidentiality), but also the 
general needs and safety of the wider community. 
The standards are based on principles of beneficence, non-maleficence, honesty, veracity,

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_996.text:
The standards are based on principles of beneficence, non-maleficence, honesty, veracity, 
confidentiality, justice, respect and autonomy (Occupational Therapy Australia, 2014) and are 
regulated by the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Authority (AHPRA). The next section 
explores these concepts in relation to driving. 
Section 1 
Legal and Medical Standards 
What are the legal and medical guidelines that you need to know when 
addressing driving with your clients?

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_997.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 19  of 84 
1.3 Duty of Care 
For full details of your role and responsibilities with respect to driving, please refer to the Austroads 
Assessing Fitness to Drive guidelines. These guidelines state that if you have any concerns about 
your client’s ability to drive that you should inform the client not to drive until further medical and 
functional assessments are conducted. You also have a responsibility to educate your client of their 
responsibilities as a driver, which includes notifying the DLA of any long-term or permanent medical 
condition that could impact on their driving. As an occupational therapist you should comply with 
usual practice requirements and document these conversations clearly in the client’s file notes. 
As an occupational therapist, your training has provided you with unique skills in assessing the 
impact of physical, sensory, and cognitive deficits on occupational performance. As part of your

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_998.text:
impact of physical, sensory, and cognitive deficits on occupational performance. As part of your 
assessment, you should consider whether the client has the cognitive ability to understand, recall 
and therefore comply with your recommendations regarding driving. If concerns exist, then you 
should notify the DLA. If imminent concerns exist, then you should notify the police. 
You may be liable under civil law in cases where a court forms the opinion that you have not taken 
reasonable steps to ensure that the impaired client drives only in circumstances that do not place 
them or other members of the community of increased risk (see Table 2 for further details of 
reporting requirements and protections). 
1.4 Consent and indemnity 
Health professionals typically have both an ethical and legal duty to maintain confidentiality. The 
patient-professional relationship is built on trust, whereby personal information is disclosed to the

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_999.text:
health professionals as the client believes the information will remain confidential. While 
maintaining your client’s confidentiality is essential to your therapeutic relationship, in certain 
circumstances confidentiality may need to be breached. With respect to driving, your duty to breach 
confidentiality is legally qualified to maintain public safety. To be open and honest with your client, 
you should inform them of your intent to notify the DLA, however you do not need the client’s 
consent to do so and you can do so anonymously in order to protect your professional 
relationship. Most Australian states have legislations in place that also provide professional 
indemnity to any person who reports a driver to the DLA in good faith because of doubt 
about the ability of that driver to drive safely and therefore will be protected from any civil 
and criminal liability (see Table 3 for which Australian states provide indemnity) (Austroads, 
2022). 
1.5 Reporting of unfit drivers

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1000.text:
2022). 
1.5 Reporting of unfit drivers 
Reporting guidelines vary between Australian states. For most Australian states there is no legal 
obligation or requirement of you to notify the DLA if concerns exist of the client’s ability to drive, 
however South Australia and the Northern Territory do impose mandatory reporting for some health 
professionals (see Table 4) (Austroads, 2022). As stated earlier you have a ‘duty of care’ to your 
client and your broader community to intervene if public safety is at risk.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1001.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 20  of 84 
You should consider reporting directly to the DLA where the client: 
• Demonstrates reduced insight into the impact of their health condition on driving ability;
• Is unable to comply with your recommendations due to a cognitive impairment; and/or
• Continues to drive despite appropriate advice and recommendations causing public health
safety risks.
TABLE 3. REPORTING LEGISLATIONS FOR DRIVER TESTING IN AUSTRALIA 
(NON-MANDATORY REPORTING)

What do you have 
to do? 
You have a duty of care and professional obligation to give clear advice to your 
client of any impairment that may impact on safe driving ability. 
Following examinations, if you have identified physical, sensory, perceptual and/or 
cognitive impairment that is likely to impact on driving skills and endanger the

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word

chunk_1002.text:
cognitive impairment that is likely to impact on driving skills and endanger the 
public then you SHOULD in good faith notify the DLA (Victoria, New South 
Wales, Australian Capital Territory), registrar (Tasmania), CEO (Western 
Australia), Chief Executive (Queensland) to uphold your duty of care. 
What are the legal 
requirements? 
There are no mandatory reporting requirements. 
What protection do 
you have? 
Under the Road Transport Act 1999 (ACT); 2013 (New South Wales), Transport 
Operations Act (Queensland), Vehicle and Traffic Act 1999 (Tasmania), Road 
Safety Act 1986 (Victoria), Road Traffic Act 2008 (Western Australia) you are 
indemnified against any action, providing that you have a reasonable concern that 
your client is not fit to drive. You are protected from civil and criminal liability when 
breaching confidentiality to report to the DLA or registrar in good faith, without 
patient consent.

What do you have

of any impairment that may impact on safe driving ability. 
If you have reasonable cause to believe that your client suffers from physical,

What are the legal

You are mandated by law to report all clients who possess an impairment that

What protection do

possess and of the actions you will carry out. 
What protection do 
you have? 
Under the Motor Vehicles Act 1959 (South Australia) no civil or criminal liability is 
incurred in carrying out the duty imposed. 
Under the Motor Vehicles Act 1949 (NT) there is no indemnity cover available. 
Note: While the state of South Australia has mandatory reporting, this only applies to medical practitioners, 
opticians and registered physiotherapists. Therefore, occupational therapists practicing in South Australia 
should follow duty of care and professional obligations as per Table 3.
