meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1005.text:
Page 21  of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
In order to understand the importance of the occupational therapy role in addressing driving, 
a small review of the literature has been conducted for you to read, which describes the relevant 
screening and assessment practices used by key stakeholders in the field of driving. Overall, 
there is a range of literature to support driving assessment practices for all occupational 
therapists. Please see below for full details. 
2.1 Profile of novice drivers 
Obtaining a drivers licence is considered a milestone 
among adolescence and young adults (Cox et al., 
2016). While driving is an efficient form of transportation 
and is a step towards gaining independence from family 
(Constantinou et al., 2011), driving offers increased 
opportunities for paid employment and future plans for 
study (Cox et al., 2016). For young adults driving also 
adds to the development of personal identity and peer

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1006.text:
adds to the development of personal identity and peer 
acceptance which are both important factors for this 
population (Constantinou et al., 2011). 
Figure 7 .Photo of Person Driving (see attribution 7, page 59) 
Young adults possess a range of human factors that impact on driving safety such as cognition, 
fatigue, alcohol and engagement in risky and/or aggressive behaviours, which places them at a 
significantly higher risk of being involved in a collision than compared to any other age group 
(Constantinou et al., 2011). Evidence suggests that young adults are more likely to engage in 
risk-taking behaviours (Constantinou et al., 2011). This may be partly due to the ongoing 
development of the frontal regions of their brains particularly, executive functions which are 
responsible for inhibition, reasoning and decision making (Constantinou et al., 2011). In addition, 
young adults are still developing their driving skills, so when coupled with alcohol, drug use, peer

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1007.text:
pressure and fatigue, young adults often overestimate their skills and underestimate the driving 
task which contributes to an increased risk of accident (Constantinou et al., 2011). 
For those young adults who have been diagnosed with a health condition, obtaining a 
drivers licence is much more difficult than compared with their peers (Cox et al., 2016). 
Evidence suggests that young adults with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) have 
diminished executive functioning which causes difficulty with sustained attention, reduced 
resistance to distractions and poor self-monitoring which are crucial skills for driving (Barkley et 
al., 2002). In addition to reduced executive functioning, young adults with Autism experience an 
increased likelihood of becoming anxious while driving and are also less likely to identify socially 
relevant road hazards such as pedestrians walking out (Cox et al., 2016). There is also an

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1008.text:
relevant road hazards such as pedestrians walking out (Cox et al., 2016). There is also an 
increased association with co-existing conditions such as anxiety and depression which in 
isolation also can impact on driving safety (Barkley et al., 2002). 
Section 2 
Supporting Evidence-Based Practice 
What evidence supports your role as a non-driver trained occupational 
therapist when assisting clients with return to driving?

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1009.text:
Page 22  of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
Given that this population group is at the highest risk of collision while driving, health professionals 
who are working with young adults with medical conditions should be aware of the added 
complexities when addressing learning to drive and the feasibility of this. Health professionals 
need to ensure that these factors are taken into consideration when determining if and when 
further comprehensive driving assessment and/or on-road training is needed. 
2.2 Profile of adult drivers with health conditions 
Driving continues to be the main form of transport, representing 69% of working adults. 
Additionally, a further 5% of adults travel as passengers in a car for work and/or study purposes 
(Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2017). For this population group, driving represents an easy and 
efficient mode of transport to fulfill life roles such as being a parent, worker and/or carer.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1010.text:
efficient mode of transport to fulfill life roles such as being a parent, worker and/or carer. 
While there is a significant amount of driving research for both young and older adults, minimal 
research exists for middle-aged adults. Research has outlined that one’s driving experience has 
been linked with increased driving efficacy (León-Domínguez et al., 2017), highlighting that more 
experienced drivers are able to detect hazards sooner and have increased problem solving 
on the road (León-Domínguez et al., 2017). However, distracted driving among middle-aged 
adults is high including phone use, and the presence of children in cars. This is likely due to family 
and work obligations combined with an overconfidence in driving skill (Engelberg et al., 2015). 
There are many causal factors that can impact on driving safety and accidents, however the 
presence of medical conditions which cause serious impairments is a significant contributor to

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1011.text:
presence of medical conditions which cause serious impairments is a significant contributor to 
road safety (Austroads, 2022). The Austroads fitness to drive guidelines, outline a range of 
medical conditions likely to affect driving but these guidelines also acknowledge that it is not 
possible to define all conditions or a combination of conditions that could affect a person’s driving 
ability (Austroads, 2022). The guidelines also highlight that the condition itself may not impact on 
driving however possible side effects from medications can affect driving and these must also be 
appropriately assessed. It is important to consider the variety or perhaps multitude of health 
conditions that can impact on driving, however particular focus should be placed on 
conditions that affect cognitive and perceptual skills, as these conditions are less able to 
be compensated for unlike conditions that only affect physical skills that can easily be

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1012.text:
be compensated for unlike conditions that only affect physical skills that can easily be 
compensated for with adaptive equipment such as a spinner knob for one-handed steering 
(Unsworth, 2009). 
Health professionals need to better understand the impact of health conditions on driving 
performance to either support safe driving if possible and/or support community mobility when 
driving is considered unsafe.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1013.text:
Page 23  of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
2.3 Profile of older drivers 
The Australian population is ageing due to a number 
of factors including increased life expectancy, 
decreased death rate, higher standards of healt h 
care and declining birth rates (Australian Bureau of 
Statistics, 2016). Over the next 25 years, the 
Australian Bureau of Statistics predicts that the 
number of people aged 65 years and over is 
projected to double and will comprise to a population 
of 6.7 million (Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2018b). 
As our population ages, increasing numbers of older 
people 
expect to continue to drive (Strogatz et al., 
2020). Older adults driving has received considerable 
attention over the years (Liddle et al., 2012; 
Unsworth, 2007; Unsworth, 2009;  Unsworth et al., 
2012; Unsworth et al., 2019). 
Figure 8. Smiling Senior Man in Modern Car (see attribution 8, 
page 59)

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1014.text:
Figure 8. Smiling Senior Man in Modern Car (see attribution 8, 
page 59) 
Older drivers, particularly aged 85 years and older who continue to drive have 10 times greater 
risk of fatal car accidents compared to young males (Lantz, 2007). The relative frailty of older 
adults also means that they are more likely to have serious injuries or die when involved in 
vehicle crashes when compared to other age groups (Koppel et al., 2011; Lantz, 2007). When 
older drivers are involved in car accidents, evidence has shown that this occurs in the following 
road environments including, complex intersections, railway crossings, roadwork and constructions 
areas, high speed interchanges such as freeways, and road curves (Unsworth, 2009). 
While a general decline in physical, cognitive and sensory skills has been associated with 
the ageing process (Baldock et al., 2006), driving skills are more often impacted by health

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1015.text:
the ageing process (Baldock et al., 2006), driving skills are more often impacted by health 
conditions that are acquired with age (Moon et al., 2018). Health conditions such as stroke, 
Parkinson’s disease, multiple sclerosis and dementia are just a few examples of conditions that 
produce physical, cognitive, and sensory deficits that impede safe driving skills among older adults. 
Additionally, the aged population have the highest percentage of medication use such as, 
benzodiazepines which can also impact on driving skills (Lloyd et al., 2001). 
Studies have shown that some older drivers with cognitive changes can compensate for 
reduced driving skills through self-regulation of their driving behaviours, which may result in 
maintaining their licence for prolonged periods of time despite the presence of health conditions 
(Unsworth et al., 2007). Some self-restricting behaviours include not driving at night, driving within

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1016.text:
close proximately to home, and allowing increased gap selection between the vehicle in front. 
Despite this, drivers are unlikely to relinquish driving on their own (Unsworth et al., 2007). 
This is often due to a lack of insight into their condition (Lantz, 2007), but also due to the need 
to maintain independence and lifestyle choices, particularly for people living in rural or remote 
areas (Unsworth, 2009). While some older drivers inappropriately continue to drive causing 
significant safety issues, others appropriately cease or do continue to drive. However, some older 
drivers may also prematurely cease driving perhaps due to a lack of education or 
assessment from health professionals (Unsworth & Chan, 2016). The need to appropriately 
identify ‘at risk’ drivers to prevent injury from crashes and maintain road safety is a serious public 
health issue.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1017.text:
Page 24  of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
2.4 Screening and Assessment processes of functional abilities for 
driving 
Two ways to evaluate driving are documented in the literature: screening and assessment. 
Screening refers to the use of a few tools to obtain and review data to determine the need for 
further evaluation (Transportation Research Board, 2016). In contrast, assessment refers to the 
use of a battery of tools to comprehensively gather information which may involve reviewing 
medical history, use of clinical assessments and on-road driving assessment (Transportation 
Research Board, 2016). Literature supporting driving screening and assessment practices among 
professional groups are described below. 
What do you need to know about Driver Licencing Authority driving assessment 
practices? 
There is currently no descriptive or experimental literature used by the licencing authority

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1018.text:
There is currently no descriptive or experimental literature used by the licencing authority 
for the assessment of people who do not have a health problem. For those people with an 
identified health condition, further assessment is requested from health professionals who use 
standardised assessments tools to assess risk and make fitness to drive recommendations. 
In terms of on road assessments, a small proportion of licensing authorities’ driving instructors 
complete these assessments for only those people without an identified health condition. There 
is limited evidence to suggest this on-road assessment is standardised, when compared 
to on-road assessments completed by OTDAs which are based on set competency 
guidelines (Catchpole & Di Stefano, 2018). Many people who fail their DLA on-road assessment 
are referred to an OTDA for further comprehensive assessment and opinion, if it is believed that a

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1019.text:
are referred to an OTDA for further comprehensive assessment and opinion, if it is believed that a 
medical issue may be a contributing factor for the fail outcome (VicRoads, 2018). 
What do you need to know about Medical Practitioners driving assessment 
practices? 
Medical practitioners are required by law to 
assess people’s medical (as opposed to 
functional) fitness to hold a driver licence as per 
Austroads fitness to drive guidelines. Their role 
involves diagnosing medical conditions and 
reviewing this in line with the Austroads 
guidelines to provide medical clearance for 
driving or for a driver assessment. Despite 
this, practitioner’s around the world rarely use 
them (Jang et al., 2007). Shanahan et al. (2007) 
surveyed medical practitioners in Adelaide, 
Australia and found that they were unaware of 
the content of their jurisdiction of fitness to drive 
guidelines. 
Fig
ure 9. Close up Photo of a Stethoscope (see attribution 9, page 59)

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1020.text:
Page 25 of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
Similarly, Sims et al. (2012) reported that as a result of poor content knowledge, 38% of GP’s 
therefore contact the licencing authority for information about medical conditions when assessing 
driving. This research is now 9-14 years old but suggests that ongoing education on fitness to 
drive is required. 
Some research has focused on the development and trial of various screening tools for GP use 
when evaluating fitness to drive. Urlings et al. (2018) developed an office-based screening tool to 
aide medical practitioners with fitness to drive decisions. The battery consisted of Snellen chart 
for visual acuity, the functional reach test and knowledge of road signs test. However, the lack of 
use of cognitive tests in their screening tool raises serious validity and reliability concern 
as cognition has been shown to be a significant predictor of fitness to drive in older adults

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1021.text:
as cognition has been shown to be a significant predictor of fitness to drive in older adults 
(Mathias & Lucas, 2009). Cheal et al. (2019) conducted usability testing of a modified version of 
DriveSafe DriveAware to enable quick and effective use of GP's to screen for driving potential of 
adults on ipads. To capture the range of skills needed for driving, a variety of tools is needed for 
screening purposes. This requires increased time for completion, and time restraints to administer 
screening tools has been identified as a barrier to GP practice, when attempting to assess fitness 
to drive (Devos & Hawley, 2013). 
There are no clear guidelines as to what and how medical practitioners should be 
assessing medical fitness to drive which causes a lack of structure and consistency in 
practice (Laycock, 2010). Current practices are often opinion based rather than supported by 
empirical evidence (Molnar et al., 2005).

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1022.text:
empirical evidence (Molnar et al., 2005). 
What do you need to know about Occupational Therapy driving assessment 
practices? 
Once a driver is medically cleared as described 
above, the occupational therapy driver assessment 
process can officially begin. OTDAs are required to 
complete a comprehensive driver assessment 
which includes an off and on road assessment, 
as per competency standards (Fields & Unsworth, 
2017). The Occupational Therapy – Driver Off Road 
Assessment Battery (OT-DORA) was developed to 
comprehensively assess clients prior to completing 
an on-road assessment (Unsworth et al., 2012). 
This includes a battery of standard and 
unstandardised assessment tools to appropriately 
assess a range of skills needed to safely operate a 
Figure 10. Black Patient and Psychologist Discussing Problem in 
Office (see attribution 10, page 59) 
vehicle including, physical, sensory, perceptual, and cognitive skills. Many of these assessments

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1023.text:
vehicle including, physical, sensory, perceptual, and cognitive skills. Many of these assessments 
have demonstrated predictive validity for driving performance (Krishnasamy & Unsworth, 2011; 
Unsworth, 2011). 
Unsworth et
 al. (2019) recently outlined that three cognitive sub-tests from the OT-DORA have 
some predictive validity in assessing fitness to drive for people following stroke

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1024.text:
Page 26 of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
which can be used to assist when screening for suitability of medically at-risk drivers, and whether 
further on 
road assessment is needed. Other comprehensive assessments used by occupational 
therapy driver assessors 
internationally include the Rookwood Assessment Battery (McKenna et 
al., 2004), DriveSafe DriveAware (Kay et al., 2009), Cognitive Behavioural Driver's Inventory 
(Engum et al., 
1988), DriveABLE (DriveABLE Assessment Centre, 1998) and Driver Health 
Inventory (Edwards et al., 2008). There are also standard procedures for OTDAs when 
conducting on road assessments to maximise the validity, reliability and fairness of this 
component of the assessment (Catchpole & Di Stefano, 2018), and standardized assessments 
used in other countries such as P-drive (Patomella et al., 2006). Clinical decision training has also 
shown to 
be effective in assisting novice OTDAs to make informed decisions about fitness to drive

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1025.text:
shown to 
be effective in assisting novice OTDAs to make informed decisions about fitness to drive 
(Harries et al., 2018). A significant body of Australian literature has also been completed to support 
OTDAs to fulfil their role in assessing fitness to drive (Fields & Unsworth, 2017; Unsworth et al., 
2019; 
Unsworth et al., 2012; Unsworth et al., 2005). 
Non-OTDAs who are considering whether their clients are suitable to return to driving within their 
practice, can
 utilize a range of standardised and non-standardised assessment  tools to assist 
with their decision making and referrals. Many non-OTDAs can use non -driving related 
assessment tools, most involving observation of a range of instrumental activities of daily 
living (IADL) to inform driving potential (Stack et al., 2018). Non-OTDAs can also use a variety 
of other standardised assessment tools to identify motor, cognitive and perceptual deficits.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1026.text:
of other standardised assessment tools to identify motor, cognitive and perceptual deficits. 
Driving is a complex occupation therefore evidence suggests that a COMBINATION of 
assessments tool
s is required rather than relying on a singular tool to predict driving 
performance (Dickerson et al., 2014; Unsworth et al., 2012). Despite this, there is still no agreed 
upon screening tool/s
 that can accurately and consistently predict on road driving performance, 
which is why on-road assessment remains the gold standard for assessing fitness to drive 
(Dickerson et al., 2014). However, there is a need for non-OTDAs to screen and differentiate 
drivers to make accurate and timely referrals for comprehensive driving assessment including on- 
road testing, to reduce unnecessary costs for clients, reduce the demand for OTDAs and to 
maximise road 
safety. 
In a systematic review of systematic reviews (also known as an overview) by Fields and Unsworth 
(2017) outlined

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1027.text:
(2017) outlined 
the most commonly recommended cognitive and perceptual assessment tools 
within fitness to
 drive evaluations. Cognition is seen as a crucial factor that impacts driving 
performance, therefore 
assessment of cognition is needed in determining suitability for driving 
(Fields & 
Unsworth, 2017). Of the 12 included reviews, the most common assessment tools 
were the Trail Making Test B, Trail Making Test A, Useful Field of View, Rey-Osterrith 
Complex Figure Test, Mini Mental State Examination, The Clock Drawing Test and the Block 
Design Test (Fields & Unsworth, 2017). The evidence from this overview also suggests that when 
assessing cognition, t
he most important domain when predicting fitness to drive was executive 
function (Fields 
& Unsworth, 2017). 
As occupational
 therapists, functional or performance-based tests  usually take precedence over 
paper-based cognitive
 tests as they more closely resemble real-world like  activities, which can then

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1028.text:
tests as they more closely resemble real-world like  activities, which can then 
better identify potential difficulties in daily occupations. A review by Poulin et al. (2013) explored 
performance-based 
executive function assessments and outlined the assessments with the 
strongest reliability
 and validity. These included the Executive Function Performance Test

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1029.text:
Page 27 of 84 CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 
(EFPT), the Multiple Errands Test (MET) and the Assessment of Motor and Process Skills 
(AMPS). With regards to driving, the AMPS has demonstrated some promising findings in being 
able to discriminate between drivers who pass and fail their driving test however further research is 
needed (Dickerson et al., 2010). The MET-Home has also been researched in the field of driving. 
No statistically significant relationship was found between MET-Home scores and driving 
outcomes, there was a trend with increased rules broken, rule breaks and time taken with drivers 
who failed their on-road test. However, drivers who self-rated their MET-Home performance were 
statistically more likely to fail their on-road driving test. While it is recommended not to use the 
MET-Home to determine driving potential, further research is needed in this area (Scott et al., 
2024, unpublished).

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1030.text:
2024, unpublished).  
Table 5 outlines a selection of commonly used screening and assessment tools used within the 
field of driving (Dickerson, 2014; Dickerson et al., 2014; Fields & Unsworth, 2017; Marshall et al., 
2007; Unsworth et al., 2019). An overview (systematic review of systematic reviews) was undertaken 
to determine which assessment tools for predicting driving outcomes for people following a health 
condition could be used by non-OTDAs. To maximise clinical utility for non-OTDAs, tools were 
excluded if they: 1) were an off-road screening or assessment battery commonly used by 
occupational therapy driver assessors, 2) costed more than $500AUD, 3) took longer than 60 
minutes to administer, 4) were unable to be sourced from an academic library, 5) were not predictive 
of on-road performance, 6) were specifically used with one medical condition and 7) were to be 
administered by medical or psychology disciplines. Therefore, the included tools are all suitable for

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1031.text:
non-OTDAs to use, and a range of tools should be used to help inform your clinical reasoning when 
addressing driving with your clients. Note: To utilise the AMPS assessment tool, clinicians need to 
complete further training and certification with associated costs. However, for those clinicians who 
are already AMPS trained, you can proceed with using this tool (in combination with other 
assessments) to address driving in clinical practice. Please refer to Table 9 for further details of its 
predictive validity in driving (Dickerson et al, 2010). 
For further information of assessment tools for specific population groups, the following systematic 
reviews can be used:
• Stroke: Devos et al., (2021)
• Acquired Brain Injury: Alhashmi et al., (2023)
• Multiple Sclerosis: Krasniuk et al., (2019)
• Mental Health: Unsworth et al., (2017)
• Older adults & Chronic diseases: Dickerson (2014) & Dickerson et al., (2014)

3.1 Clinical intervention 
Please print or electronically type into the Response Sheet for Driving Flowchart 
(Appendix B) to document your responses when working through the flowchart. 
Initial assessment 
The initial assessment will typically be the 
usual assessment undertaken at your service 
to get to know the client including: 
• Reason for referral and/or admission to service
• Medical history
• Social history
• Home environment
• Previous occupational performance
• Current occupational performance
• Current roles, routines, and habits Figure 11. Women in Yellow and Green Floral Shirt Washing 
Vegetables (see attribution 11, page 60) 
Driving history 
You should also gather information about your client’s driving history as it can help to inform your 
clinical reasoning regarding the need for further comprehensive assessment. Some areas to ask 
your clients about include: 
• Number of years of driving experience?

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1037.text:
your clients about include: 
• Number of years of driving experience?
• Age commenced driving?
• Where and how they learnt to drive?
• Current licence status? Ie. Which state is it, current restrictions?
• Types of driving experience? i.e. city, freeway, interstate
• Any previous licence suspensions, fines or driving accidents?
• Type of car? i.e. automatic or manual
• Is the client currently driving? Why not? If not, when did they last drive?
• Any difficulty currently driving such as getting lost?
• Are there any times when you feel like you shouldn’t be driving? ie. After night-time
medication, feeling unwell, when abusing substances?
Gathering this information can be sensitive as your client may wish to not disclose some of this 
information due to fear of losing their licence. It is important to corroborate this information with

What are some of the methods and administration procedures that can

chunk_1039.text:
a family member, but to be cautious that they may also not disclose some of this information 
particularly if the carer does not drive, as if your client loses their licence this will significantly 
impact on their daily life too. Some questions you can ask their family member or carer include: 
• Do you feel safe as a passenger?
• Do you have to assist with their driving at all? Ie. Prompting/direction when driving?
• Do you have any concerns about their ability to drive?
• Are you reliant on their ability to drive to access the community?
Step 1. Identify your client’s needs for community mobility 
Community mobility is defined as “moving around in the community and using public or private 
transportation such as driving, walking, bicycling, or accessing and riding in buses, taxi cabs, or 
other transportation systems” (American Occupational Therapy Association, 2021, p. 1). 
Community mobility provides individuals with independence, freedom, and links to their

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1040.text:
Community mobility provides individuals with independence, freedom, and links to their 
occupational identities. Its purpose is to enable transportation from one place to another to enable 
people to participate in other occupations of meaning and purpose. 
The role you have in evaluating safety and providing interventions to address community mobility 
issues varies and may include: 
• Screening for passenger safety ie. Seating, positioning, seatbelt use, cognitive or
behavioural impairments that may impact on driver safety
• Assessing abilities to cross the road and negotiate curbs
• Reading signage
• Driving readiness and ongoing safety
• Public transport access and re-training
• Creating transportation alternatives and community resources
• Scooter assessment and/or prescription
If driving is no longer considered safe, then exploring other forms of community mobility through 
appropriate assessment and intervention is required to maintain independence, freedom, and

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1041.text:
appropriate assessment and intervention is required to maintain independence, freedom, and 
occupational participation in the community. 
Step 2. Identify if driving is a valued occupation 
During initial interactions with your client, you have gathered information to determine if driving is a 
valued occupation. This may involve clients who are currently driving, who wish to continue to 
drive, and clients who have ceased driving who wish to return to driving. 
Here are some questions that may assist you in understanding the importance of driving with your 
clients: 
• Is driving important to you?
• What does driving enable you to do?
• Does your partner or family member drive too?
• Would it be easier or harder to fulfill your usual routine if you could no longer
drive?
• Tell me about some places that you drive to. If you could no longer drive, how
would you get there?
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 30 of 84

CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 P
 
age 31  of 84 
Step 3. Conduct screening assessments 
If your client values driving as an occupation and wants to continue/resume driving, then you may 
consider conducting screening assessments. As part of medical fitness to drive guidelines, there 
are range of vision standards for driving clearance (Austroads, 2022). These include: 
• Visual acuity (with or without glasses) of 6/12
• Visual fields <120 degrees horizontal plane
Your client must meet these visual standards in order to progress any further with the 
driving process as per the Austroads medical standards. You can refer to any optometrist or 
orthoptist and request completion of the DLA eyesight report to obtain visual clearance for driving 
standards. Note: any visual defects should prompt a referral to an optometrist or orthoptist for a full 
visual assessment. 
The Bells test (Gauthier et al., 1989) is used to assess for the presence of unilateral neglect which

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1043.text:
may be present in clients with neurological problems. If the client presents with unilateral neglect, 
then the client is not safe to pursue the driving process (Unsworth, 2011). If the client has 
demonstrated >4 errors it is likely that that your client is unsafe to drive (Mazer et al., 1998). 
Generally, research has shown that neglect persisting greater than 3 months post neurological 
event is unlikely to resolve (Hier et al., 1983), therefore the client should be educated on driving 
cessation and to explore other community mobility alternatives (refer to step 1). 
If the client presents with deficits in attention, then this should be recorded in the analysis summary 
to determine the potential impact on driving performance (refer to step 5). 
Step 4. Conduct assessments 
Standardised assessments 
Please refer to Table 5 for a selection of common standardised assessment tools used in the field

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1044.text:
Please refer to Table 5 for a selection of common standardised assessment tools used in the field 
of driving. While this table provides tools with predictive validity in driving, no singular tool can 
accurately and consistently predict driving performance, therefore a combination of tools is 
recommended to help assess a range of areas and inform your clinical reasoning when making 
recommendations about your client’s ability to drive. It is suggested that you choose a range of 
assessments (both standardised and performance-based) which are specific to your client’s 
medical condition and associated impairments, to help inform your clinical reasoning and 
recommendations.

meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

Functional task analyses 
If a client has difficulty performing simple occupations such as showering or preparing a hot drink, 
then it is highly likely that the client does not possess the skills to drive safely. As driving is 
considered an instrumental activity of daily living (IADL), assessing other IADLs can be an 
important part of your assessment, as these occupations will encompass similar cognitive skills to 
perform the occupation. Some occupations to assess may include: 
• Shopping
• Financial management
• Meal preparation
• Health management i.e. medications, appointments
To help inform your thinking processes, also known as clinical reasoning, please refer to Table 6 
which provides you with various clinical reasoning questions throughout each step of the driving 
flowchart (Unsworth, 2021). 
Please refer to Table 7 for clinical reasoning definitions.

• How will the identified impairments impact on driving?
Step 7. Results Focus on pr ocedural (scientific), ethical and conditional reasoning 
• Are these impairments new or existing?
• Is the condition expected to improve? Consider recommending no
driving until condition returns to normal.
• Is the condition expected to deteriorate? Consider recommending no
driving and further OTDA assessment.

These clinical reasoning definitions were developed by Unsworth (2004) and Unsworth (2021) 
and form the hierarchical model of clinical reasoning in occupational therapy practice. These 
different modes of thinking are defined as the thinking processes clinicians use when 
undertaking their practice, which highlights the unique analytical skills occupational therapists 
possess. They have been included in this pathway to promote expert practice and are worth 
consideration when working through your clinical reasoning, as they can easily be applied when 
addressing return to driving. 
TABLE 7. CLINICAL REASONING DEFINITIONS 
Worldview Worldview is not a type of reasoning however encompasses a clinicia ns’ 
spiritual and ethical values and beliefs, which provides an overview of the 
world and therefore informs all clinical reasoning. 
Ethical Reasoning Informs your deci sion-making and actions based on a moral dilemma, which

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1050.text:
Ethical Reasoning Informs your deci sion-making and actions based on a moral dilemma, which 
may conflict with another moral dilemma. 
Scientific Reasoning Utilises a bio -medical approach to assist with hypothesis generation and 
testing to scientifically reason through your practice with a client. 
Narrative Reasoning Utilises a phenomenological ap proach to understand the meaning of your 
client’s illness and their experience of living with that illness. 
Diagnostic Reasoning Used to identify your c lient’s impairments and occupational performance 
issues, which can help inform realistic goal setting and outcomes. 
Procedural Reasoning Refers to the reas oning processes used when evaluating and determining 
which interventions (ie. your procedures) to be used with your client. 
Interactive Reasoning Used to help get to know who your client is and how best to communicate 
with t
hem both verbally and non-verbally. This type of reasoning is commonly

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1051.text:
with t
hem both verbally and non-verbally. This type of reasoning is commonly 
used to help build rapport with your client. 
Conditional Reasoning Used when trying to understand what is meaningful to the person which 
invol
ves you taking into consideration of your client’s past, present and future 
circumstances based on their health condition. 
Pragmatic Reasoning Refers to reasoning abou t personal, organisational, political, and economic 
contexts which involves consideration of resource restraints, financial 
limitations and also your client’s motivation levels. 
Step 5. Analysis Summary 
Following assessment, you should make a list of the client’s strengths and occupational 
performance issues from the various assessments. These could include physical, sensory, 
perceptual, psychosocial and/or cognitive strengths or limitations. 
Some strengths of your client may include: 
• Writing a shopping list (planning and upper limb dexterity)

• Writing a shopping list (planning and upper limb dexterity)
• Able to walk around shops with no rests (good mobility and endurance)

Some occupational performance issues of your client may include: 
• Increased time to read the shopping list (slowed processing)
• Did not collect all items on shopping list at the shops (attention)
• Difficulty using the self-check out at the register (new learning and problem solving)
Step 6. Evaluation 
To make sense of the analyses, you should then ask yourself if there are any physical, cognitive, 
perceptual, sensory, or psychosocial issues listed in Step 5 that are likely to impact on driving? 
Table 8 highlights some examples of links between occupational performance issues, impairments, 
and potential impact on driving skills. If your client demonstrates impairments in one or more of 
these domains, it is likely that your client requires further on-road assessment to determine driving 
suitability and ensure safety. 
If the answer is no, as there are no functional impairments that would impact on driving skills,

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1054.text:
If the answer is no, as there are no functional impairments that would impact on driving skills, 
then you should refer onto a medical practitioner or GP to obtain medical clearance prior to return 
to driving. Ensure that you clearly document your outcomes and recommendations to both the GP 
(Appendix D) and your client (Appendix E), which involves notifying their insurance company. 
If the answer is yes, please refer to step 7 for further details.

Step 7. Results 
Once you have determined that the client presents with functional impairments that will likely 
impact on driving skills, you will need to determine whether these impairments are able to be 
rehabilitated and remediated and if so, what the expected timeframes for recovery are likely to be. 
Progress during rehabilitation should be monitored through re-assessment at various time points, 
including clear documentation to your client (Appendix E). 
If your client continues to present with functional impairments as they have plateaued with their 
rehabilitation and/or as a result of their progressive medical condition, then you should refer your 
client onto a medical practitioner for medical opinion and/or medical clearance (Appendix D). This 
is required for the client proceed onto an on-road assessment. 
In some states, notification to the licencing authority is mandatory here. You should only be 
notif

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1062.text:
notif
ying the licencing authority when the client is ready to re-commence driving. However, 
if you have identified immediate risk such as the client does not have insight into their 
impairments and the client will drive regardless of your recommendation then notification 
to the licencing authority may have to occur earlier to reduce this risk. You are indemnified 
against any criminal action, providing you have reasonable concern that the client is not fit 
to drive. Please refer to Section 1: Legal and Medical standards for further details on reporting 
legislations and professional indemnity cover. 
Note:
 that regardless of whether there are any functional impairments present or not, you should 
be aware of the recommended return to driving timeframes as per the Austroads medical 
standards. For example, a person cannot return to driving for 4 weeks following a cerebral infarct 
even if no functional impairments are present. It is important to educate your client of these

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1063.text:
even if no functional impairments are present. It is important to educate your client of these 
restricted timeframes as a result of their medical condition. 
Simultaneously, you will need to refer onto an occupational therapy driving assessor for 
comprehensive driving assessment. While there is a cost for OTDA assessment, these can vary up 
to $1000 depending on different funding models, reports required, public or private settings and 
location. Each state has different methods of sourcing an OTDA however, you can visit the 
Occupational Therapy Australia website https://otaus.com.au/find-an-ot to do this. Victorian 
clinicians can also source an OTDA via the VicRoads website which lists qualified OTDAs and 
regions they service in a pdf document located under ‘how to locate an Occupational Therapy 
Driver Assessor’ here: https://www.vi
 croads.vic.gov.au/licences/health-and-driving/information-for- 
health-professionals/occupational-therapist

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

health-professionals/occupational-therapist 
If the client’s functional impairments are not able to be rehabilitated, or the condition is a 
progressive medical condition and it has been deemed by a medical practitioner and/or an OTDA 
following on-road assessment that your client is unsafe to continue or resume driving, then you 
should consider providing counselling for driving cessation (see section 5) and explore alternative 
community mobility options (see step 1 for further details). It is important that your client notifies the 
driver licencing authority here for licence cancellation.

3.2 Administration of screening assessments 
This section details how to administer screening assessment tools which includes procedures, 
scoring methods and where to source this relevant information. 
For administration of other standardised and performance-based tools, please refer to Table 5 on 
where to source the tool which will provide further information within the associated manuals.  
Visual acuity 
Visual acuity is assessed by a Snellen Chart (20 ft/6m). 
Note: although there are various free versions available online these are not always reliable due to 
inaccurate sizing, therefore it is recommended to purchase your own Snellen chart (see Table 5 of 
where to source Snellen Charts). 
What do you need to do? 
• Position the Snellen chart 6m from the client’s eye level.
• Ask the client to stand at the appropriate location and cover one eye.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1066.text:
• Ask the client to stand at the appropriate location and cover one eye.
• Ask the client to read the letters out loud, beginning from the left-hand side of the top row.
• Repeat this process for the opposite eye and if the client wears glasses (with their glasses
on).
• Record the smallest row of letters accurately read by the client with only one error.
What does this mean? 
Legal requirements in Australia state that the client must have 6/12m (20/40ft) of binocular static 
acuity (with or without glasses) in order to drive (Austroads, 2022; Unsworth, 2011). If the client 
makes any errors with visual acuity, consider a referral to an optometrist or orthoptist for further 
assessment. 
See example of a Snellen Chart located here: https://www.austin.org.au/Assets/Files/snellen- 
chart.pdf

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1067.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 40  of 84 
Visual fields 
To assess visual fields, the Confrontation Visual Fields Test can be used (Elliot et al., 1997). 
What do you need to do? 
• Position yourself in a seated position opposite the client with your knees touching.
• Ask the client to remove any glasses and to cover one eye.
• Ask the client to look directly at your nose.
• Hold up a pen (with a red dot at the tip) about 30cm away from the top of your client’s
head, then move it in and arc beginning on a vertical plane outside of the client’s vision
then into the midline. Repeat this on a horizontal plane.
• Ask the client to “look at my nose; do not look anywhere else. Tell me when you can see
the red dot out of the corner of your eye” (Unsworth, 2011, p. 19).
• Ask the client to cover the other eye and repeat the above.
• Record the errors made on the horizontal and vertical and oblique meridians of both eyes
using Appendix C.
What does this mean?

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1068.text:
using Appendix C.
What does this mean? 
Legal requirements in Australia state that the client must have 110 degrees of binocular visual field 
to drive. If the client demonstrates any delay or errors in identifying the pen, then it is likely that a 
visual field defect is present and referral to an optometrist or orthoptist for further assessment is 
needed (Unsworth, 2011; Austroads 2022). 
Unilateral neglect 
Unilateral neglect can be assessed using the Bells test (Gauthier et al., 1989). The administration 
time is approximately 5 minutes. 
The Bells Test and administration instructions can be freely downloaded from Stroke Engine here: 
https://strokengine.ca/en/assessments/bells-test/ 
3.3 Interpreting assessment tool outcomes 
Following completion of the included assessment tools, a few methods can be utilised to help 
interpret the assessment outcomes. When conducting these assessments, functional

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1069.text:
interpret the assessment outcomes. When conducting these assessments, functional 
observations notes should be taken to allow time to reflect and apply your clinical reasoning to 
generalise how impairments in one occupation can potentially impact on driving skills. 
The use of cut off scores can also be used to interpret the assessment results as outlined in Table 
9; however, these scores suggest that further investigation is needed and should be used 
combination with functional assessment outcomes to assist with guiding your clinical reasoning 
and the need for further assessment with an OTDA as no single assessment tool has 
demonstrated consistent predictive validity for driving outcomes, therefore recommendation to 
cease driving should not be based solely on these cut off scores.

3.4 Question and Answers 
Below are a series of questions and answers developed to assist clinicians with some complex 
decision making when determining driving process recommendations. 
How long is my client not allowed to drive for once they get home from hospital, and who 
do they need to get permission from to resume driving? 
There are no specific time frames restricting a person from driving as each individual is different. 
The Austroads Assessing Fitness to Drive Guidelines (Austroads, 2022) outline the medical 
standards for driving. You can inform your client that they will need to seek medical clearance prior 
to resuming driving, which is completed by a medical professional in the hospital or community. 
You can also inform your client that while they may be medically fit to resume driving, they may 
experience some functional impairments that could impact on their driving therefore further

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1080.text:
experience some functional impairments that could impact on their driving therefore further 
assessment and recommendations from a non-driver trained occupational therapist may also be 
needed. 
What do you do if my client reports they feel fine to drive? Can they just resume driving? 
No, your client must seek medical clearance before returning to driving. You must also ensure that 
you have fully assessed your client to make sure that there are no ongoing functional limitations 
that may impact on driving. 
My client reports “my rehab doctor has said that I can’t drive for 4-6 weeks. Will they notify 
my GP or licensing authority?” Is this correct? 
Following time in hospital, a medical practitioner will provide a detailed discharge summary to the 
clients GP, which should include recommendations about driving. Inpatient medical practitioner’s 
will not often notify the licensing authority as following this period, as clients may present with no

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1081.text:
ongoing impairments that could impact on driving therefore there is no need to notify the licensing 
authority or, it may be too early to determine the permanent impact of the health condition on 
driving. Therefore, it is important that appropriate follow up is in place in the community to ensure 
that their condition is monitored to determine if there are potential safety concerns driving and 
therefore if notification is required. 
When does my client have to notify the licensing authority of their change in health status? 
This may very between states, however your client should inform the licensing authority (usually 
through obtaining medical clearance and completion of the medical report) when they are ready to 
commence the driving process. 
Prior to this, you should inform your client that they are unable to drive until the complete the 
necessary steps are taken ie. await further recovery, obtain medical clearance. However, if you

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1082.text:
necessary steps are taken ie. await further recovery, obtain medical clearance. However, if you 
have concerns regarding your client’s ability to comply with your recommendation for example, 
reduced insight into their impairments and therefore there are potential safety risks you have a 
duty of care to notify the licencing authority earlier. This may result in licence conditions being put 
on their licence to restrict their driving until the appropriate steps are completed.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1083.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 44  of 84 
What do you do when family members do not want their loved one driving anymore 
following a recent admission to hospital? 
If family members have concerns about their loved one driving, there are several steps they could 
take: 
• You could provide them with some resources to help support driving cessation discussions
(see resources section for further details).
• You could suggest an Occupational Therapy driving assessment to comprehensively
assess their safety who may also make recommendations to prolong their driving while still
ensuring safety ie. no freeway driving.
• You could suggest that they discuss this with their GP.
• You could suggest that they anonymously write to the licensing authority outlining their
concerns.
After commencing the return to driving process, what happens if my client decides that 
he/she no longer wishes to continue driving?

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1084.text:
he/she no longer wishes to continue driving? 
You should document any assessment outcomes to date and outline the reasons for cessation. 
You should recommend your client to surrender their licence by visiting their local driving licensing 
authority. For identification purposes, the client may wish to apply for  a proof of age card that can 
be used across all Australian states. This can be completed online here https://service.vic.gov.au/
find-services/personal/apply-for-a-proof-of-age-card       
The
 client will also need to explore other community mobility options post driving cessation. 
Please
 refer to section 5 for further details on how to further assist your client. 
Can
 my client go through the driving assessment process if they have never driven before 
but want to start? 
If your client suffers from a long term or permanent health condition that could impact on driving 
then they will likely require an OT driving assessment to enable safe driving however they need 
to

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott

chunk_1085.text:
to 
follow the DLA processes for obtaining a learner’s permit licence first. They will then need to 
obtain medical clearance prior to participating in an OT driving assessment. 
What
 if my client refuses to undergo assessment as outlined in the return to driving 
process? 
You should explain to your client their role and responsibility as a driver, which includes notifying 
the DLA
 of any permanent or significant health condition that may impact on driving. You should 
also explain your role as an occupational therapist and that by undergoing relevant assessments 
you will
 determine if further on-road assessment is warranted. If you have concerns about your 
client’s ability to drive based on their medical conditions, please refer to section 1 regarding your 
duty
 of care, consent, and reporting legislations to the DLA.

chunk_1086.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 P
 
age 45  of 84 
What if the client scores above the cut off scores, but you still have concerns about the 
client’s ability to drive safely? 
If your client scores above the suggested cut off scores following physical, cognitive, sensory or 
and/or psychosocial assessments and you still have concerns about the client’s ability to drive 
safely, you could consider the following: 
1. Ongoing rehabilitation to remediate impairments or,
2. Recommend  an occupational therapy driver on-road assessment, as this is still considered
the gold standard to assessing fitness to drive.
My client requires an Occupational Therapy driving assessment. What can be provided to 
assist my client with organizing this? 
Each state has different methods of sourcing an OTDA however, you can visit the Occupational 
Therapy Australia website www.otaus.com.au/find-an-ot t
o do this. Victorian clinicians can also

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1087.text:
Therapy Australia website www.otaus.com.au/find-an-ot t
o do this. Victorian clinicians can also 
source an OTDA via the VicRoads website which lists qualified OTDAs and regions they service in 
a pdf document located here: https://www.vicroads.vic.gov.au/licences/health-and- 
driving/information-for-health-professionals/occupational-therapist 
My client is from interstate and wishes to resume driving, what do you do? 
There may be a few different pathways that your client can follow depending on whether they are 
planning to return to their original state or whether they plan on remaining in their current state. If 
your client has a new medical condition and they are planning to return to their original state, then 
they need to notify the DLA of the state in which their licence was issued. However, if your client 
wishes to remain in the current state for greater than 6 months then they need to visit a customer

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1088.text:
wishes to remain in the current state for greater than 6 months then they need to visit a customer 
service centre to complete a transfer of licence application form. They will need to outline whether 
they have any medical conditions that may impact on driving here and depending on the type and 
severity of the medical condition the DLA may either transfer their licence pending a new medical 
report OR they may refuse the transfer of licence until a medical report with clearance is provided. 
My client is awaiting medical clearance, are they still able to supervise a learner driver? 
No. Your client needs to be medically and functionally fit to be able to supervise a learner driver. 
This is because if something was to happen with the learner driver, your client needs to be able to 
take over control of the vehicle which requires them to have medical clearance and deemed 
functionally suitable to operate a motor vehicle.

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1089.text:
functionally suitable to operate a motor vehicle. 
My client self restricts their driving by only driving locally and during the day. Do they need 
to inform the DLA or have an OT driving assessment? 
No. Your client may be self-restricting to maintain the longevity of their licence, however they be 
self-restricting due to underlying medical changes which is affecting their driving skills. It is 
recommended that they discuss driving with their GP at regular intervals to maintain their medical 
fitness to drive. You should also inform your client that if they recognize any changes in their health 
that could impact their driving that they notify their GP as this may affect their insurance. You may 
want to discuss this with a family member (if possible) to increase the likelihood of this occurring.

From an ethical and legal perspective, clear and effective communication (including documentation 
practices) between your client, medical and other health professionals is an important aspect in 
maximising compliance to proposed recommendations. 
4.1 Medical letter template 
When communicating with medical health professionals, which could 
include a specialist or a GP, it is important that you include the 
results of the assessments conducted which have informed your 
various modes of clinical reasoning and therefore your 
recommendations. This will allow the medical practitioner to 
complete the medical report for the DLA with the appropriate 
information. 
Medical letter template can be found in Appendix D. 
Note: the DLA are only able to make licensing decisions based on the information that has been 
provided to them, therefore the more evidence you provide will allow for the most appropriate 
decision to be made.

chunk_1092.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 47 of 84 
4.2 Client letter template 
Following your assessment, it is important to provide the 
client with the outcome and therefore your 
recommendations both verbally and in a written format. 
When the client receives recommendations that she/he 
is not able to drive, she/he may become emotional. 
Additionally, there is a lot of information to take in which 
may impact on their ability to recall important pieces of 
education. Therefore, having a summary of all the details 
in writing can be helpful for the client to refer to later. 
Another reason for your outcomes and 
recommendations to be in writing is that the client’s 
family members will be able to read this information if 
they were not present in the session which may aide in 
compliance with your recommendations. 
Client letter template can be found in Appendix E.

chunk_1093.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 48 of 84 
4.3 Transition of care within and/or between health services 
Regardless of your workplace, clients who wish to resume driving will often be involved with 
various health care services and/or will transition between various areas within the same health 
care service for example, transfer from inpatient rehabilitation to community rehabilitation. It is 
important that driving is addressed as early as reasonably practicable to receive the appropriate 
education and advice to maximise safety. A client’s condition is likely to change throughout their 
health care journey, so to maximise consistent messaging and ensure appropriate follow up, 
communication between colleagues and health services is important. 
Handover template can be found in Appendix F. 
Figure 14. Modern Businesswomen in Casual Outfit Talking on 
Mobile Phone in Office (see attribution 14, page 60) 
4.4 Driving Education Handout

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1094.text:
Mobile Phone in Office (see attribution 14, page 60) 
4.4 Driving Education Handout 
Educating your clients of their roles and responsibilities as a driver is part of your duty of care and 
professional obligation. There are several key points of information that are important to educate 
your clients about. Additionally, clients may be overwhelmed or may be experiencing memory 
changes therefore being able to provide your clients with this information in a written format can 
help increase compliance. 
Driving education handout can be found in Appendix G.

5.5 Alternative Mobility Options 
Local Councils 
Local councils can provide a range of services and further information to support people to access

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott

chunk_1102.text:
Local councils can provide a range of services and further information to support people to access 
their local communities. They can also provide services which reduce the need for accessing the 
community. Examples include: 
• Cycling and walking tracks
• Public transport options within their local area
• Carshare options
• Carpooling programs
• Assisted Transport (door-to-door pick up and drop off car services)
• Community Transport buses
• Services such as, meals on wheels or shopping assistance
To be eligible to receive these council community support services this may require a My Aged 
Care assessment. It is recommended that you provide your clients with their local councils contact 
details to further enquire about their eligibility and options. 
Volunteer Transport Options 
There are a range of volunteer transport options to assist with meeting the everyday needs of 
people in their local communities by being more mobile and having safe and reliable transport, for 
example:

Multi-Purpose Taxi Program (MPTP) 
Within some Australian states the MPTP makes transport more accessible and affordable for 
people with a severe disability. This usually requires the GP to assess your client’s eligibility and 
apply online for half price taxi cards. 
Other 
There may also be a range of informal supports that can assist people with accessing their local 
communities. Commencing these discussions with your clients may create awareness to initiate 
these conversations with the following: 
• Family or friends
• Neighbours
• NDIS transport funding

chunk_1106.text:
Drivers Decisions Workbook/s 
This workbook was developed by Eby et al. (2000) through the University of Michigan, United 
States of America. This workbook guides older drivers to reflect on age-related changes in abilities 
and habits that could affect safe driving. The five sections of the workbook include: 
• On the road
• Seeing
• Thinking
• Getting around
• Health
This workbook also includes tips on driving cessation and other forms of transportation
https://www.michigan.gov/-/media/Project/Websites/agingdriver/MDOT_DrivingDecisionsWorkbook

chunk_1107.text:
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 Page 53 of 84 
A workbook tiled ‘Driving and staying independent: A decision aid for older drivers’ was developed 
by the NSW Government and the University of Wollongong to help empower older adults to make 
informed decisions when it comes to driving. It takes drivers through 5 steps to assist with making 
decisions about whether to continue, modify or retire from driving. The five steps of the workbook 
include: 
• Step 1: To help with my decision about driving
• Step 2: Weighing up my options
• Step 3: What else do I need to make my decision?
• Step 4: Making my decision: What is the best option for me?
• Step 5: Now that I have decided
A copy of the interactive workbook can be located here https://www.uow.edu.au/science-medicine- 
health/research/older-drivers-resource/ 
Driving Change Collaboration (2021). Driving and staying independent: A decision aid for older drivers. The 
University of Wollongong.

Drive Focus
Drive Focus was created by the Driver Rehabilitation Institute in the United States.  Drive Focus is

related skills. There are currently Melbourne and Brisbane routes available, with further state

chunk_1112.text:
Glossary of Terms 
CRICOS Provider No. 00103D | RTO Code 4909 P
 
age 56  of 84 
OT and OTDA 
Occupational Therapist or Occupational Therapy. 
OTDA refers to an Occupational Therapy Driver Assessor who has completed additional training to 
specialize in driving assessment and rehabilitation. Non-OTDA’s are occupational therapists with 
either undergraduate or post-graduate training to become occupational therapists, however, are 
not trained to complete comprehensive driving evaluations. 
DLA 
Driver’s License Authority refers to the licensing agency within each Australian state. This agency 
differs across the states however, the roles and responsibilities of the licensing agencies includes 
decision making about licensing conditions. 
GP 
General Practitioner is a doctor who is also qualified in general practice medicine. They treat a 
wide variety of health conditions and are usually the first point of medical contact for people in the 
community.

Dear Dr Ngu 
Sarah Smith was referred to Community-Based Rehabilitation on the 17th of January 2021 
following an inpatient admission for a L) MCA infarct on the 20th November 2020. Sarah has 
identified a rehabilitation goal of return to driving.  
Sarah has been engaged in the occupational therapy service between 1/2/2021-20/8/2021. 
Assessments were conducted on 1/8/2021: 
• List outcomes of standardised assessment/s
• List outcomes of functional assessments or observations

the client which include:

the client which include: 
• Option 1. No functional impairments identified, therefore requires medical clearance as per
Austroads medical standards. Medical report to be forwarded to licencing authority prior to
return to driving (note: for periodic assessment required for dementia diagnoses).
• Option 2. Functional impairments identified. Recommendation to cease driving temporarily
while awaiting further rehabilitation. Will require repeat assessments to determine if further
comprehensive driving assessment required.
• Option 3. Functional impairments identified however condition has plateaued therefore, no
further rehabilitation indicated.  Recommendation for an OT driving assessment to determine
driving safety. Requires medical clearance via medical report (outlining meets Austroads
medical standards and need for OT driving assessment) to be forwarded to the licencing
authority.

she has identified a goal of being able to return to driving. Sarah is independent with 
her mobility and is able to use both her upper limbs in occupations, however, 
presents with cognitive changes. Sarah continues to demonstrate improvements in 
her rehabilitation, however, requires further rehabilitation and assessment to 
determine her driving potential.

demonstrating reduced attention.

ommendations provided:

DRIVING EDUCATION HANDOUT 
Why is driving a privilege? 
Many people consider driving a 
meaningful activity as it provides freedom, 
independence and enjoyment. However, 
there are certain responsibilities you have 
as a driver to make sure that you are safe 
to drive. Driving a car is a complex skill 
that requires good physical and cognitive 
skills. There are different health conditions 
that can impact on these skills, which may 
affect your ability to drive safely. Just 
because you have a health condition, it 
does not mean that you will not be able to 
drive. It might mean that you have to 
regularly check with your medical or health 
professional that your condition is well 
managed to enable you to continue 
driving. 
What are my responsibilities as a 
driver? 
As a driver, you are required by law to 
report to your driver licencing authority 
any permanent or long-term illness that

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1181.text:
report to your driver licencing authority 
any permanent or long-term illness that 
is likely to affect your ability to drive 
safely. Your doctor will be able to advise 
whether or not you should be reporting 
your condition to the licencing authority or 
not. When reporting your condition to the 
licencing authority, it does not mean that 
your licence will be taken away. It means 
that your medical and health professional 
teams can work with the licencing 
authority together to help manage your 
condition with respect to driving. This is 
also important because if you continue 
driving without obtaining medical approval, 
or fail to notify the licencing authority of 
any permanent or long-term illness and 
you are involved in an accident; you may 
be criminally liable and your insurance 
may not cover you. It is important to also 
notify your insurance company as 
changes to your policy may be required. 
Who decides if I am able to drive? 
Driving screens or assessments can be

meta.creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 22 for Word
meta.author: Hayley Scott
meta.title: Driving Clinical Decision Pathway

chunk_1182.text:
Who decides if I am able to drive? 
Driving screens or assessments can be 
completed by medical or health 
professionals. These assessments are not 
used to decide if you are allowed to drive 
or not but helps to inform whether further 
assessments are needed. These health 
professionals have a responsibility to 
inform the licencing authority if the patient 
may be at risk of driving unsafely. In some 
instances, people require an Occupational 
Therapy driving assessment to make sure 
they are safe to drive. The driver licencing 
authority will inform you if this is needed. 
However, the driver licencing authority 
makes the final decisions about your 
licence status, not your health care 
team. 
Who do I contact for further 
information? 
For more information you can contact your 
driver licensing authority in your state or 
territory via the contact details on the 
Austroads website www.austroads.com.au 
You can also visit your GP or speak with 
your Occupational Therapist.
