chunk_1234.text:
Abstract 
Introduction 
In Australia, all stroke survivors are restricted in driving for four weeks , and persons who 
experience a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) are restricted in driving for two weeks. All health 
professionals working in stroke and TIA have a responsibility to provide written and verbal 
information on return to driving (RTD) to persons with stroke or TIA and provide them with a n 
RTD management plan prior to discharge from hospital.  
 
Aim 
This thesis aims to determine whether Austroads’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines and the National 
Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management are being met in the 
multiprofessional team’s role in pro viding RTD education to stroke survivors and in facilitating 
stroke survivors’ adherence to driving restrictions.  
 
Methodology 
Study one is a systematic review of adherence to RTD guidelines and legislation following stroke.

chunk_1235.text:
Study one is a systematic review of adherence to RTD guidelines and legislation following stroke. 
Study two reports on a medical record audit of inpatient documentation related to the provision 
of RTD education and management plans in the acute hospital setting, and the results of an 
anonymous patient survey of RTD behaviours. Study three presents the findings from a survey 
of Australian health professionals working in the field of stroke regarding the knowledge and 
use of RTD guidelines. Study four reports on the development and implementation of an 
electronic learning module on RTD, targeting Australian health professionals working in the field 
of stroke.  
33

chunk_1236.text:
Results 
The systematic review revealed only three studies , all based in the United Kingdom,  that 
investigated the provision of RTD education in the acute hospital setting . The medical record 
audit revealed that patients with stroke or TIA are not routinely receiving documentation on the 
provision of education on RTD prior to discharge from hospital . The anonymous patient survey 
revealed that, if provided with education on RTD, a person with st roke or TIA will follow the 
advice give n. The results of the national survey of health professionals revealed that health 
professionals lack knowledge about RTD guidelines , and the management of RTD is being 
deferred to other health professionals. The development of an electronic learning module on 
RTD after stroke, targeting Australian health professionals, is bridging the practice-evidence gap 
in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines after stroke and TIA.    
 
Conclusion

chunk_1237.text:
in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines after stroke and TIA.    
 
Conclusion 
The provision of education on res trictions in driving , and RTD management plans , in patients 
with stroke and TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting is not well-
managed. Strategies need to be developed and implemented to ensure all patients with stroke 
and TIA  who are discharged home from the acute hospital setting receive nationally -
recommended education on driving restrictions, and RTD management plans. 
 
 
  
34

chunk_1239.text:
1.1 Background 
A stroke occurs when the blood supply to the brain is interrupted, causing damage to, or death 
of brain tissue. The effects of stroke can include weakness in arms and legs, and difficulty with 
speaking, thinking and vision. Stroke occurs in approximately 60,000 people in Australia each 
year, and stroke is Aus tralia’s second largest killer and cause of disability  (National Stroke 
Foundation, 2010b). A major predictor of a patient’s return to independence post -stroke, and 
hence quality of life, is the ability to drive (Poole, Chaudry, & Jay, 2008). In Australia, all survivors 
are restricted in driving for four weeks after stroke and for two weeks after transient ischaemic 
attack (TIA) (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016).  
 
1.2 Rationale 
Little is known about health professionals’ and stroke survivors ’ knowledge of the  nationally-
agreed guidelines concerning the management of return to driving (RTD) after stroke and TIA.

chunk_1240.text:
agreed guidelines concerning the management of return to driving (RTD) after stroke and TIA. 
Little is known about how survivors of stroke and TIA manage the decision -making processes 
that guide their RTD after acute hospital admissions and whether or not they return to driving 
too early. Little is known about whether educating health professionals about RTD after stroke 
and TIA would influence clinical practice. Additionally, little is known about the post-stroke RTD 
education and advice given to patients in the acute setting , and the documentation of RTD 
management plans in their inpatient medical records.  
 
The reason for undertaking this series of studies came about because I was employed at a large 
regional and tertiary hospital (hereafter defined as the participating hospital ) as the specialist 
occupational therapist working in the Neurology Department’s Stroke Unit . Whil e in this

chunk_1241.text:
occupational therapist working in the Neurology Department’s Stroke Unit . Whil e in this 
position, I noticed that stroke survivors were not formally assessed, advised or educated about 
36

chunk_1242.text:
their RTD after stroke or TIA.  There was no consistency in the post -stroke, pre -discharge 
documentation and management related to the resumption of driving  post-discharge. Also, as 
the acute therapist, I was unsure about what advice and education should be or were provided 
to survivors of stroke and TIA, and therefore I was also unsure how survivors managed their RTD 
after discharge. I was particularly concerned about patients who were discharged directly home 
from the acute setting. It was this uncertainty and concern that led me to decide to investigate 
the current clinical management of RTD after stroke and TIA and to focus on the health  care 
provided to patients discharged directly home.    
 
In the studies’ participating hospital, patients experiencing stroke or TIA are admitted either to 
the Neurology ward or the Acute Stroke Unit , which is a speciality sub -unit of the Neurology

chunk_1243.text:
the Neurology ward or the Acute Stroke Unit , which is a speciality sub -unit of the Neurology 
ward (Hubbard, Evans, McMullen -Roach, Marquez, & Parsons, 2014 ). Many, but not all, are 
referred to the acute -stroke occupational therapist. If appropriate,  the therapist provide s 
education and information about restrictions in driving after stroke or TIA. This education aims 
to align  with the Stroke Foundation ’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management  (National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010b) and The Australasian Road Transport and Traffic Agencies ’ and the 
National Transport Commission of Australia ’s (Austroads’) Assessing Fitness to Drive for 
Commercial and Private Vehicle Drivers  document (Austroads and National Road Transport 
Commission, 2003). However, at the time , provision of education did not appear to follow a 
standardised protocol . This  meant that survivors of recent stroke or TIA may have been

chunk_1244.text:
standardised protocol . This  meant that survivors of recent stroke or TIA may have been 
returning to driving too early and may have been unaware that they were doing so . Although 
they were usually instructed to seek further clarification from the ir medical specialists and/or 
local doctors post-discharge, it was unclear whether or not they followed this advice. For these 
reasons, this thesis will  investigate the management of RTD after stroke or TIA, and the RTD 
37

chunk_1245.text:
behaviours of survivors of recent stroke or TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute 
setting.  
 
To date, most studies in the field of driving post-stroke have focused on how stroke impacts the 
driving task (Fisk, Owsley, & Mennemeier, 2002; Lee, Tracy, Bohannon, & Ahlquist, 2003; McKay, 
Rapport, Bryer, & Casey, 2011), the assessment of stroke survivors’ ability to drive (Devos et al., 
2011; S. C. Marshall et al., 2007; Ponsford, Viitanen, Lundberg, & Johansson, 2008; Soderstrom, 
Pettersson, & Leppert, 2006 ) and the retraining of stroke survivors ’ RTD (Akinwuntan, Devos, 
Verheyden, et al., 2010; Devos et al., 2010; Mazer et al., 2003). To my knowledge, there are no 
studies researching adherence to current guidelines and legislation related to RTD post-stroke.  
 
1.3 Research aims and questions 
1.3.1 Research aim 
This research project aims to determine whether Austroads’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines and the

chunk_1246.text:
This research project aims to determine whether Austroads’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines and the 
National Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management are being met in the 
multi‐professional team’s role in providing education and in the stroke survivor’s adherence to 
driving restrictions.  
 
  
38

chunk_1247.text:
1.3.2 Research objectives   
Associated with the research aim are specific research questions:  
Research question 1. Is RTD education routinely provided to persons with stroke or TIA during 
their acute inpatient stays?   
Research question 2. What factors influence the provision of RTD education to patients with 
stroke or TIA in the acute inpatient setting? 
Research questions 3. Do patients with stroke or TIA recall education provided on RTD during 
their acute inpatient stays? 
Research question 4. When do patients with stroke or TIA who are discharged directly home from 
the acute inpatient setting return to driving?   
Research question 5. What are the knowledge and use of Australian RTD guidelines in health 
professionals working with stroke survivors and persons with TIA? 
Research questions 6. Can an education strategy for health professionals working with stroke 
survivors bridge the practice-evidence gap in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines? 
 
1.4   Synopsis

chunk_1248.text:
1.4   Synopsis 
The study entitled Shifting Gears  consists of four investigations: a systematic review ; a 
retrospective medical record audit and a post-discharge patient survey; a national survey  of 
health professionals ; and the development and implementation of an electronic learning 
module. Each part of the study has an accompanying published journal article. 
 
39

chunk_1249.text:
Chapter two will present an in-depth critique of current literature in relation to RTD after stroke 
and TIA . Chapter three reports on th e results of a systematic review of adherence to RTD 
guidelines and legislation following stroke. The results of this investigation were published in 
the British Journal of Occupational Therapy in 2016  (Frith, Hubbard, James, & Warren-Forward, 
2015) and inform the research methodology and agendas of the next three studies, reported in 
Chapters four to six. Chapter four reports on the findings of a medical record audit of inpatient 
documentation related to the provision of RTD education and management plans for patients 
with stroke or TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting. It also 
reports on the results of an anonymous patient survey on the recall of RTD education and RTD 
behaviours. The investigation reported in this chapter will be published in the Australian Journal

chunk_1250.text:
behaviours. The investigation reported in this chapter will be published in the Australian Journal 
of Occupational Therapy in 2017 (Frith, Warren-Forward, Hubbard, & James, 2017). Chapter five 
reports on the findings from a national survey of the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines by 
Australian health profession als working in the field of stroke. The health professional survey 
resulted in a quantitative paper and a qualitative paper, which have both been submitted to an 
academic journal for publication and are currently under peer review. This survey provided an 
educational component for the health professional by providing links to Austroads ’ and the 
National Stroke Foundation ’s guidelines. Chapter six reports on the development and 
implementation of an electronic learning module  (e-module), which sought to bridg e the 
practice-evidence gap identified as part of the above investigations , using a readily accessible

chunk_1251.text:
practice-evidence gap identified as part of the above investigations , using a readily accessible 
translational online learning module specifically designed for health professionals working in the 
field of stroke. A paper reporting the development and  implementation of the e-module has 
been accepted for publication in Occupational Therapy and Healthcare (Frith, Hubbard, James, 
& Warren-Forward, in press). Finally, Chapter seven will draw together the key findings from the 
four studies presented in this thesis , explore the clinical implications for the management of 
RTD, and provide recommendations for future research. 
40

chunk_1252.text:
1.5   Anticipated research significance 
How RTD after stroke and TIA is managed in the acute hospital setting is, as yet, unknown. This 
thesis aims to generate new knowledge about the  clinical practice s surrounding the 
management of RTD in patients with recent stroke or TIA who are discharged directly home from 
the acute setting . The thesis aims to describe current clinical practice  and the behaviours of 
those with stroke or TIA who are current drivers of motor vehicles. This new knowledge should 
increase our understanding of whether people with stroke or TIA recall their RTD education and 
how it impacts on their RTD behaviour. The outcome of this thesis will inform clinical practice 
and help develop clinical practice guidelines in the management of RTD after stroke and TIA. 
 
  
41

15(1), 37-41.

chunk_1260.text:
2.1 Stroke and transient ischaemic attack  
Stroke is classified as either ischaemic, resulting from a blockage in a cerebral artery leading to 
or within the brain; or h aemorrhagic, resulting from a rupture in a cerebral artery (Grysiewicz, 
Thomas, & Pandey, 2008). Stroke is one of Australia’s largest causes of death and disability. Each 
year, 60,000 Australians experience strokes, and one in six people will experience strokes in their 
lifetimes. Over 50% of new or recurrent strokes affect those aged over 75 years of age. Stroke is 
estimated to cost the Australian community $5 billion a year (Australian Institute of Health and 
Welfare, 2013). 
 
One-third of people with stroke experience impairments that impact their ability to carry out 
everyday activities (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2013 ). Impairments resulting 
from stroke can be classified as motor (Lawrence, Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001), sensory (Carey

chunk_1261.text:
from stroke can be classified as motor (Lawrence, Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001), sensory (Carey 
& Matyas, 2011), vision (Fisk et al., 2002), language (Brady, Kelly, Godwin, Enderby, & Campbell, 
2016), cognition (Tatemichi et al., 1994) and behaviour (G. Kelly, Brown, Todd, & Kremer, 2008). 
Table 2.1 outlines some of the impairments a stroke survivor may experience. Impairments can 
occur in isolation or in combination and can affect a person’s ability to walk, talk, eat, drink and 
perform activities of daily living. The most common impairment resulting from stroke is upper 
limb and lower limb motor weakness, which is experienced by over 70% of stroke survivors 
(Lawrence, Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001 ). Other impairments can impact a person’s ability to 
effectively communicate with others, for example, dysphagia , and ability to accurate perceive 
and interpret the surrounding environment, for example, homonymous hemianopia. As many

chunk_1262.text:
and interpret the surrounding environment, for example, homonymous hemianopia. As many 
as 44% of stroke survivors may also experience some form of cognitive impairment (Lawrence, 
Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001 ). The severity of the stroke can determine the degree to which a 
person experiences impairment(s) and in turn the level of disability experienced. 
46

Stroke causes permanent damage to the brain. This is often preceded by a transient ischaemic 
attack (TIA) (Rothwell et al., 2005). A TIA has been traditionally defined as a sudden neurological

chunk_1264.text:
event lasting less than 24 hours (Ad Hoc Committee on Cerebrovascular Diseases, 1990) and not 
resulting in any permanent brain  damage (Lewandowski, Chathan, & Silver, 2008 ). However, 
with advances in neuroimaging, this definition and description is under challenge. A person with 
a TIA will experience similar impairments to those of stroke , such as hemiparesis (arm and/or 
leg weakness), sensory disturbances, facial weakness, dysphasia and/or visual disturbances. 
Symptoms can last anywhere from several minutes to several hours (Lewandowski et al., 2008) 
and may be viewed as benign, particularly if they last for less than an hour (Easton et al., 2009).  
 
47

chunk_1265.text:
The risk of stroke following TIA is high, with research indicating that a person with a TIA has a 1 
in 10 chance of having a full stroke in the next three months. Fifty percent of those who then 
have a stroke will do so within t he next two days (Johnston, Gress, Browner, & Sidney, 2000 ). 
Advances in the use of magnetic resonance imaging have challenged the traditional “transient” 
notion of TIAs, with results revealing that despite the resolution of symptoms following a TIA, 
irreversible brain damage has, in fact, occurred (Johnston, 2002). Evidence shows that people 
with TIA who experience symptoms for longer than one hour are less likely to experience a full 
recovery (Levy, 1988) and are more likely to have infarcts that are detectable via neuroimaging 
and are similar to those observed after stroke (Easton et al., 2009 ; Kidwell, Alger, & Di Salle, 
1999; Oppenheima et al., 2006 ). This re search demonstrates that a TIA is, in fact, a minor

chunk_1266.text:
1999; Oppenheima et al., 2006 ). This re search demonstrates that a TIA is, in fact, a minor 
ischaemic stroke and, because of its significance regarding the risk of recurrent stroke, is a 
significant medical event that should not be left untreated (Dutta, Bowen, & Foy, 2015). 
 
In Australia, when a person is experiencing stroke -like symptoms, they should be immediately 
transported to hospital via the Ambulance Service to ensure they receive the best -available 
hyper-acute management. Once the stroke event has fully resolved, the next phase of functional 
recovery starts. Those diagnosed with mild stroke or TIA may be discharged directly home from 
a hospital’s emergency department or from the acute setting. In many cases, following discharge 
their ongoing care will be managed by their local doctor s or, in the first 6 -8 weeks, by 
neurologists. In the sub-acute phase of care, those diagnosed with more severe stroke may be

chunk_1267.text:
neurologists. In the sub-acute phase of care, those diagnosed with more severe stroke may be 
referred to inpatient rehabilitation, and this may be followed up eventually with community -
based or home-based rehabilitation (Agency for Clinical Innovation, 2016).  
 
48

chunk_1268.text:
There are many health professionals involved in the care of a person who experiences a stroke. 
Organised stroke care coordinated by a multidisciplinary team provides the stroke survivor with 
the best outcomes with regard to returning home to live independently (Stroke Unit Trialists, 
2013). The multidisciplinary team consists of medical, nursing and allied health staff.  Examples 
of the allied health professions that may be involved in stroke rehabilitation include 
physiotherapy, occupational therapy,  speech pathology, dietetics and social work. 
Physiotherapy is the most commonly received allied health service provided to stroke survivors 
in hospital, followed by occupational therapy and speech pathology. However, not all stroke 
survivors will see  a heath care professional from each profession (Hubbard et al., 2014). As there 
are many different pathways of health care for survivors of stroke and TIA, how are issues such

chunk_1269.text:
are many different pathways of health care for survivors of stroke and TIA, how are issues such 
as return to driving (RTD) after stroke managed and organised, and which professions are, or 
should be, involved? 
 
2.2 Stroke and driving a motor vehicle 
In Australia, a person is able to obtain a provisional driving licence from the age of 17 (Roads 
and Maritime Services, 2016), and for many, driving is seen as a necessity (Mazer et al., 2003) 
rather than a privilege. It is noted that a  person makes approximately 20 decisions each 
kilometre he or she drives (American Automobile Association, 2016 ). Driving is considered an 
instrumental activity of daily living (Dickerson, Reistetter, Schold Davis, & Monahan, 2011) and 
a major contributor to a person’s quality of life and satisfaction (Devos et al., 2011; Mazer et al., 
2003; White et al., 2012 ). Driving promotes independence and increases choices related to

chunk_1270.text:
2003; White et al., 2012 ). Driving promotes independence and increases choices related to 
occupations and social engagement (White et al., 2012 ). For example, being able to drive a 
motor vehicle can be essential to someone’s ability to engage in employment -related 
occupations and fulfil life roles (Mazer et al., 2003; Stav & Pierce, 2010). An inability to drive can 
49

chunk_1271.text:
threaten what a person perceives as a normal and predictable life (White et al., 2012).  Driving 
is a complex task that relies on a person’s ability to “perceive, analyse and execute decisions on 
a continual basis, often without conscious effort” (Mazer, Gelinas, & Benoit, 2004, p. 292). 
 
The complex nature of driving a motor vehicle can be explained using the Person-Environment-
Occupation Performance (PEOP) model (Christiansen, Baum, & Bass-Hagen, 2005). According to 
this model, a person’s occupational performance is “the outcome of the transaction of the 
person, environment and occupation. It is defined as the dynamic experience of a person 
engaged in purposeful activities and tasks within an environment” (Law et al., 1996, p. 16 ). 
Figure 2.1 demonstrates how the successful driving of a motor vehicle is reliant on the 
“transactions” between the: 
• Intrinsic “person”: the combination of visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and cognitive

chunk_1272.text:
• Intrinsic “person”: the combination of visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and cognitive 
skills; the driver’s ability, including previously learnt skills and past driving experiences 
(Akinwuntan, Wachtel, & Rosen, 2012); and psychosocial factors such as confidence and 
mood 
• Extrinsic “environment”: the vehicle , road conditions, traffic conditions, number of 
passengers, weather conditions, and driving ability (Akinwuntan et al., 2012; Mazer et 
al., 2003) 
• Occupations: the activities and tasks that contribute to occupational performance 
(Christiansen et al., 2005; Law et al., 1996). 
50

chunk_1273.text:
These transactions take p lace in a rapidly repeating cycle , and when stroke occurs, the 
transactions potentially break down. 
Figure 2.1 PEOP model in the context of the driving task. Adapted from 
www.LifelongLearningWithOT.wordpress.com 
 
It has been reported that only one -third of stroke survivors return to driving after stroke (Fisk, 
Owsley, & Pulley, 1997). Allen, Halbert, and Huang (2007) in South Australia reported that only 
19% of stroke survivors from their rehabilitation unit had returned to driving at  a six-month 
follow up; they did not however, report on the proportion that received information or referral 
for a driving assessment. Two other international studies reported that between 30% and 58% 
of people return to driving post stroke (Lee et al., 2003; Tan, O'Driscoll, & O'Neill, 2011). 
Due to the nature of impairments experienced following stroke, stroke survivors can be at high

chunk_1274.text:
Due to the nature of impairments experienced following stroke, stroke survivors can be at high 
risk of motor vehicle accidents when they return to driving (Fisk et al., 1997). In a cross-sectional 
51

chunk_1275.text:
design study comparing the relationships among vision, attention and driving behaviours of 50 
stroke survivors and 105 older adults without stroke, it was identified that people with less 
severe functional impairments are more likely to return to driving than those with more severe 
functional impairments (Fisk et al., 2002 ). Limitations of this study were its size and its use of 
consecutive sampling to recruit participants from a stroke support group based at a 
rehabilitation centre in the United States of America.  Attendees at the stroke support group  
included both post-stroke drivers and post -stroke non-drivers and may not fully represent the 
wider post-stroke population. It is not clear whether the stroke survivors received inpatient 
rehabilitation following their stroke or whether they were discharged home from the acute 
hospital setting. It is also not known what educ ation or assessment  processes the recruited

chunk_1276.text:
hospital setting. It is also not known what educ ation or assessment  processes the recruited 
stroke survivors had gone through prior to  returning to driving  or why the stroke non -drivers 
had not returned to driving . Participants were at least six months post -stroke and still 
experiencing neurological deficits, indicating that their strokes may not have been in the mild 
range. Fisk et al. (2002) concluded that those with more extensive functional impairments would 
be less likely to return to driving. However, their study highlighted that no single impairment in 
isolation impacts driving. This is an important finding as it demonstrates the complexity of the 
driving task. 
52

chunk_1277.text:
Driving a motor vehicle is a learnt skill (Klavora et al., 1995), but the impairments experienced 
after a stroke can impact a person’s ability to drive. These impairments can vary greatly (Klavora 
et al., 1995 ), but can be broadly grouped together into visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and 
cognitive skills. These skills work together in a complex combination in order for the person to 
safely operate a motor vehicle (Akinwuntan et al., 2002; Akinwuntan et al., 2012; Delfosse, 2014; 
Klavora et al., 1995 ; Korner-Bitensky, Bitensky, Sofer, Man -Son-Hing, & Gelinas, 2006 ). 
Impairment in one or more of these skill sets can impact the performance within the other skill 
sets and, therefore, the driving task. Figure 2.2 presents a diagrammatic representation of the 
interplay among the various skill domains and the driving task.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Figure 2.2 The interplay of skills required for the driving task 
Intrinsic person: Visuoperceptual skills

chunk_1278.text:
Intrinsic person: Visuoperceptual skills 
In relation to the “intrinsic person”, visuoperceptual skills are foundational to being able to 
perceive the external driving environment, interpret what is being seen and then safely and 
efficiently react to it in a timely and appropriate manner (Mazer, Korner-Bitensky, & Sofer, 1998; 
Nouri & Lincoln, 1992). Impairments in visual attention and visual processing speed can result in 
difficulty observing the surrounding environment, followed by delayed planning in how to safely 
Visuoperceptual 
skills
Sensorimotor 
skills
Cognitive 
skills
53

chunk_1279.text:
manoeuvre the motor vehicle in response to environmental demands (Klavora et al., 1995 ; 
Lundqvist, Gerdle, & Ronnberg, 2000 ). According to a United Kingdom -based acute -stroke 
prevalence study conducted by Lawrence,  Coshall, Dundad, et al. (2001), over a three -year 
period, approximately 46% of stroke survivors in the acute setting had a visual impairment. 
While visual impairments do not necessarily stop a person from being able to drive, vision is an 
essential element requiring assessment prior to a stroke survivor returning to driving (Austroads 
and National Transport Commission, 2016).  
 
In the previously mentioned study by Fisk et al . (2002) investigating the correlation between 
vision and self-reported driving behaviours, of 50 people with stroke and 105 older adults, it was 
found that “stroke survivors were impaired on all visual measures, with the exception of visual

chunk_1280.text:
found that “stroke survivors were impaired on all visual measures, with the exception of visual 
acuity” (p.473). For example, 40% of all stroke subjects had an impaired range in the useful field 
of view which could significantly impact the ability to drive a mo tor vehicle. What was 
interesting, however, was that stroke survivors with higher levels of visual impairment were less 
likely to resume driving and, if driving,  deliberately modified their driving behaviour to 
compensate for this  impairment. Although this  study was limited to a stroke cohort in a 
rehabilitation context in the United States of America, it provides evidence that vision is a key 
element impacting driving after stroke.   
Intrinsic person: Sensorimotor skills 
Lawrence et al . (2001) identified t hat the highest prevalence of impairments resulting from 
stroke related to sensorimotor dysfunction (Figure 2.3).  This is an important prevalence study

chunk_1281.text:
stroke related to sensorimotor dysfunction (Figure 2.3).  This is an important prevalence study 
of acute-stroke survivors, providing evidence about the impairments acute-stroke survivors may 
experience. This cohort study used Stroke Registry data collected from 1259 survivors living in 
South London, with collection of data obtained in the acute hospital setting, beginning with the 
54

chunk_1282.text:
first-ever stroke. Considering the similarities between the United Kingdom and Australian public 
health services, the prevalence of impairments at stroke onset would have some relevance to 
the Australian population. However, the study was published in 2001 , and therefore the data 
may be outdated. There is currently no Aus tralian stroke impairment prevalence literature 
available for acute-stroke survivors who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital 
setting. 
 
 
Figure 2.3 Prevalence of impairments three months post -stroke (Lawrence, Coshall, Dundas, et al., 
2001).  
In their critical review of the evidence related to driving retraining, Mazer et al . (2004) discuss 
the interplay among the different impairments experienced foll owing illness or injury and the 
impacts on the various activities related to the driving task. This was the first paper to describe 
how sensorimotor impairments can impact driving -related activities , using  the PEOP model .

chunk_1283.text:
how sensorimotor impairments can impact driving -related activities , using  the PEOP model . 
However, the results are not specific to stroke. For example, impairments in strength and range 
of motion in the upper limb can impact the ability to put on a seat belt, turn the steering wheel

chunk_1284.text:
and change gears; and in the lower limb, the ability to shift the foot, for example, from the brake 
to the accelerator. These impairments and a person’s motor endurance can impact response 
and reaction time (Crotty & George, 2009 ; Klavora et al., 1995 ), as can impairments in 
proprioception and coordination (Mazer et al., 2004 ). Despite the high p revalence of 
sensorimotor impairments following stroke and their perceived impact on driving activities, 
there is a gap in the literature reporting on the impact that sensorimotor impairments have on 
RTD behaviours following stroke. This may suggest that s ensorimotor impairments are more 
responsive to recovery interventions targeting RTD than other “intangible” impairments such as 
visuoperceptual and cognitive impairments.   
 
Intrinsic person: Cognitive skills 
In the acute phase post -stroke, about 44% of patients experience cognitive impairments , and

chunk_1285.text:
In the acute phase post -stroke, about 44% of patients experience cognitive impairments , and 
the presence of cognitive impairments is a leading cause of disability at three months post -
stroke (Lawrence, Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001 ). Cognitive impairments experienced following 
stroke that impact on driving include insight, judgement, attention, concentration and memory 
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016; Fisk et al., 2002; Tatemichi et al., 1994). 
With over one-third of survivors experiencing disability as a result of stroke (Australian Institute 
of Health and Welfare, 2013 ), there is an increasing number of stroke survivors with cognitive 
impairments wishing to return to driving (Korner-Bitensky et al., 2006). In a Cochrane review of 
literature pertaining to rehabilitation of drivers, Crotty, Gelinas, and Devos (2014)  concluded 
that outcomes of cognitive skills retraining and its benefit in RTD outcomes in stroke survivors

chunk_1286.text:
that outcomes of cognitive skills retraining and its benefit in RTD outcomes in stroke survivors 
have remained inconclusive. This review included only four studies, with participants recruited 
across the acute and rehabilitation contexts who were no more than 1.7 years post-stroke. The 
interventions used in the experimental group involved the use of technology, with two studies 
using driving simulators that are not a vailable to health professionals working in the public 
56

chunk_1287.text:
health system in Australia. The use of technology in occupational therapy is an evolving practice, 
and its use in driver retraining is largely experimental, as evidenced by the small number of 
studies available. However, despite the fact that this  method is experimental, it highlights the 
impact cognitive impairment has on driving ability and can be a key reason why people stop 
driving after stroke (Fisk et al., 2002; Lundqvist et al., 2000).  
 
Lundqvist et al. (2000) investigated the neuropsychological aspects of driving in a cohort of 23 
patients with stroke in Sweden, who were at least three months post-stroke, compared with 28 
healthy controls. Their results suggest  stroke “patients performed significantly worse in 
attentional and cognitive processing” (p. 144) , and they reported “a significant difference 
between the [stroke] patient and control groups in most of th e neuropsychological test

chunk_1288.text:
between the [stroke] patient and control groups in most of th e neuropsychological test 
performances” (p. 145). A strength of this study is the finding that neuropsychological testing is 
useful when assessing driving skill after stroke. A limitation however, is that the validity and 
reliability of the use of simulation in predicting on -road driving ability is  still uncertain. An 
additional limitation is the small convenience sample of stroke survivors treated at one hospital 
in Sweden and therefore its generalisability to other stroke survivor populations . In this study, 
91% (n=21) of stroke survivors had returned to driving at the time the study was conducted and 
these stroke survivors reported a restriction period averaging 1.7 months. The stroke survivors 
in this study were making decisions about returning to driving within two months of their stroke 
and reported variances in the advice provided by health professionals. This h ighlights the

chunk_1289.text:
and reported variances in the advice provided by health professionals. This h ighlights the 
importance of education of stroke survivors regarding their stroke impairments and the impacts 
on the driving task. Cognition has been identified as a focus for assessment of a person’s ability 
to return to driving (Korner-Bitensky et al., 2006). In the previously mentioned study by Fisk et 
al. ( 2002), attention was often an impairment experienced in stroke survivors , regardless of 
stroke severity, and was a contributing factor to stroke survivors ’ modifying their RTD 
57

chunk_1290.text:
behaviours. Cognitive impairments, such as attentional processing, may be present even in 
those with mild stroke and initially may be less evident to both the stroke survivor and the health 
professional (Fisk et al., 2002). Therefore, education and assessment in the acute hospital setting 
are essential for ensuring stroke survivors make informed decisions about RTD.   
 
2.3  Return-to-driving guidelines and legislation 
In Australia, there are six States and two Territories, and each has its own government-led Driver 
Licensing Authority (DLA). A DLA is responsible for the issuing, renewing, suspending, refusing 
or cancelling of a person’s driver’s licence, taking into consideration the heal th and driving 
record of the licence holder (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ). There are 
two types of licences in Australia. The first is a Private Licence, which is required to drive a

chunk_1291.text:
two types of licences in Australia. The first is a Private Licence, which is required to drive a 
motorcycle, car or light rigid vehicle for personal use. A light rigid vehicle is one that is greater 
than four and a half tonnes but less than eight tonnes or can carry more than 12 people. The 
second is a Commercial Licence, which is required when driving a vehicle as a source of income 
or when the vehicle is a medium rigid (a two-axle small truck or bus over eight tonnes), heavy 
rigid (a three -axle big truck or  bus), heavy combination (semi -trailer) or multiple combination 
vehicle (heavy combination with additi onal trailer/s) (Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2016).  
 
Every licence holder in Australia is bound by the medical standards dictated by either their 
Private or Commercial Licence type. These medical standards are outlined in the document , 
“Assessing Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private Vehicle Drivers ”, which is a combined

chunk_1292.text:
“Assessing Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private Vehicle Drivers ”, which is a combined 
Australian and New Zealand document developed by the Australasian Road Transport and 
Traffic Agencies and the National Transport Commission of Australia (Austroads and Nati onal 
58

chunk_1293.text:
Transport Commission, 2016 ). This document was first published in 1998 to provide health 
professionals with medical standards for licensing and clinical management guidelines for 
licence holders with various medical conditions. These guidelines wer e updated in 2016 and 
included the medical standards for stroke and TIA.  
 
The presence of a medical condition does not necessarily exclude a person from driving. When 
assessing a person’s fitness to drive, the complexity of the driving task, the potential  impact of 
the medical condition on driving ability , and how well the person’s condition is managed or 
monitored are all factors that are taken into account. Some licence holders may be given a 
Conditional Licence as a result of a driving assessment due to a medical condition. A Conditional 
Licence will stipulate medical treatments, vehicle modifications or driving restrictions that allow

chunk_1294.text:
the licence holder to drive safely and reduce risk to other road users. A Conditional Licence may 
contain conditions as simple as needing to wear glasses while driving or only driving during 
daylight hours, to more complicated stipulations such as only driving a vehicle that has been 
fully modified (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016).  
 
Around the world, if a licence holder has a medical condition that may impact on the ability to 
drive, he or she has a legal responsibility to inform the relevant DLA (American Automobile 
Association, 2016 ; Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ; Canadian Medic al 
Association, 2012 ; Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency, 2016 ). Failure to disclose a medical 
condition, at the time of either issue or renewal of the licence, or during the course of the 
licensing period, may result in the driver’s licence being cancelled. In the event of an accident,

chunk_1295.text:
licensing period, may result in the driver’s licence being cancelled. In the event of an accident, 
the driver’s insurance may not cover him or her if a medical condition was not disclosed 
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016). Internationally, it is well-recognised that 
59

chunk_1296.text:
if a health professional has a concern about a person’s “fitness to drive”, he or she has an ethical 
responsibility to report those concerns to the Driver Licensing Agency (American Automobile 
Association, 2016 ; Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ; Canadian Medical 
Association, 2012; Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency, 2016). However, there is inconsistency 
internationally regarding a health professional’s legal responsibility when it comes to fitness to 
drive. In the United Kingdom, there is no mandatory reporting requirement for health 
professionals who assess a patient as being unfit to drive (Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency, 
2016). However, in the United States of America, Canada and Australia, depending on the State 
or Territory in which the person resides, health professionals are bound by mandatory reporting 
requirements (American Automobile Association, 2016 ; Austroads and National Transport

chunk_1297.text:
requirements (American Automobile Association, 2016 ; Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2016; Canadian Medical Association, 2012). There is often hesitation among health 
professionals to report fitness -to-drive concerns due to fear of litigation (Jang et al., 2007 ; S. 
Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ). H owever, in Australia, a health professional ca nnot be sued by a 
person for “breaching confidentiality” with regard to reporting them as unfit to drive. On the 
contrary, if after discussing fitness to drive with a patient and client, the health professional feels 
that the advice will not be heeded, then the health professional can report their patient or client 
to the DLA without the person’s consent (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016).  
 
2.3.1 Return-to-drive guidelines after stroke or transient ischaemic episode 
This thesis focuses on the Australian medical standards for licensing of people who have

experienced a stroke or TIA. Table 2.2 compares the Australian RTD standards against three key 
countries, United States of America, United Kingdom and Canada.

In the United Kingdom and Canada, there are recommended four-week restrictions in driving 
after stroke (Canadian Medical Association, 2012 ; Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency, 2016 ). 
However, in the United States of America, there are no recommended restriction timeframes. 
The American Stroke Association recommends that stroke survivors abstain from driving until 
impairments have resolved, and that clearance from a medical professional be provided prior to

chunk_1300.text:
impairments have resolved, and that clearance from a medical professional be provided prior to 
returning to driving (American Heart Association and American Stroke Association, 2016), with 
their website stating:  
“Driving against your doctor’s advice can be dangerous and may be illegal. In some 
cases, your doctor may have the legal responsibility to notify your state that you’ve been 
advised not to drive.” 
61

chunk_1301.text:
Figure 2.4 demonstrates the type of information on driving after stroke available to stroke 
survivors residing in the United States of America. 
Figure 2.4 Information about driving after stroke on the American Stroke Association's website.

2017. Retrieved from: 
http://www.strokeassociation.org/STROKEORG/LifeAfterStroke/RegainingIndependence/Driving/D
riving-After-Stroke_UCM_311016_Article.jsp#.WI1FKYVOJMs. Copyright (2017) by American Heart 
Association and American Stroke Association. 
62

chunk_1302.text:
In the United States of America and Canada, a person who experiences one or more TIAs should 
cease driving until symptoms have resolved and medical clearance has been provided by a 
medical professional (American Medical Association, 1999 ; Canadian Medical Association, 
2012). In the United Kingdom, a person who experiences a single TIA should not drive for four 
weeks, while for someone who experiences multiple TIAs, a period of three months’ restriction 
in driving is recommended (Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency, 2016).  
In Australia, the medical standards for licensing after stroke and TIA are more clearly defined. 
They are outlined in Section 6, titled Neurological Conditions of the Austroads guidelines. Under 
stroke, it states:  
“Stroke may impair driving ability either because of the long-term neurological deficit it 
produces or because of risk of a recurrent stroke or transient ischaemic at tack (TIA) at

chunk_1303.text:
produces or because of risk of a recurrent stroke or transient ischaemic at tack (TIA) at 
the wheel of the vehicle” (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a, p. 98).  
Table 2.3 outlines the standards in Australia for both private and commercial licensing types for 
stroke and TIA. To return to driving , those diagnosed with stroke or TIA are advised to seek 
“clearance” before returning to driving. The Austroads guidelines state that an assessm ent by 
an “appropriate specialist” is required to determine whether ongoing neurological impairments 
that may impact on the driving task are present. Depending on the outcome of this assessment, 
and the level of impairment present, the person with stroke may be referred for a driving 
assessment (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ). Austroads’ guidelines also 
indicate that the actual event of stroke or TIA rarely causes a motor vehicle accident, as neither 
63

chunk_1304.text:
condition produces a loss of consciousness. However, the impairments resulting from stroke can 
impact a person’s ability to drive a motor vehicle. 
 
Table 2.3 Medical standards for licensing – Stroke and transient ischaemic attack             
Medical Standards for Private Licensing Medical Standards for Commercial 
Licensing 
Stroke 
A person should not drive for at least four weeks 
following a stroke.  
A return to driving is considered following an 
assessment by a specialist or driver assessor.  
A person should not drive for at least three 
months following a stroke.   
A return to driving is considered following 
an assessment by a specialist or driver 
assessor. 
Transient ischaemic attack 
A person should not drive for at least two weeks 
following a TIA.  
A person should not drive for at least four 
weeks following a TIA.  
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016) 
 
The four-week and two-week restrictions in driving after stroke and TIA respectively were only

chunk_1305.text:
The four-week and two-week restrictions in driving after stroke and TIA respectively were only 
introduced into the Austroads guidelines in 2012 after a revision of the previous guidelines. Prior 
to 2012, the medical standards for licensing were less specific regarding timeframes for 
restrictions in driving following stroke and TIA and, consequently, more confusing for health 
professionals and stroke survivors to interpret. This reason alone was motivation for embarking 
on this doctoral research study.  
 
64

chunk_1306.text:
For example, prior to 2012, a person diagnosed with stroke had no mandated period of 
restriction in driving; they could return to driving if clearance had been given b y a doctor. The 
doctor’s clearance, however, would be dependent on the extent of residual neurological 
impairment and the likelihood of these impairments impacting the driving task. For a person 
diagnosed with only one TIA, there were no licensing recommen dations. However, for two or 
more TIAs, the person was not allowed to drive until he or she had had a TIA -free period of six 
months (Austroads and National Road Transport Commission, 2003 ). Before 2012, the 
guidelines mainly foc used on residual neurological impairments that warranted driver 
assessment. While the 2012 (and subsequent 2016) guidelines provided greater clarity for health 
professionals regarding how long the person diagnosed with stroke or TIA should be restricted

chunk_1307.text:
professionals regarding how long the person diagnosed with stroke or TIA should be restricted 
in driving, what are still lacking are descriptors of the management pathways by which stroke 
survivors resume driving at the end of the restriction period and how health professionals should 
follow and document that transition process. 
The move towards an Australian recommended restriction period commenced in 2010 when the 
National Stroke Foundation released their updated Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management 
(National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ). In these guidelines, for the very first time, it was 
recommended that all stroke survivors be restricted in driving for four weeks post-event and 
that all TIA survivors be restricted in driving for two weeks  post-event. Table 2.4 summarises 
Chapter 8 of the clinical guidelines, titled “Community Participation and Long Term Recovery”, 
which features a small section on RTD (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a). In 2010, and again

chunk_1308.text:
which features a small section on RTD (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a). In 2010, and again 
for the very first time, the clinical guidelines also recommended that patients be provided with 
verbal and written information about driving restrictions and their responsibilities in informing 
the DLA about their stroke and that this be included in the discharge planning. However, there 
are some limitations with these guidelines. Firstly, driving is only mentioned in Chapter 8, 
65

chunk_1309.text:
suggesting that m anagement of RTD is a long -term issue after stroke. There was also no 
consideration given to the fact that RTD is relevant to stroke survivors in the very early phase of 
recovery, particularly for those who have mild strokes or make a full recovery and who  are 
discharged directly home from the acute setting. 
 
Table 2.4 National Stroke Foundation Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management   ̶  Chapter 8.2 Driving 
Chapter 8: Community Participation and Long Term Recovery  
      Chapter 8.2: Driving 
• All patients should be asked about their driving history and intentions to drive again  
• Any patient who wishes to return to driving should be provided with information on 
restrictions in driving following stroke  
• Patients are to be informed that he or she has a responsibility to report their medical condition 
to the relevant State or Territory Driver Licen sing Authority and notify their car insurance 
company before returning to driving

chunk_1310.text:
company before returning to driving  
• A stroke survivor should not return to driving for at least four weeks 
• Stroke survivors require an assessment by their local doctor or specialist prior to returning to 
driving 
• People with TIA should be instructed not to drive for two weeks 
• If a person is deemed medically fit but is required to undertake further testing, they should be 
referred to an occupational therapy driving assessment 
(National Stroke Foundation, 2010a) 
 
Return to driving is relevant across the continuum of stroke recovery. Stroke survivors and those 
who experience TIAs and who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting will 
likely want to return to driving. Therefore, it is important that education on the restrictio ns in 
driving after stroke and TIA is provided in the acute hospital setting. If a survivor does not receive 
this education, he or she may not make an informed choice about when to return to driving . 
66

chunk_1311.text:
Some stroke survivors need a driving assessment before t hey resume driving (Barnsley, 
McCluskey, & Middleton, 2012), and all should receive “clearance” to return to driving.  
 
2.3.2 Return-to-driving advice and assessment  
The Austroads guidelines recommend that a stroke survivor receive clearance from a medical 
professional (namely a doctor) prior to returning to driving (Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2016). Doctors are often the final decision -makers when it comes to a person’s 
ability to return to driving (Liddle, Hayes, Gustafsson, & Fleming, 2014 ), and a general 
practitioner (GP;  a person’s local physician) will often provide thi s to stroke survivors wanting 
advice on RTD ( Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ; McNamara, Ratcliffe, George, & Walker, 2011 ). 
Although the GP is often called upon to provide “medical clearance” or determine a person’s 
“fitness to drive” (S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ), evidence suggests that GPs lack the skill and

chunk_1312.text:
“fitness to drive” (S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ), evidence suggests that GPs lack the skill and 
educational resources to adequately assess a person’s suitability to return to driving after illness 
or injury (S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999). Jang et al. (2007) surveyed 445 GPs on practices related 
to assessing fitness to drive. They reported that almost 50% of physicians did not feel confident 
in their ability to assess fitness to  drive and that almost 50% did not feel suitably qualified to 
make such decisions. The GPs were also influenced by mandatory reporting requirements. That 
is, in locations where physicians were legally bound to inform the Driver Licensing Agency of a 
person’s inability to drive a motor vehicle, physicians were less likely to assess patients for 
fitness to drive. They reported evidence of reluctance on the part of GPs when advising patients 
about RTD or assessing suitability to return to driving, with 75% of physicians reporting concerns

chunk_1313.text:
about RTD or assessing suitability to return to driving, with 75% of physicians reporting concerns 
about preserving the physician-patient relationship, and avoidance of discussions about driving 
in order to achieve this. There is consistent evidence that GPs feel torn between the 
maintenance of relationships with patients and concern for other road users (S. Marshall & 
67

chunk_1314.text:
Gilbert, 1999) and, in turn, GPs avoid discussions about driving (Liddle et al., 2014). Liddle et al. 
(2014) investigated the roles health professionals play in managing RTD in patients with acquired 
brain injury who were receiving rehabili tation. They identified that some health professionals 
purposely deferred discussions about driving to other members of the team in order to maintain 
a therapeutic relationship with the patient. There is no evidence to date as to whether this same 
phenomenon is present in patients diagnosed with stroke, especially mild stroke. 
  
Evidence indicates inconsistencies in the provision of RTD advice following stroke. In a cohort 
study of 290 stroke survivors recruited from a rehabilitation centre in the United St ates of 
America and who were between three and six months post -stroke, Fisk et al. (1997)  revealed 
that almost 50% of stroke survivors d id not receive advice from any health professional about

chunk_1315.text:
that almost 50% of stroke survivors d id not receive advice from any health professional about 
their driving ability. Similarly, a longitudinal study of 22 Australian community -dwelling stroke 
survivors by White et al. (2012)  revealed inconsistencies in the provision of advice on RTD.  In 
the White study, almost 20% of participants received no advice prior to discharge home from a 
stroke unit or inpatient rehabilitation unit, and 40% received advice from their GPs once home, 
with one participant “told in a follow-up appointment that he should not be driving. As he was 
unaware of this, he had already been driving” (p. 836).  
 
The fact that Fisk et al. published their findings in 1997 is of concern as it could be argued that 
these findings are out of date. However, White et al. (2012) found inconsistencies still existed in 
the provision of education about RTD to stroke survivors in the rehabilitation phase of their

chunk_1316.text:
the provision of education about RTD to stroke survivors in the rehabilitation phase of their 
recovery. If , over the last 20 years, there  still exists a gap in providing education to stroke 
survivors in a rehabilitation setting, how well is this issue being managed with stroke survivors 
68

chunk_1317.text:
whose impairments may not warrant inpatient rehabilitation and are therefore discharged 
directly home? 
 
If stroke survivor s and their families are provided with inaccurate, inconsistent or no advice 
regarding their driving ability and recommended restrictions and reporting requirements, this 
can influence important decisions they will need to make (Barnsley et al., 2012; Fisk et al., 1997). 
There is emerging evidence that those with mild stroke may not even be aware there are any 
restrictions. Because their hospital admission is usually only a few days long, they may never 
receive any advice or information  about RTD. They may even not be aware of the presence of 
post-stroke impairments or the ir significance in relation to driving motor v ehicles (Fisk et al., 
1997). However, irrespective of stroke severity, due to the recommended restrictions in driving 
for all stroke survivors and people who experience TIA s, all should receive approp riate and

chunk_1318.text:
for all stroke survivors and people who experience TIA s, all should receive approp riate and 
timely advice and evaluation of their driving ability (Fisk et al., 1997). Due to the value placed on 
driving as an occupation, this needs to occur as early as possible, including in the acute hospital 
setting (White et al., 2012 ). This highlights the need for all people with stroke or TIA, who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting, to receive education on the four-week 
and two-week restrictions on driving. 
 
It has been identified that the management of RTD after stroke should apply a multidisciplinary 
team approach (Liddle et al., 2014). In an Australian study of health professionals working in the 
community with stroke survivors, McCluskey and Middleton (2010) investigated the perceived 
barriers experienced by these health professionals when providing outdoor mobility and

chunk_1319.text:
barriers experienced by these health professionals when providing outdoor mobility and 
transport training. They identified that gaps in the knowledge of RTD guidelines and legislation 
across all professions were a barrier. They also reported that occupational therapists were more 
69

chunk_1320.text:
likely to be aware of RTD guidelines, even if they were not sure how to implement them in 
practice. This study is limited by the fact that it was not acute-care-based, with stroke survivors 
receiving rehabilitation, in particular, community -based rehabilitation, following an inpatient 
rehabilitation admission. Although this study is specific to Australia, it nevertheless  highlights 
inconsistencies in the management of RTD  after stroke. What is important a bout this study is 
that it is the first Australian study to report that health professionals feel their lack of knowledge 
of RTD guidelines may be contributing to the RTD practice-evidence gap.  
 
The occupational therapy profession appears to play an important role in RTD after stroke. As 
the definition below indicates, occupational therapists take responsibility for the assessment 
and treatment of functional impairments impacting activities of daily living.

chunk_1321.text:
and treatment of functional impairments impacting activities of daily living.  
 “Occupational therapy is a client -centred health profession concerned with promoting 
health and wellbeing through occupation. The primary goal of occupational therapy is to 
enable people to participate in the activities of everyday life. Occup ational therapists 
achieve this outcome by working with people and communities to enhance their ability 
to engage in the occupations they want to, need to, or are expected to do, or by 
modifying the occupation or the environment to better support their occ upational 
engagement.” 
(World Federation of Occupational Therapists, 2012) 
 
The Stroke Foundation’s clinical guidelines (2010) recommend that all survivors with residual 
neurological impairments undertake driver assessment (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ). 
Because of the professional expertise of occupational therapists, they are often asked to 
70

chunk_1322.text:
evaluate a person’s ability to drive , and some are qualified to do so (Korner-Bitensky et al., 
2006). The role of the occupational therapist in driving assessment and retraining is well -
documented in rehabilitation and community contexts (Crotty & George, 2009; Fisk et al., 1997; 
Korner-Bitensky et al., 2006; Mazer et al., 2003). They have the outcome measures and expertise 
to assess visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and cognitive function after stroke, including the 
functions required to operate a motor vehicle. What is not well -documented, however, is how 
this domain of professional responsibility is managed in the acute, inpatient hospital setting. If 
only some of the patients diagnosed with acute stroke or TIA are referred to occupational 
therapists, how is RTD managed in those who are not referre d? Are there other professions 
filling this potential gap in clinical practice? It not, are some of the patients diagnosed with a

chunk_1323.text:
filling this potential gap in clinical practice? It not, are some of the patients diagnosed with a 
recent stroke or TIA being discharged directly home, unaware that they must comply with RTD 
restrictions of up to four weeks after the stroke event and two weeks after the TIA event? 
2.4  Conclusion 
Impairments resulting from stroke, including visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and cognitive  
impairments, can impact a person’s ability to drive a motor vehicle safely and efficiently. I n 
Australia, following stroke, survivors are restricted in driving for four weeks, and after TIA, they 
are restricted for two weeks. The driving restrictions in place after stroke and TIA are due to the 
risk of recurrent TIA and/or stroke in the days and weeks after the event, and are not necessarily 
due to functional limitations after stroke. Even so, there are significant functional impairments 
resulting from stroke that can also impact driving. After stroke and TIA, medical clearance is

chunk_1324.text:
resulting from stroke that can also impact driving. After stroke and TIA, medical clearance is 
recommended to return to driving, and prior to discharge,  all survivors should receive written 
and verbal information about RTD. Although occupational therapists and doctors have role s in 
the management of RTD after stroke, all health professionals working in the field of stroke have 
71

chunk_1325.text:
a responsibility to discuss RTD with stroke survivors . However, evidence indicates there is a 
general sense of reluctance to do so and a trend to defer to others. Even in a rehabilitation 
context, where survivors are more likely to have neurological impairments assessed and treated, 
inconsistencies exist in the provision of advice on, and the management of, RTD after stroke. 
This raises questions about what may or may not occur in patients diagnosed with mild stroke 
and TIA. The last cohort, therefore, is of interest to this doctoral research study, because this 
group is more likely to be discharged directly home from the acute setting and , in turn, more 
likely to have relatively short stays in hospital.  
This literature review has highlighted t he importance placed on RTD following stroke and TIA , 
and the recommended restrictions in driving for all persons with stroke and TIA, regardless of

chunk_1326.text:
and the recommended restrictions in driving for all persons with stroke and TIA, regardless of 
severity. What this literature review has not been able to identify, define or describe is the 
management of RTD in patients who are diagnosed with stroke or TIA and who are discharged 
directly home from the acute hospital setting. This thesis will aim to generate new knowledge 
about how RTD is managed in patients diagnosed with stroke and TIA who are discharge d 
directly home from the acute hospital setting, and how to bridge the related practice-evidence 
gaps identified. Chapter three presents the findings of a systematic review which investigated 
the adherence to RTD guidelines in the acute hospital setting.  
72

chunk_1357.text:
Chapter 3 
 
Systematic Review 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Corresponding publication:  Frith, J., Hubbard , I.J., James , C.L. &  Warren-Forward, H . (2015) 
Returning to driving after stroke: A systematic review investigating adherence to legislation and 
guidelines. British Journal of Occupational Therapy, 78 (6), 349 -355. doi: 
10.1177/0308022614562795  
87

chunk_1358.text:
3.1 Chapter overview 
The aim of the systematic review of the literature  was to determine how well health 
professionals around the world were managing return to driving (RTD) after stroke or transient 
ischaemic attack (TIA) in the acute hospital setting. In Australia, there is a four-week restriction 
in driving after stroke and a two -week restriction after TIA. The aim of the systematic review 
was to determine whether health prof essionals working in acute hospitals routinely provide 
education on restrictions in driving after stroke or TIA, prior to the patient leaving hospital. The 
second aim was to determine whether stroke survivors actually adhere to driving restrictions 
and when people with mild stroke or TIA return to driving.

chunk_1367.text:
3.3 Chapter synopsis 
The systematic review revealed that there is an extensive body of literature on the assessment 
(Devos et al., 2011; S. C. Marshall et al., 2007; Ponsford et al., 2008; Soderstrom et al., 2006) and 
retraining (Akinwuntan et al., 2005 ; Akinwuntan, Devos, Nieuwboer, et al., 2010 ; Devos et al., 
2010; Mazer et al., 2003 ) of driving in stroke survivors in the rehabilitation and community 
settings. However, there is little evidence on ho w RTD is managed for patients with stroke or 
TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting  (Frith et al., 2015 ). This 
systematic review captured only three studies (Biswas, Radhakrishnan, Banerjee, & Datta -
Chaudhuri, 2006; J. Johnston, Stocks, Chaudhuri, & Dey, 2004; McCarron, Loftus, & McCarron, 
2008), all based in the United Kingdom, that investigated the provision of education in the acute 
setting and/or the RTD behaviours of patients with stroke or TIA. The ke y findings were that

chunk_1368.text:
setting and/or the RTD behaviours of patients with stroke or TIA. The ke y findings were that 
occupational therapists were the main providers of education on RTD restrictions, but that only 
50% of patients with stroke or TIA were seen by an occupational therapist during their hospital 
admissions. However, the study also revealed that if provided with RTD e ducation in the acute 
setting, 64% of people with stroke or TIA waited at least four weeks before returning to driving. 
The systematic review revealed that not only is RTD in the acute hospital setting not well -
researched, in those studies that have been conducted, only 50% of patients received education 
on driving restrictions. This investigation identified a gap in knowledge about current clinical 
practice in Australia related to the management of RTD in patients with stroke or TIA who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting.  Chapter four will therefore present

chunk_1369.text:
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting.  Chapter four will therefore present 
the findings from a medical record audit of patients discharged directly home from a regional 
hospital with stroke or TIA and from a post-discharge anonymous patient survey.  
  
96

chunk_1373.text:
Chapter 4 
 
Medical Record Audit and  
Anonymous Patient Survey 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Corresponding publication: Frith, J., Warren -Forward, H., Hubbard , I.J. &  James, C.L. (2017) 
Shifting gears: An inpatient medical record audit and post discharge survey of return to driving 
following stroke/transient ischaemic attack.  Australian Journal of Occupational Therapy. doi: 
10.1111/1440-1630.12359  
99

chunk_1374.text:
4.1 Chapter overview 
The systematic review revealed only three studies (Biswas et al., 2006; J. Johnston et al., 2004; 
McCarron et al., 2008) investigating the management of return to driving (RTD) after stroke and 
transient ischaemic attack (TIA) in the acute hospital setting. A lthough driving after stroke is a 
well-researched topic, the systematic review revealed that the management of RTD for the 
patient with stroke or TIA discharged directly home from  the acute setting ( the study’s 
participant cohort) is not (Frith et al., 2015). As the published literature was based on studies in 
the United Kingdom, more extensive research is required.  
The aim of this study was to investigate current practice in Australia in the management of RTD 
for patients with stroke and TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital. The 
study was undertaken in one tertiary hospital in New South Wales, Australia. It included an audit

chunk_1375.text:
study was undertaken in one tertiary hospital in New South Wales, Australia. It included an audit 
of the inpatient medical records of the study’s patient cohort (Appendix 1), and a post-discharge 
anonymous patient survey  (Appendix 2) . The med ical record audit investigated t he 
documentation related to the provision of education and RTD management plans. The post -
discharge patient survey investigated whether patients discharged from the acute hospital 
setting recalled receiving advice on driving restrictions and whether they adhered to this advice. 
100

chunk_1386.text:
4.3 Chapter synopsis 
The results of this study revealed that the documentation of provision of education on RTD and 
RTD management plans is inconsistent for patients with stroke or TIA who were discharged 
directly home from the acute hospital setting. The precursors to having RTD education 
documented in the medical records were input by occupational therapist s, documentation of 
cognitive impairment, and patients who were male (Frith et al., 2017). With only 50% of patients 
being seen by occupational therapists (Biswas et al., 2006; Frith et al., 2017), the findings from 
this study provide one reason why some patients in the study’s cohort may not be receiving the 
recommended RTD management in the acute hospital setting. A promising finding from the 
patients surveyed was that 65% of patients waited four weeks  or more before returning to 
driving, offering some evidence that if provided with education on restrictions in driving after

chunk_1387.text:
driving, offering some evidence that if provided with education on restrictions in driving after 
stroke or TIA, patients are more likely to adhere to the advice they have received (Frith et al., 
2017).  
 
The results of the systematic review, the medical record audit and the anonymous patient survey 
revealed that a practice-evidence gap is evident in adherence to RTD clinical guidelines in the 
acute hospital setting. Further investigation is needed to determine why this gap exists. Chapter 
five presents the findings of a national survey conducted with Australian health professionals 
working in stroke to determine their knowledge of RTD clinical guidelines and how they are used 
in clinical practice. 
 
  
111
