chunk_1391.text:
5.1 Chapter overview 
The results of the systematic review  and the medical record audit in the previous chapter s 
revealed that occupational therapists were the only health professionals documenting return-
to-driving (RTD) management plans for patients with stroke and transient ischaemic attack (TIA) 
prior to disc harge home from the acute hospital setting. The results raised questions as to 
whether or not other health professionals might be involved in the management of RTD without 
this being documented, and questions about potential practice -evidence gaps in the use of 
Austroads’ guidelines (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ) and the National 
Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management (National Stroke Foundation, 
2010a). Gaps potentially relate to the role of the multiprofessional team in providing education 
to patients with stroke a nd TIA about restrictions in driving and in the documentation of RTD 
management plans.

chunk_1392.text:
management plans.  
 
The aim of this study was to gain an understanding of the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines 
among Australian health professionals working with patients diagnosed with recent stroke and 
TIA. The findings of this study are reported in two manuscripts. The first manuscript (Section 5.2) 
presents the findings from an analysis of the quantitative survey data. The second manuscript 
(Section 5.3) presents the findings from a n analysis of the qualitative survey data , that is, an  
analysis of the free-text question at the end of the survey, “Is there anything else you would like 
to add?”. This chapter includes both manuscripts. 
  
114

chunk_1393.text:
5.2 Return to driving after stroke: Knowledge of health professionals 
5.2.1 Introduction 
The ability to drive a motor vehicle has a significant impact on the quality of life of stroke 
survivors and is a major predictor of a stroke survivor’s return to independence (Griffen, 
Rapport, Bryer, & Scott, 2009 ; Liddle et al., 2009 ; Lister, 1999; Patomella, Johansson, & Tham, 
2009). The deficits that result from stroke and can impact the ability to drive a motor vehicle are 
well-researched (Fisk et al., 2002 ; Lee et al., 2003 ; McKay et al., 2011 ). They include (i) upper 
and lower limb sensorimotor dysfunction ; (ii) impairments in judgement, mental processing, 
comprehension and reaction time; and (iii) deficits in peripheral vision (Devos et al., 2011). 
 
Even if a person has a mild stroke, impairments such as visual field deficits, sensorimotor 
dysfunction and poor concentration can still be present during the initial recovery phase of

chunk_1394.text:
dysfunction and poor concentration can still be present during the initial recovery phase of 
stroke. Not only can these deficits impact a person’s driving ability, he or she is also at risk of 
either recurrent stroke in the first month or recurrent TIA in the first week after a TIA (Hennessy 
& Britton, 2000). Rothwell and Warlow (2005) reported that 17% of TIAs occur on the same day 
of a stroke, 9% on the day before a stroke and 43% in the week preceding a stroke. Furthermore, 
following stroke, there is also a 9% incidence of seizures within the first two years (Bladin et al., 
2000; Yale, Hansotia, Knapp, & John, 2003). A stroke survivor who experiences a mild stroke is 
often discharged directly home from the Acute Stroke Unit or acute medical ward after having 
only stayed in hospital for a few hours or days.  
 
In Australia, the guidelines entitled “Assessing Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private

chunk_1395.text:
In Australia, the guidelines entitled “Assessing Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private 
Vehicle Drivers” (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016) were developed by  the 
Australasian Road Transpor t and Traffic Agencies (Austroads) and the National Transport 
115

chunk_1396.text:
Commission. The purpose of these guidelines is to provide Australian health professionals with 
medical standards for licensing  and clinical guidelines for determining fitness  to drive. These 
stipulate a four-week restriction in driving after all strokes and a two-week restriction after TIAs. 
In addition, t he Australian Stroke Foundation’s Guidelines for Stroke Management (National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010 a)  recommend that stroke survivors be provided with verbal and 
written information about: 
• The impact of stroke on driving skills and driving restrictions imposed after stroke  
• How to be cleared to drive at the end of the restriction period  
• The driver’s obligation to inform their State ’s or Territory’s Driver Licensing Authority 
of their stroke. 
 
Return to driving  after an acute admission for  TIA or stroke is an under -researched topic, as 
demonstrated by the findings in the systematic review (Frith et al., 2015), which identified only

chunk_1397.text:
demonstrated by the findings in the systematic review (Frith et al., 2015), which identified only 
three studies (Biswas et al., 2006; Johnston et al., 2004; McCarron et al., 2008) that investigated 
RTD behaviours associated with patients who had TIA or  stroke and were discharged directly 
home from an acute hospital. The review identified that less than 50% of stroke survivors in the 
United Kingdom received RTD education prior to leaving hospital, and about one-third returned 
to driving during the restricted period. This evidence indicates that survivors of TIA or mild stroke 
may be at high risk of resuming driving because they have not been provided with RTD education 
and may therefore be unaware they should not be driving. As the review contained no Australian 
data, what was missing from the literature was how well Australian health professionals are 
managing RTD after TIA or stroke in the acute setting and whether they are adhering to

chunk_1398.text:
managing RTD after TIA or stroke in the acute setting and whether they are adhering to 
nationally-agreed RTD clinical guidelines. 
116

chunk_1399.text:
The aim of this study was to assess the knowledge  about, and use of, RTD guidelines  
recommended by Austroads’ guidelines and the National Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines 
for Stroke Management, among Australian health professionals working with stroke survivors.  
 
5.2.2 Methodology 
5.2.2.1 Study design 
A cross-sectional, anonymous survey (Appendix 3) was used to assess the knowledge and use of 
Austroads’ guidelines and the National Stroke Foundation ’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke 
Management by health professionals working with stroke survivors.   
 
5.2.2.2 Participants 
Any Australian health professional working in the field of stroke was eligible to participate. The 
authors sought to obtain a cross -section of professionals from medicine, nursing and allied 
health.  
 
5.2.2.3 Survey tool 
The survey consisted of three sections (Table 5.1). Section A contained 9 fixed -response

chunk_1400.text:
The survey consisted of three sections (Table 5.1). Section A contained 9 fixed -response 
questions about the respondents’ knowledge of and opinions about RTD guidelines and clinical 
practice in the management of RTD. The two questions that were the focus for this manuscript 
were those related to the driving restrictions following TIA and stroke  (questions 2 and 3) . 
Section B contained 7 fixed-response questions on respondents’ demographics. Some of these 
questions provided an opportunity for respondents to expand on the information provided. For 
example, if a respondent selected “allied health”, there was an option to select a specific allied 
117

chunk_1401.text:
health professiona l. Section C contained a single , open-response question allowing the 
respondent to provide further details on any other information related to the survey. The survey 
was available both electronically (hosted by SurveyMonkey) and in hard-copy form. The survey 
(Table 5.1) was based on issues of concern raised in the literature and was pilot tested with a 
small cohort of health professionals from different disciplines, working in the field of stroke, for 
face and content validity prior to distribution. 
 
5.2.2.4 Data analysis 
Survey results were analysed using MS Excel and SPSS version 20.0 (Coakes, 2013). Results from 
each response were analysed and reported as descriptive outcomes (mean, standard deviations 
and percentages) and associations between demographic data and responses were teste d and 
reported as odds ratios.

5.2.2.5 Procedures 
The study was approved by the Human  Research Ethics Committee of the University of 
Newcastle, Australia (Appendix 4) . Email invitations were sent via professional associations , 
including Occupational Therapy Australia, the Australian Physiotherapy Association, Speech 
Pathology Australia, the Australian College of Nursing, the Australasian Faculty of Rehabilitation 
Medicine, and the Rural Doctors Association of Australia. Email invitations were also sent via 
stroke-specific clinical networks in the different Australian States and Territories and via 
Australian universities offering health-related programs. A hard-copy invitation was distributed

chunk_1408.text:
Australian universities offering health-related programs. A hard-copy invitation was distributed 
at a national stroke conference. Recipients were also encouraged to forward the survey 
invitation to colleagues. The survey was available for four months  from August to December 
2012. Consent was implied when participants responded to the survey. 
  
122

chunk_1409.text:
5.2.3 Results 
5.2.3.1 Characteristics of respondents 
Of the 455 survey respondents (Table 5.2), 74% were allied health professionals and 13% were 
doctors. Over 60% of the allied health professionals were occupational therapists and over half 
of the doctors were general practitioners (the Australian term for a person’s local doctor) in the 
primary health care sector . Forty-six percent of respondents were aged between 26 and 35 
years, 36% were based in the State of New South Wales, 32% had gre ater than 10 years ’ 
professional experience in the care of stroke survivors, and 54% worked in hospitals.   
When asked to recall the number of stroke survivors respondents had provided health care to 
in the previous four weeks, 40% (n=180) reported between 3 and 10 survivors and 22% (n=98) 
reported between one and two . When asked to recall the number of stroke survivors 
respondents had provided RTD education to in the previous four weeks, 34% (n=125) reported

chunk_1410.text:
respondents had provided RTD education to in the previous four weeks, 34% (n=125) reported 
they had not provided RTD education to any survivors of stroke, and a further 37% (n=136) had 
only provided RTD education to one or two stroke survivors. When compared with their 
colleagues, respondents with over 10 years’ experience were more likely to have seen a greater 
number of stroke survivors (p=0.0013). Those who worked in hospitals were also more likely to 
have provided RTD education to a greater number of stroke survivors (p<0.0001).

chunk_1413.text:
5.2.3.2 Respondents’ knowledge of return-to-driving guidelines 
Respondents to the survey were asked two knowledge -based questions about restrictions in 
driving after TIA and stroke. A lmost all respondents answered the question s on TIA (97.8% ; 
n=445) and on stroke  (98%; n= 446). However, o f these, only 12% (n=53) responde d as 
recommended to both questions , i.e. a  two-week restriction after TIA and a four -week 
restriction after stroke. Only  27% responded as recommended following TIA , and 22% as 
recommended following stroke. Nearly two-thirds of health professionals (63%; n=281) chose 
non-recommended responses to both questions. 
 
5.2.3.3 Analysis of driving restrictions after a transient ischaemic attack: Two weeks 
Of the 27% (n=119) respondents who selected the recommended answer to the question about 
RTD restrictions after TIA (Table 5.3), 45% (n=202) responded that people with TIA “should not

chunk_1414.text:
RTD restrictions after TIA (Table 5.3), 45% (n=202) responded that people with TIA “should not 
drive until told so by their doctor ”, 16% ( n=72) that they should not drive for four weeks and 
12% (n= 52) responded that there were no restrictions in driving after a TIA.  
 
Those who were significantly more likely to provide the recommended answer were 
respondents who had seen between  3 and 40 stroke survivors in the four weeks prior to 
completing the survey (p=0.005), those who were occupational therapists (p=0.002) and those 
who worked in hospital s (p=0.04). Those who were significantly more likely to provide non-
recommended answers were those who had worked with stroke survivors for >10 years 
(p=0.03). In the four weeks prior to completing the survey , these respondents were also more 
likely to have provided advice on RTD to ≤2 or >40 stroke survivors (p=0.0001).

Those who were significantly more likely to provide the recommended answer of a four-week 
restriction had either ≤2 years’ professional experience or 5-10 years’ experience (p=0.02) and 
had worked with stroke survivors for 1-10 years (p=0.03). In the four weeks prior to completing 
the survey, these respondents were also more likely to have provided health care to 11-60 stroke 
survivors ( p=0.002) or provided advice on RTD to 11 -40 stroke survivors. In addition, 
respondents who provided the recommended answer were also more likely to be occupational

(p=0.03).

5.2.3.5 Professional responsibilities after stroke and transient ischaemic attack 
In response to the question regarding which health professionals should provide RTD education 
to people with TIA and stroke (Table 5.5), a total of 446 respondents answered this question. 
Respondents could select more than one answer and 85% (n=379) selected the occupational 
therapist and 72% (n=319) the doctor.  In response to the question asking when people with TIA 
or stroke should be provided with RTD education, 92% ( n=411) selected whil e in hospital. In 
response to the question about the reporting of concerns regarding driving ability to licensing 
128

chunk_1419.text:
authorities, 66% (n=293) correctly responded that health professionals have a legal and ethical 
responsibility to inform authorities when there are concerns about a person’s ability to drive.

5.2.4 Discussion 
This study identified that health professionals’ knowledge about RTD after stroke is limited, with 
many unaware of the recommended RTD restrictions after both stroke and TIA. The study’s 
respondents identified occupational therapists as the most appropriate health professionals to 
provide education to people with TIA and stroke on restrictions in driving , and general 
practitioners as the most appropriate health professionals to provide clearance to return to 
driving. However, it is importan t to bear in mind that more than 50% of respondents to the 
survey were occupational therapists. Even so, this raises concerns about the adequacy of RTD 
management, as evidence indicates that less than 50% of patients with recent stroke or TIA who 
129

chunk_1421.text:
are discharged directly home are referred to occupational therapists (Biswas et al., 2006; Frith 
et al., 2017).   
 
5.2.4.1 Knowledge of return-to-driving guidelines 
This study identified that only 1 in 5 healt h professionals correctly identified the four-week 
driving restriction after stroke and only 3 in 10 correctly identified the  two-week driving 
restriction after TIA.  Many responded that people with either a TIA or stroke should not return 
to driving until cleared to do so by a doctor. According to Austroads’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines 
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ) and the Stroke Foundation ’s Clinical 
Guidelines for Stroke (National Stroke Foundatio n, 2010a ), once the restriction period ends, 
medical clearance is required to return to driving. Therefore, this answer is partially correct. 
However, firstly, it means that stroke survivors may not be informed about the recommended

chunk_1422.text:
However, firstly, it means that stroke survivors may not be informed about the recommended 
restrictions; and secondly, it assumes that the survivor will discuss this issue with his or her local 
doctor and that the doctor is knowledgeable about RTD restrictions after stroke and TIA. What 
this study has not been able to identify is whether  the cohort of health profes sionals who 
answered “until told so by a doctor” are aware of the restriction periods after TIA and stroke or 
whether they are deferring to other health professionals to manage RTD. These findings suggest 
that a practice-evidence gap may exist in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines. Evidence 
suggests that while the use of clinical guidelines in stroke can improve outcomes for stroke 
survivors, difficulties exist in the implementation of these guidelines (Hubbard et al., 2012). If a 
practice-evidence gap does exist, it may be the result of health professionals’ skills and attitudes,

chunk_1423.text:
culture within the health facility and availability of the guidelines (Kang & Schneck, 2004).  
 
130

chunk_1424.text:
A promising finding is that health professionals working in hospitals were more aware of the 
restriction period following TIA and stroke. This appears to indicate that  survivors of TIA and 
stroke may be receiving this information prior to leaving hospital.  However, due to the bias 
towards occupational therapists among the respondents , education may be provided by 
occupational therapists, rather than by other members of the multidisciplinary team.  
 
5.2.4.2 Role of local doctors 
The respondents in this study have indicated that health professionals rely on the medical 
profession, particularly a person’s general practitioner (local doctor), to provide advice about 
RTD after TIA and stroke. In everyday clinical practice, in a cohort of patients who are discharged 
directly home from the acute hospital setting, GPs may be the only health professionals involved 
in the long term. Therefore, the role of managing a person’s RTD should, perhaps, default to the

chunk_1425.text:
in the long term. Therefore, the role of managing a person’s RTD should, perhaps, default to the 
GP. Evidence suggests, however, that GPs are not necessarily the best professionals to provide 
advice on RTD, as they are less likely to know RTD guidelines (Marshall & Gilbert, 1999) and are 
likely to find the assessment of driving ability  challenging (Jang et al., 2007 ; Jones, Rouse -
Watson, Beveridge, Sims, & Schattner, 2012 ). There is also a reluctance on the part of GPs to 
discuss driving with patients for fear of damaging the physician -patient relationship , and 
because of the pressures of mandatory reporting in some places (Jang et al., 2007; Liddle et al., 
2014; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ). This can create clinical variance between the advice one 
person may receive from a GP as opposed to what another pe rson may receive. A person may 
(i) return to driving when they are legally not supposed to , or (ii) be restricted in driving longer

chunk_1426.text:
than is required, thus creating an increased burden on daily life  and a reduced quality of life. 
This clinical variance in health professionals’ advice also has implications for the stroke survivor’s 
licensing and insurance responsibilities and the health professional ’s ethical, and sometimes 
legal, responsibilities (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016). 
131

chunk_1427.text:
5.2.4.3 Role of occupational therapists 
Over 80% of respondents nominated the occupational therapist as the most appropriate person 
to provide advice on RTD after stroke; presumably, this is expected to occur while the patients 
are still in hospital. The results of this study indicate that occupational therapists are more likely 
to provide  the recommended advice. Considering the high response rate from occupational 
therapists, it can be concluded that they themselves have identified their profession as having 
this role in RTD management.  
 
Literature suggests that the role of providing education on RTD while a patient is still in hospital 
lies with occupational therapists (Frith et al., 2015 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). There is extensive 
literature on the role occupational therapists play in assessing a person’s ability to drive (Devos 
et al., 2011 ; Korner-Bitensky et al., 2000 ; Korner-Bitensky, Sofer, Gelinas, & Mazer, 1998 ;

chunk_1428.text:
et al., 2011 ; Korner-Bitensky et al., 2000 ; Korner-Bitensky, Sofer, Gelinas, & Mazer, 1998 ; 
Lundberg, Caneman, Samuelsson, Hakamies-Blomqvist, & Almkvist, 2003) and driver retraining 
(Akinwuntan, Devos, Verheyden, et al., 2010; Crotty & George, 2009; Devos et al., 2009; Mazer 
et al., 2003). However, this literature is based on a cohort of stroke survivors who were in the 
rehabilitation phase of their recovery and not in the acute hospital setting. If, as the evidence 
suggests, occupational therapists may see only 50% of patients with stroke and TIA admitted to 
acute hospitals (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Frith et al., 2017 ), less than half of all patients  would be 
provided with education about driving if they were discharged directly home from the acute 
setting. Stroke survivors who make a full recovery from stroke or have impairments which do 
not re quire inpatient rehabilitation are still at risk of recurrent stroke (Hennessy & Britton,

chunk_1429.text:
not re quire inpatient rehabilitation are still at risk of recurrent stroke (Hennessy & Britton, 
2000). Reliance on the occupational therapist to provide advice on RTD in the acute hospital 
setting potentially leads to a practice-evidence gap and may be putting stroke survivors at risk 
of driving during restriction periods because they are unaware of the restrictions.  
132

chunk_1430.text:
5.2.4.4 Influence of years of experience 
The number of years working in a chosen profession and the number of years working in the 
field of stroke influenced knowledge of RTD guidelines for stroke in this stu dy. Health 
professionals with less than one year’s professional experience  or greater than 10 years ’ 
professional experience were less likely to know RTD restrictions following stroke and TIA. This 
may be due to inexperienced health professionals not being aware of RTD guidelines and more 
experienced health professionals not being aware that such guidelines have been revised. 
However, the results of this study revealed that experienced health professionals are more likely 
to see a higher number of stroke su rvivors each month (for example, more than 40) when 
compared with health professionals with less experience. If this is the case, a seemingly highly 
skilled and experienced workforce is not utilising readily available RTD guidelines. The question

chunk_1431.text:
skilled and experienced workforce is not utilising readily available RTD guidelines. The question 
remains as to why.   
 
5.2.5 Limitations 
A limitation of this study is the potential misinterpretation of the two knowledge -based 
questions. One respondent indicated in the free-text section of the survey that there were two 
possible answers to the questions regarding restrictions in driving after TIA and stroke. The 
answer the researchers were looking for was “restricted in driving for two weeks” and 
“restricted in driving for four weeks” respectively. However, the response of “should not drive 
until cleared by a medical professional” could technically also be correct as medical clearance is 
required prior to the TIA or stroke survivor’s return to driving. This misunderstanding could have 
impacted on some of the participants’ responses to these questions, as 45% answered this way 
to the TIA question and 77% to the stroke question. Further limitations include the bias towards

chunk_1432.text:
to the TIA question and 77% to the stroke question. Further limitations include the bias towards 
133

chunk_1433.text:
occupational therapists being the main respondents to the survey  as well as the researchers 
being unable to determine the potential sample size for the survey. 
 
5.2.6 Conclusion 
There are two key questions that remain unanswered following the results of this study. Firstly, 
are health professionals aware of the restriction periods present after TIA and stroke? Secondly, 
if the health professional is unaware, are people with recent TIA or stroke at risk of being  
misinformed regarding driving restrictions? 
 
Both occupational therapists and doctors have been identified as having an important role to 
play in providing education on RTD. However, due to the limited number of responses from 
health professionals other than occupational therapists and physicians, this may not reflect the 
views of all health professionals working in the field of stroke. Further investigation is required 
to gain a clearer understanding of the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines among all health

chunk_1434.text:
to gain a clearer understanding of the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines among all health 
professionals working in the field of stroke. Further education and support may be required for 
health professionals on their knowledge and use of RTD guidelines, to ensure that survivors of 
TIA and stroke who are discharged directly home from an acute hospital  setting are aware of 
how to manage their return to driving.  
 
134

chunk_1435.text:
5.3 Australian health professionals’ experience of return-to-driving 
guidelines after stroke 
5.3.1 Introduction 
Acute hospitals in Australia admit about 30,000 patients with stroke each year. Discharge 
planning is vital for patients who transition from acute -care facilities directly back into the 
community (National Stroke Foundation, 2015 ). While RTD management plan s should be 
provided as part of their discharge care plans (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a), only 44% of 
stroke survivors are discharged home with plans (National Stroke Foundation, 2015).  Australia’s  
Stroke Foundati on Guidelines for Stroke Management  (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ) 
recommend that patients be provided with both verbal and wri tten information about the 
impact of stroke on driving skills; driving restrictions imposed after stroke; how to be cleared to 
drive at the completion of the restriction period; and the stroke survivor’s obligation to inform

chunk_1436.text:
drive at the completion of the restriction period; and the stroke survivor’s obligation to inform 
their State’s or Territory’s Driver Licensing Authority of the stroke. The restrictions for driving a 
private vehicle recommend a four-week restriction in driving after all strokes and a two-week 
restriction in driving after TIA  (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ; National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010a ). For Australian health professionals, these recommended driving 
restrictions, and other medical standards for licensing , are published in The Australian Road 
Transport and Traffic Agencies’ (Austroads’) and the National Transport Commission’s Assessing 
Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private Vehicle Drivers  (Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2016). At the end of the restriction period, clearance by a medical professional to 
return to driving is also recommended.

chunk_1437.text:
return to driving is also recommended. 
 
Evidence is emerging of a practice-evidence gap in the use of RTD guidelines in patients who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting (Frith et al., 2015; Frith et al., 2017). A 
135

chunk_1438.text:
systematic review (Frith et al ., 2015) revealed no evidence regarding adherence to Australian 
RTD guidelines, both in the health professionals’ responsibility to discuss RTD with the stroke 
survivor prior to being discharged home from the acute hospital  setting, and in the patient’s 
adherence to the stipulated driving restrictions. The systematic review revealed three studies, 
all based in the United Kingdom, highlighting that less than 50% of stroke survivors discharged 
directly home from the acute setting received education on RTD and that provision of education 
was highly associated with whether or not a stroke survivor was seen by occupational therapists 
during the admission (Biswas et al., 2006; Johnston et al., 2004; McCarron et al., 2008). As only 
50% of stroke survivors are seen by an occupational therapist during their acute admission s 
(Biswas et al., 2006; Frith et al., 2017), this raises concerns about adherence to RTD guidelines

chunk_1439.text:
(Biswas et al., 2006; Frith et al., 2017), this raises concerns about adherence to RTD guidelines 
and the roles other health professionals play in the management of RTD after stroke. This study 
aims to explore the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines among Australian health professionals 
working in the field of stroke. 
 
This study reports on the analysis of the qualitative data in the responses to a national survey of 
Australian health professionals’ knowledge and use of RTD guidelines following stroke. 
 
5.3.2 Methods 
This study is a parallel paper presenting qualitative data from a survey which has been described 
elsewhere. This study was approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee of the University 
of Newcastle, Australia (Appendix 4). A cross-sectional, anonymous survey was used to gather 
information from Australian health professionals working in the field of stroke on their

chunk_1440.text:
information from Australian health professionals working in the field of stroke on their 
knowledge and use of RTD guidelines (Appendix 3). Details of the full survey have been reported 
elsewhere (Frith, James, Hubbard, & Warren-Forward, 2016b). The data analysed for this study 
136

chunk_1441.text:
were submitted in response to an open -ended question asking respondents for any additional 
comments that they would like to provide. The survey was available for four months from August 
to December 2012. Informed consent was implied when participants responded to the survey. 
When direct quotes from respondents have been used, corrections to spelling, grammar or 
abbreviations have been underlined, for example; R28 (SP): “I feel that is a concern that 
reporting to the RTA [Road Traffic Authority] following a stroke is not mandatory.”  In addition, 
the occupation of the respondent making the quote has been identified. For example, the above 
statement was made by a speech pathologist. All occupations with their associated 
abbreviations are provided in Table 5.6. 
 
Inductive thematic analysis was used to investigate responses to the survey question, “Is there 
anything else you would like to add?”. This enabled an in-depth, exploratory investigation of the

chunk_1442.text:
anything else you would like to add?”. This enabled an in-depth, exploratory investigation of the 
qualitative data (Kelly, 1985). Responses were read through several times to identify common 
sub-themes within the text. Data that were relevant to the phenomena in question were 
extracted and placed into an Excel spreadsheet. Following reading of the transcripts, two 
authors (JF and CJ) used an inductive approach to code data into relevant and meaningful 
categories (Bowling, 2002 ). A meeting occurred between these two researchers to merge 
categories into themes. This allowed for intersubjective agreement on the final themes  (Kvale, 
2007). To ensure validity of the interpretation of the data, key themes were checked for 
confirming and disconfirming evidence within the dataset (Erickson, 1986). To remove bias and 
to ensure the validity of the themes, the data were reviewed independently by a third researcher 
(IH). 
 
137

chunk_1443.text:
5.3.3 Results 
5.3.3.1 Characteristics of respondents 
Of the 455 survey respondents who completed the survey, 90 (19.8%) respondents provided 
answers to the open -ended question. Twenty responses were not included in the analysis as 
they were not relevant to the study’s aims, for  example, “ You omitted Geriatrician and 
Rehabilitation specialist from some of your survey choices”. Therefore, there were 70 remaining 
comments, of which 56 (80%) were provided by allied health professionals, and w ere included 
in the thematic analysis. Table 5.6 shows the percentage and number of participants by health 
profession.

chunk_1445.text:
The thematic data analysis identified two main themes, Knowledge ( Section 5.3.3.2) and 
Responsibility (Section 5.3.3.3), and, under each theme, three sub -themes. The sub-themes of 
Knowledge are professional uncertainty and inconsistency ; deferring to others ; and patient 
uncertainty and inconsistencies. The sub -themes of Responsibility are health professionals ’ 
responsibility; mandatory reporting; and driver assessment.  
  
5.3.3.2 Theme one: Knowledge 
Two-thirds (67%; n=61) of the respondents made comments pertaining to knowledge about RTD 
guidelines and process, and these were coded into three sub-themes:  
• Professional uncertainty and inconsistency  
• Deferring to others 
• Patient uncertainty and inconsistency.   
 
Professional uncertainty and inconsistency 
In the management of RTD after stroke, responders identified a need  for education, a lack of 
education and training, improved guidelines and consistency regarding practice and existing

chunk_1446.text:
education and training, improved guidelines and consistency regarding practice and existing 
processes, as shown in the following responses: 
 “… all professionals working with clients who sustained strokes should receive adequate 
information as to what to tell the clients with regard to return to driving.” R51 (OT) 
“Big issue which is currently handled poorly at all levels.” R37 (C) 
 
139

chunk_1447.text:
They also wrote about a lack of knowledge with regard to RTD guidelines, the complexity of the 
current processes and guidelines, and a lack of available education and resources, as shown in 
the following responses: 
 “Undertaking this survey has highlighted my lack of knowledge in this field.” R1 (RN) 
“… how complicated the whole process is.” R3 (OT) 
 
Respondents also expressed concerns about the lack of education and resources available to 
assist health professionals to provide appropriate advice to patients , and the confusing nature 
of the current guidelines, as shown in the following responses:  
“I would appreciate formal education in this area, as often patients ask me about  
returning to driving or require reinforcement of recommendations provided by a doctor  
or OT.” R17 (SP) 
“… education to patients is hit and miss.” R19 (OT)  
“It feels as if everybody is unsure, especially GPs.” R51 (OT)

chunk_1448.text:
“It feels as if everybody is unsure, especially GPs.” R51 (OT) 
 
Doctors were perceived to be the health professionals most unclear about RTD processes and 
guidelines, and their education was seen as a priority, as shown in this response:  
“In my experience, doctors’ knowledge of their responsibilities in relation to driving has 
been very poor.” R20 (OT) 
“Sometimes doctors themselves don’t know they are able to clear patients to 
drive…More education to [the] GP…would be useful.” R23 (SP) 
140

chunk_1449.text:
There was also frustration for  those who correctly educate patients about their RTD but then 
have those recommendations ignored by other professionals, and reported avoidance of the 
issue, due to the uncertainty around processes, as shown in this response:  
“One of the greatest difficu lties we find with this is that recommendations regarding 
temporary cessation of driving pending medical clearance are not backed up by other 
team members despite the clear guidelines and mandatory reporting requirements for 
some professions. This leaves p atients confused and unsure of the correct information  
…. Return to driving post -stroke is a topic many health pro fessionals seem loath to 
touch.” R30 (OT) 
 
Deferring to others 
Health professionals wrote about often deferring to others, particularly doctors and 
occupational therapists, to make decisions about RTD, as reported by R40 (OT): “I often do not

chunk_1450.text:
occupational therapists, to make decisions about RTD, as reported by R40 (OT): “I often do not 
state the number of weeks …. Instead I advise them that they are unable to drive until cleared by 
their doctor and recommend that they discuss this with their rehab physician”; and as stated by 
R30 (OT): “[there is] ... a tendency for this job to fall to the occupational therapist”; and R10 (PT): 
“..majority of advice I give to patients about returning to driving just involves making sure they 
follow up with their Specialist or GP prior to returning to driving.”  
 
Patient uncertainty and inconsistency 
Respondents wrote that processes can be confusing for patients as they are left  not knowing 
what to do with regard to RTD and that adherence to driving restrictions may rely too heavily 
on poorly informed decisions made by the patient, as stated by R46 (OT): “… available patient 
information brochures are often in a language that is confusing for patients ”; and R56 (PT): 
141

chunk_1451.text:
“Return to driving currently relies too much on the client to be responsible. After stroke  … 
memory and insight can mean that people drive when they should not.”  
 
There were also conflicting comments about stroke sur vivors’ RTD, as reported by  R61 (CNS): 
“Stroke survivors drive without care about medical warnings” ; and R32 (OT): “ Most stroke 
survivors are happy not to drive for the recommended period of time.” 
 
Health professionals also wrote about current guidelines and processes not allowing for 
individual patient factors and the impact that can ha ve on RTD decision -making after stroke. 
Health professionals reported that, for patients with mild stroke or those who had previous 
comorbidities prior to stroke, RTD guidelines are not clear, as reported by R26 (OT): “The criteria 
for permanent or long term are confusing and tempting for patients, especially following a mild 
or recent stroke ”; and R18 (OT): “… many stroke survivors have comorbidities that are not

chunk_1452.text:
or recent stroke ”; and R18 (OT): “… many stroke survivors have comorbidities that are not 
necessarily considered.”  
 
5.3.3.2 Theme two: Responsibility 
Half (50%; n=30) of the respondents made comments pertaining to responsibility when 
managing RTD after stroke, and these were coded into three sub-themes:  
• Health professionals’ responsibility  
• Mandatory reporting 
• Driver assessment. 
 
142

chunk_1453.text:
Health professionals’ responsibility 
Respondents wrote about a general assumption that occupational therapists were the key 
health professionals responsible for educating stroke survivors on restrictions in driving after 
stroke and in assessing suitability for RTD after the restriction period, as reported by R9 (OT):“… 
I believe it is the OT’s role”; R14 (OT): “At our Stroke Unit, we [OT] are mandated to cover return 
to driving”; and R50 (PT): “The occupational therapist in my unit discusses driving with all stroke 
patients.”  
 
Doctors were identified as the other key health professional s. H owever, concerns were 
expressed about their involvement and how best to assess fitness to drive , as reported by R44 
(OT): “Doctors are too unclear about what their responsibility is and what advice should be given. 
So they tend to avoid the situation”; R7 (GP): “[Reliance on GPs to make decisions about a stroke

chunk_1454.text:
So they tend to avoid the situation”; R7 (GP): “[Reliance on GPs to make decisions about a stroke 
survivor’s ability to drive] imposes a ridiculous ethical and administrative burden on rural GP s”; 
R48 (OT): “I find it incredibly frustrating , though, how often GPs ‘sign’  off a patient as clear to 
drive despite our reported concerns to them” ; R16 (SP): “It is impossible to judge from seeing 
someone at a consult if they are capable of driving”; and R13 (NP): “I am a neuropysch. We are 
asked repeatedly to advise the rehab co nsultant on someone’s cognitive ability to RTD post -
stroke via our assessments despite our texts [assessment tools] not being devised or validated 
for RTD specifically.”  
 
There was a consensus among the occupational therapy respondents that the responsibility for 
managing RTD after stroke should be shared among all health professionals working with a 
stroke survivor , as reported by R51 (OT): “ I think all professionals working with clients who

chunk_1455.text:
stroke survivor , as reported by R51 (OT): “ I think all professionals working with clients who 
sustained strokes should receive adequate information as to what to tell the clients with regard 
143

chunk_1456.text:
to return to driving”; and R62 (OT): “This is an issue often left to OTs within teams but should be 
something that the whole multi-dis [multidisciplinary] team have knowledge and skill in.”  
 
Mandatory reporting 
Health professionals impacted by mandatory reporting, as in those working in South Australia 
and the Northern Territory, commented on the fact that current RTD guidelines and processes 
do not reflect mandatory r eporting requirements, as reported by R5 (OT): “… a lot of health 
professionals find this [mandatory reporting ] a difficult thing” ; and R39 (OT):  “… we have 
mandatory reporting … which is not always applied.”   
 
Respondents also commented on the impact mandatory reporting has on their patients who, as 
reported by R26 (OT): “… wish to recover and do not want to consider that their condition may 
be ongoing, so are initially quite reluctant to submit mandatory self-reporting forms.”

chunk_1457.text:
be ongoing, so are initially quite reluctant to submit mandatory self-reporting forms.” 
 
Respondents not impacted by mandatory reporting expressed concerns about this also, as 
reported by R47 (OT): “I feel that is a concern that reporting to the RTA [Road Traffic Authority] 
following a stroke is not mandatory”; and R28 (SP): “I would like to see the laws changed so that 
it is mandatory for the authorities to be informed whenever a licensed driver has a stroke.” 
 
Driver assessment 
Another issue raised by respondents related to the use of occupational therapy driving 
assessments to assist in decision-making as to whether a stroke survivor can return to driving, 
and concerns were raised about current and future access to this assessment, as reported by R9 
144

chunk_1458.text:
(OT): “… GPs are over-cautious and then recommend an OT driving assessment, which is often 
unnecessary and expensive”; R7 (GP): “We need easily accessible…driving testing officers…$500 
for a pensioner to do an OT assessment, so they [don’t] do it ”; and R25 (OT):  “I … provide 
information on private driving assessment options to my patients.”  
 
Concerns were identified by occupational therapy respondents about the future of occupational 
therapy driving assessments as they were perceived to be scarce or cost-prohibitive options for 
patients, as reported by R30 (OT): “There is also very limited access to comprehensive 
occupational therapy driving assessments in our region”; and R57 (OT): “There is a concern that 
funding will not support the occupational therapist driver assessment centres in the near future. 
Without this service, who  will assess people to determine their ability to safely operate a 
vehicle?” 
 
5.3.4 Discussion

chunk_1459.text:
vehicle?” 
 
5.3.4 Discussion 
This study revealed that Australian health professionals involved in the management of RTD 
after stroke reported uncertainty and inconsistencies for health professionals and patients alike, 
and that health professionals may be deferring to others , rather than manag ing this  issue 
themselves. Other concerns raised were the lack of RTD knowledge, education and resources 
for health professionals and patients, and confusion about who is responsible for educating and 
advising patients about RTD management. The overall result points to potential inconsistencies 
in the advice and  education about driving restrictions post-stroke that stroke survivors are 
receiving. 
 
145

chunk_1460.text:
5.3.4.1 Lack of knowledge 
Despite the availability of clinical guidelines that define recommended practices in the 
management of RTD after stroke (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016; National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010a), this study identified that Australian health professionals working in 
stroke are unclear about how to manage t he RTD process for patients with stroke and TIA. 
Austroads’ guidelines (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ) and the National 
Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management (National Stroke Foundation, 
2010a) include clearly stated recommendations related to survivors of stroke and TIA, and also 
recommend that all stroke survivors receive both verbal and written information on RTD 
restrictions prior to leaving hospital, be informed of their responsibility to notify the Driver 
Licensing Authority of their stroke, and be cleared by a medical practitioner prior to return to

chunk_1461.text:
Licensing Authority of their stroke, and be cleared by a medical practitioner prior to return to 
driving (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a). These guidelines have been put in place to support 
health professionals in their role of providing education to patients a bout driving after stroke  
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ). Yet the findings in this study indicate 
that knowledge of, and compliance with these guidelines is perceived as complex, confusing and 
inconsistent. The comments made by respondents regarding lack of knowledge reflect those in 
the qualitative data of the survey. Out of a total of 455 health professionals across Australia who 
completed the main survey, only 12% ( n=53) correctly answered both questions regarding 
restrictions in driving after TIA and stroke (Frith, James, Hubbard, & Warren-Forward, 2016a).  
 
This study finds that health professionals working in stroke are concerned about doctors’

chunk_1462.text:
This study finds that health professionals working in stroke are concerned about doctors’ 
potential lack of knowledge of RTD guidelines and process , a concern supported by previous 
studies. For example, Goodyear and Roseveare (2003) found that only 11% of doctors working 
within an acute hospital setting in the United Kingdom knew the RTD guidelines for stroke. 
146

chunk_1463.text:
This study identified a perception that occupational therapists and doctors have the primary 
responsibility for RTD management after stroke. While it is important for occupational therapists 
and doctors to be well-educated in the use of RTD guidelines (Batool, Roberts, Kaira, & 
Manawadu, 2014; Brooke & Southward, 2006; Goodyear & Roseveare, 2003; Jang et al., 2007; 
S. Marshall, Demmings, Woolnough, Salim, & Man -Son-Hing, 2012 ), it may be important for 
other health professionals to be educated in RTD management as they may have contact with 
patients recovering from stroke during professional contact at different phases of recovery. For 
example, in the acute hospital setting, only 50% of patients with stroke may see occupational 
therapists (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). If RTD education is  left to occupational 
therapists alone, the 50% of patients who do not see occupational therapists may be unaware

chunk_1464.text:
therapists alone, the 50% of patients who do not see occupational therapists may be unaware 
of driving restrictions after stroke and TIA. To ensure that all patients with stroke or TIA who  
own current driver’s licences are provided with RTD education that complies with the guidelines, 
this study support the Stroke Foundation’s (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ) 
recommendation that all health professionals working in stroke receive education on the 
management of RTD. 
 
5.3.4.2 Deferring responsibility 
Health professionals who mak e decisions or provide education about a patient’s ability to 
resume driving after stroke must be adequately informed, educated and resourced and, in turn, 
confident about fulfilling this responsibility (S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999). Even though Australia’s 
nationally-agreed clinical g uidelines recommend that all health professionals involved in the 
field of stroke have a responsibility to discuss RTD with stroke survivor s (National Stroke

chunk_1465.text:
field of stroke have a responsibility to discuss RTD with stroke survivor s (National Stroke 
Foundation, 2010a ), health professionals in this study  reported that some are defer ring to 
147

chunk_1466.text:
others, such as to GPs. This may be problematic, as GPs may be unaware of their assumed role 
in managing driving after stroke and/or uncertain about what advice and education they should 
be providing. According to the study by Jang et al. (2007) , 50% of GPs did not feel confident 
assessing fitness to drive or felt qualified to do so. There is also evidence that they may avoid 
discussing the issue of driving in order to preserve their relationships with their patients  (Jang 
et al., 2007; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999), or they may see it as a lower priority compared with 
the management of other health issues  (Liddle et al., 2014 ). To ensure that all patients with 
stroke or TIA who own current driver’s licences are provided with RTD education that complies 
with the guidelines, the authors of this study recommend the introduction of an integrated care 
plan which includes documentation about RTD after stroke and TIA.   
 
5.3.4.3 Mandatory reporting

chunk_1467.text:
plan which includes documentation about RTD after stroke and TIA.   
 
5.3.4.3 Mandatory reporting 
This study identified mandatory reporting as having an impact on health professionals’ 
adherence to RTD guidelines, particularly in those Australian States and Territories where this is 
a requirement. Respondents fel t that current RTD guidelines did  not support mandatory 
reporting requirements. Mandatory reporting was seen as a burden that negatively impacted 
adherence to RTD guidelines , and health professionals avoided discussing RTD with patients 
because of this.  Interestingly, health professionals who were not mandated to report concerns 
about a person’s ability to drive felt that mandatory reporting should occur and would result in 
increased compliance with RTD guidelines. As is the case in Australia, Canada  has differing 
mandatory reporting requirements across the country. In a cohort of Canadian doctor s, S.

chunk_1468.text:
mandatory reporting requirements across the country. In a cohort of Canadian doctor s, S. 
Marshall et al. (2012)  found differing views on mandatory reporting between those who were 
bound by them and those who were not. The clinical practices of doctors  were compared 
between areas with mandatory reporting requirements and areas where discretionary reporting 
was allowed. In the areas with mandatory reporting, fewer doctors assessed their patients’ 
148

chunk_1469.text:
ability to drive, and more doctors reported their patients’ inability to drive. The practice of doing 
fewer assessments in states with mandatory reporting was attributed to the perceived negative 
impact on the doctor -patient relationship and the doctors’ lack of education about assessing 
fitness to drive  (S. Marshall et al., 2012 ). The evidence indicates , therefore, that mandatory 
reporting may not necessarily ensure co mpliance with RTD guidelines after stroke  and that 
education on RTD guidelines is of greater importance . To reduce confusion and increase 
consistency, it is recommended that there be a nationally consistent approach to the mandatory 
reporting requirements related to stroke and TIA across Australia , applied irrespective of the 
State or Territory in which the person resides. 
 
5.3.5 Strengths and limitations 
These findings provide an in-depth investigation into Australian health professionals’ concerns

chunk_1470.text:
These findings provide an in-depth investigation into Australian health professionals’ concerns 
about RTD issues after stroke. However, these findings cannot be generalised to other countries. 
A limitation of this study is that only 70 participants of the survey’s 455 respondents provided 
additional comments. There was also a selection bias towards occupational therapists and those 
working in the Australian States of New South Wales and Queensland.    
 
5.3.6 Conclusion 
This study provided a “window” into the reported confusion, complexity and inconsistency that 
health professionals are experiencing in the management of RTD in stroke survivors. To manage 
this, health professionals may be reluctant to engage with this issue, may defer to other health 
professionals or may avoid it altogether.  This, in turn , is creating confusion for the stroke 
survivor in how to manage RTD. Education of health professionals in RTD guidelines is required

chunk_1471.text:
survivor in how to manage RTD. Education of health professionals in RTD guidelines is required 
to ensure all health professionals working throughout the continuum of stroke recovery are 
149

chunk_1472.text:
aware of the role they play in managing stroke survivors’ return to driving, regardless of stroke 
severity. 
 
5.4 Chapter synopsis 
This chapter presented quantitative and qualitative analyses of the results from a national 
survey of Australian health professionals’ knowledge and use of RTD guidelines. The studies 
revealed that health professionals lack knowledge about driving restrictions after stroke and are 
uncertain regarding who is responsible for managing RTD. Health professionals are deferring to 
others, with occupational therapists and general practitioners  being seen as the key health 
professionals involved in the management of RTD. As demonstrated in Chapters three and four, 
a practice-evidence gap has emerged in the use of RTD guidelines in the acute hospital setting . 
As a result, there are inconsistencies in the content and timing of education provided to stroke 
survivors. Chapters three, four and five have indicated a compelling need for an education

chunk_1473.text:
survivors. Chapters three, four and five have indicated a compelling need for an education 
strategy to be made available in Austroads’ guidelines and the National Stroke Foundation’s 
Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management regarding RTD, targeting all Australian health 
professionals working in the field of stroke. Chapter six presents the development, 
implementation and assessment of an electronic learning module on returning to driving after 
stroke.

chunk_1484.text:
Chapter 6 
 
Development and Implementation  
of an Electronic Learning Module 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Corresponding publication: Frith, J., Hubbard, I .J., James, C .J & Warren-Forward, H. (2017). In 
the Driver’s Seat: Development and implementation of an e -learning module on return -to-
driving after stroke. Occupational Therapy in Health Care . Accepted for publication March 14, 
2017. doi: 10.1080/07380577.2017.1307481 
156

chunk_1485.text:
6.1 Chapter overview 
The results of the previous studies presented in this thesis have revealed that clinical guidelines 
for the management of return to driving (RTD) after stroke may be inconsistent , as evidenced 
by the documentation about RTD education and management in patients with stroke and 
transient ischaemic attack (TIA) who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital 
setting. The findings also revealed that a contributing factor to this practice-evidence gap is the 
lack of knowledge of clinical guidelines by health professionals and the reported uncertainty 
regarding their roles and responsibilities. As a result, health professionals tend to defer the 
management of RTD to others , and persons with stroke and TIA are often left confused about 
how to manage their own RTD. While they may turn to their general practitioners for advice, the 
results of the studies have revealed that general practitioners may also lack the skills and

chunk_1486.text:
results of the studies have revealed that general practitioners may also lack the skills and 
experience to adequately manage RTD. The studies in this thesis so far indicate that a clinically-
accessible strategy is needed to educate health professionals on the management of RTD after 
stroke and TIA in order to bridge the practice -evidence gap and ensure that  all patients with 
stroke and TIA receive documented RTD management plan s prior to being discharged home 
from the acute hospital setting. This chapter presents a clinically -accessible strategy in the 
development and implementation of an electronic learning  module which provides evidence -
based education on RTD after stroke and TIA. 
 
6.2 Manuscript 
This manuscript is published as: Frith, J, Hubbard, IJ, James, CJ, Warren -Forward, H. (2017). In 
The Driver’s Seat: Development and implementation of an e -learning module on return -to-

chunk_1487.text:
The Driver’s Seat: Development and implementation of an e -learning module on return -to-
driving after stroke. Occupational Therapy in Health Care . Accepted for publication March 14, 
2017. doi: 10.1080/07380577.2017.1307481 
157

chunk_1488.text:
6.2.1 Abstract 
Gaps exist in the knowledge of return -to-driving guidelines for Australian health professionals 
working in stroke, and education is needed. In this article, authors evaluate the implementation 
of an e -learning module. Pre- and post -module knowledge test s and a survey were used to 
assess the e -module’s success in achieving its learning o bjectives. Initially, 204 learners 
completed the module with 68% scoring 100% in the post -module knowledge test. Only 12 
learners completed the survey. The authors recommend that health professionals other than 
occupational therapists access the e -module a nd that a review of the  e-module structure is 
required to improve results on the knowledge tests.  
 
6.2.2 In the driver’s seat: Development and implementation of an e-learning module on return-
to-driving after stroke  
Globally, stroke is the second leading  cause of death and the third leading cause of disability

chunk_1489.text:
Globally, stroke is the second leading  cause of death and the third leading cause of disability  
(World Health Organization, 2012 ). In the United States of America, approximately 795,000 
people will experience a stroke each year (Benjamin et al., 2017 ). One in six will experience a 
stroke in their lifetimes, with over 50% of new or recurrent strokes affecting those aged over 75 
years. In Australia, 65% of stroke survivors will have experienced a disability that impacts on 
their activities of daily living (ADL) (Senes, 2006). One of these ADLs is driving. 
 
Driving a motor vehicle involves a complex collaboration of motor, perceptual and cognitive 
skills (Delfosse, 2014; Klavora et al., 1995) as a person simultaneously interacts with the motor 
vehicle and the external environment (Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency, 2016). The deficits 
experienced following stroke can vary greatly (Klavora et al., 1995), and the ones that can impact

chunk_1491.text:
Akinwuntan et al., 2012; Korner-Bitensky et al., 2006). A deficit in one of these skills can impact 
the performance of another and therefore affect a person’s ability to efficiently operate a motor 
vehicle. As a result, a stroke survivor may need to be restricted in driving, either temporarily or 
permanently.  
 
Around the world, there are variances in the driving restrictions recommended for people who 
experience transient ischaemic attack (TIA) or stroke. In the United States of America, there is 
no mandated restriction in driving after TIA or stroke (American Geriatrics Society, 2016 ), 
whereas Canada has a one-month restriction after stroke. Canada also has no restriction for TIA 
(Canadian Medical Association, 2012). Both the United Kingdom (UK) and Australia have specific 
restrictions in driving after stroke and TIA. In the UK, there is a one-month restriction after stroke 
and between one and three months ’ restriction following TIA (Driver and Vehicle Lic ensing

chunk_1492.text:
and between one and three months ’ restriction following TIA (Driver and Vehicle Lic ensing 
Agency, 2016). Australian stroke survivors are restricted in driving a private vehicle for a period 
of four weeks after a stroke event. For those who experience TIA, the restriction period is two 
weeks. For commercial vehicles, the licensee is re stricted for three months after a stroke and 
four weeks after a TIA. For all stroke and TIA survivors, medical clearance is recommended prior 
to returning to driving (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016).  
 
The restriction period for stroke and  TIA is particularly important for stroke survivors who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting, as evidence indicates they are at risk 
of returning to driving within this restriction period and without clearance (Frith et al., 2015). In 
2015, an audit of Australian acute -stroke services revealed that only 44% of stroke  survivors

chunk_1493.text:
2015, an audit of Australian acute -stroke services revealed that only 44% of stroke  survivors 
discharged home from the acute hospital setting were provided with written care plan s at the 
time of discharge (National Stroke Foundation, 2015). A study conducted by Frith et al. (2017) 
159

chunk_1494.text:
revealed that only 35% of stroke survivors in an Australian acute-stroke unit had documented in 
their medical records that return -to-driving (RTD) education had been p rovided prior to 
discharge. Another study conducted by Frith et al. (2016a)  identified that health professionals 
working in stroke lacked knowledge of RTD guidelines and were confused as to whose 
responsibility it was to discuss RTD with stroke survivors. As a result, stroke survivors were either 
provided with inconsistent advice about returning t o driving, or health professionals defer red 
responsibility to others, creating further confusion for health professionals as well as stroke 
survivors themselves (Frith et al., 2016a). Consequently, one-third of stroke survivors will return 
to driving within the restriction period, with many approaching family and friends for advice not 
provided by health professionals (Frith et al., 2016a; Frith et al., 2017).

chunk_1495.text:
provided by health professionals (Frith et al., 2016a; Frith et al., 2017). 
 
The Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management (2010) recommend that all health professionals 
working in stroke have a responsibility to discuss RTD with stroke survivors. However, 
occupational therapists have been shown to have a specific role in the assessment and retraining 
of stroke survivors in the rehabilitation and community contexts (Allen et al., 2007; Finestone et 
al., 2010 ; Korner-Bitensky et al., 2006 ). Generally, an individual primary -care or general 
practitioner is relied on to assess fitness to drive and provide “medical clearance” for someone 
to return to driving (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ; Jang et al., 2007 ; S. 
Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ; White et al., 2012 ). While occupational therapists are more 
experienced with RTD g uidelines compared with other health professionals (McCluskey &

chunk_1496.text:
experienced with RTD g uidelines compared with other health professionals (McCluskey & 
Middleton, 2010), only 50% of stroke survivors are referred to occupational therapist s in the 
acute hospital setting (Biswas et al., 2006; Frith et al., 2017). Therefore, it is essential that other 
health professionals working in stroke assume greater responsibility in providing advice on 
driving restrictions after stroke and TIA, to ensure all stroke survivors receive this information.  
160

chunk_1497.text:
In order to achieve this, health professionals need to be educated on RTD guidelines as well as 
the role they can play in managing a stroke survivor’s return to driving.  
 
As well as Austroads ' guidelines, there exists the Clinical Guidelines for Stroke M anagement, 
which are evidence-based, nationally -agreed clinical guideline s developed by the Australian 
Stroke Foundation by a national expert working group and endorsed by the National Health and 
Medical Research Council (National Health and Medical Research Council, 2017). The section of 
the clinical guidelines entitled “Community Participation and Long Term Recovery” recommends 
that all patients discharged home from hospital be provided with written and verbal education 
on returning to driving after stroke. This education must include information on driving 
restrictions, as well as the stroke survivors’ responsibility to inform the State or Territory’s Driver

chunk_1498.text:
Licensing Agency of their medical conditions, and the implications for licensing and insurance if 
they fail to do so. An RTD management plan must be provided for the stroke survivor as part of 
the overall stroke care plan. Included in this management plan are the methods by which the 
stroke survivor will be cleared to return to driving at the end of the restriction period (National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010a). 
 
Despite the availability of Austroads’ guidelines (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 
2012) and the Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management (National Stroke 
Foundation, 2010a), there is a practice-evidence gap in their implementation (Frith et al., 2015; 
Frith et al., 2016a, 2016b; Frith et al., 2017). Evidence shows that health professionals working 
in stroke lack the knowledge and skills to adequately provide RTD education to patients and to

chunk_1499.text:
in stroke lack the knowledge and skills to adequately provide RTD education to patients and to 
assist in the clearance process. Also, health professionals are reluctant to broach the topic of 
driving with patients due to fear of repercussion s or uncertainly a bout mandatory reporting 
161

chunk_1500.text:
requirements (Frith et al., 2016a ; Jang et al., 2007 ; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ). However, 
evidence has suggested th at if stroke survivors are provided with education on driving 
restrictions, they are likely to be adhered to (Frith et al., 2017). To increase the likelihood that 
clinical practice aligns with the guidelines, targeted education for health professionals may be 
beneficial.  
 
Prior to 2016, there were no educational opportunities available in Australia that offered a 
comprehensive summary of both Austroads ’ guidelines (Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2012) and the Stroke Foundation’s guidelines (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a) 
on RTD after stroke or TIA. Therefore, in response to the literature, the authors developed an 
educational module on RTD after stroke, which was offered through the Stroke Foundation’s e-
learning platform. Thus, the purpose of this paper is to report on the development, piloting and

chunk_1501.text:
learning platform. Thus, the purpose of this paper is to report on the development, piloting and 
implementation of an e -learning module on RTD after stroke or TIA th at aimed to educate 
Australian health professionals. 
 
6.2.3 Development of the program 
Learning medium 
An e -learning or online learning format was selected to increase accessibility and economic 
viability for all Australian health professionals (Foroudi et al., 2010 ; Masters & Ellaw ay, 2008; 
Richardson, 2002). E-learning is described as the use of technology, largely the internet, to pre-
emptively provide education to be completed by the person in their own time and “out of sight” 
of the educator (Ellaway & Masters, 2008 ). It can be more accessible than face -to-face 
education, but still allow the learner to be actively involved, with the opportunity for the learner 
to obtain new information which is linked to their clinical experience (Kala, Isaramalai, & 
162

chunk_1502.text:
Pohthong, 2010 ). Self -reflective activities built into a learning environment can provide 
opportunities for learner s to test their understanding of new knowledge . This , in turn, can 
reinforce the key messages (Low, 2007 ). It is fast becoming a popular choice for health 
professionals’ continuing professional development (Reilly & Spratt, 2007), for example, in the 
education of nurses (Lewis, Davies, Jenkins, & Tait, 2005) and medical professionals (Ellaway & 
Masters, 2008).  
 
E-module objectives  
This e-learning module was developed to provide accessible education to health professionals 
and to increase the likelihood that stroke survivors discharged home, including those discharged 
from acute hospitals, receive information on RTD after stroke or TIA. To enhance clinical utility, 
the module was designed to have minimal impact on clinical time, taking approxim ately 30 
minutes to complete. Learning objectives of the e -module included being able to identify (a)

chunk_1503.text:
minutes to complete. Learning objectives of the e -module included being able to identify (a) 
when a patient diagnosed with a recent TIA may return to driving, (b) when a person diagnosed 
with a recent stroke may return to driving , (c) what the hea lth professional ’s role was in 
managing a patient’s RTD after stroke or TIA, and (d) the process to follow if concerns are 
identified about a person’s ability to return to driving after stroke.   
 
Development and Piloting of Content and Format 
A cognitive approach was undertaken when considering how to present the content of the e -
module. “Cognitivism” is a learning theory that emphasises the active involvement of the learner 
by the use of structure when presenting key information. The authors aimed to pres ent the 
concepts in a meaningful way to enable learners to organise and relate new information to 
existing knowledge (Ertmer & Newby, 1993). 
163

chunk_1504.text:
Available clinical guidelines on RTD after stroke , as well as peer -reviewed evidence on driving 
after stroke, were appraised. The e-learning module, entitled “Return to driving”, and its content 
were developed by JF and reviewed by co-authors, IH, CJ and HWF. The module highlighted the 
roles and responsibilities of each health professional in managing the return to driving for stroke 
survivors, regardless of the clinical setting or stage of recovery. It provided a succinct summary 
of RTD processes , combining the recommendations provided by Austroads ’ Fitness to Drive 
Guidelines for stroke and TIA (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2012 ) and the 
Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Strok e Management (National Stroke Foundation, 
2010a). It was divided into 8 sections (Table 6.1). This module was part of an already-established 
suite of e -learning modules that were freely available via the Stroke Foundation’s education

chunk_1505.text:
suite of e -learning modules that were freely available via the Stroke Foundation’s education 
platform on the InformMe (National Stroke Foundation, 2016) webpage. 
 
Table 6.1: The sections of the e-learning module 
Section Content 
1 Introduces the module and includes a prior knowledge test, statistics on road deaths and 
the impact of stroke on driving, and information about driving cessation and driving 
assessment. 
2 Introduces Austroads’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines for Commercial and Private Vehicle 
Drivers and the Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke, and provides a link to 
the Stroke Foundation’s clinical guidelines. The standards for licensing after stroke and 
TIA are covered in detail in a later section. 
3 Describes the different licences available in Australia and the responsibilities expected of 
health professionals, the driver and the Driver Licensing Agency in regard to managing 
licences. 
164

chunk_1506.text:
4 Details the restrictions imposed on stroke and TIA survivors for those who hold private 
licences and those who hold commercial licences 
5 Describes the assessment process involved in clearing a stroke survivor to return to 
driving at the end of the enforced restriction period. It explains the role of the general 
practitioner and occupational therapist in the assessment process. 
6 Explores the processes a health professional can go through if there are concerns about a 
person’s fitness to drive. 
7 Provides case studies to reinforce key learnings from other sections. The case studies 
provide examples of stroke or TIA survivors at various stages of recovery and differing 
severity. 
 
Once the content was drafted, the e-module was sent to the Stroke Foundation’s e-learning and 
resources coordinator to be uploaded and tested. The e-module was piloted with various health 
professionals, including a health academic researcher, a physiotherapist, a clinical nurse

chunk_1507.text:
professionals, including a health academic researcher, a physiotherapist, a clinical nurse 
specialist and an occupational therapist. The health professionals were chosen based on the fact 
they currently worked with stroke survivors and reported their knowledge of RTD guidelines to 
be limited. The reviewers were asked to complete the entire module and provide feedback on 
the general features of the e -module, e.g. ease of n avigation, hyperlink functionality, 
typographical or grammatical errors, design and layout, quality of content, relevanc e and 
appropriateness of learning assessments, and time for completion . In the  question, “Please 
provide any other relevant feedback that you would like to share”, the testers asked if there was 
a need for additional content or clarification of content. Information obtained from the pilot 
process was used to further inform the e-module. 
 
165

chunk_1508.text:
Module launch 
The e-learning module went “live” in September 2015, accompanied by an e-mail invitation to 
all health professionals on the list-serves of the State and Territory Stroke networks. Invitations 
were also sent via the following professional associations: Occupational Therapy Australia, the 
Australian Physiotherapy Association, Speech Pathology Australia, the Australian College of 
Nursing, the Australasian Faculty of Rehabilitation Medicine and the Rural Doctors Association 
of Australia. All recipients were encouraged to forward the invitation to their own networks and 
colleagues.  
 
Evaluation of the e-learning module 
The main evaluation tool used to assess whether the module’s objectives were being met were 
the pre- and post-module knowledge tests. The knowledge test was specifically aligned with the 
learning objectives , and the aim was to compare the results of the pre - and post -module

chunk_1509.text:
learning objectives , and the aim was to compare the results of the pre - and post -module 
knowledge test s. The six multiple -choice questions given to learners in the knowledge tests 
covered the following areas: (i) restriction periods following TIA for p rivate and commercial 
licences; (ii) restriction periods following stroke for private and commercial licences; (iii) details 
of RTD management plans ; and (iv) health professionals’ responsibilities regarding fitness  to 
drive. The authors also collected dat a such as the number who completed the module’s 
knowledge tests, the time spent doing the knowledge tests and the scores the learners achieved. 
The learner’s profession was not recorded. In the first 4 months after the module was launched 
(September 2015 to the end of January 2016), a link was embedded into the module , directing 
the learners to an additional survey on post -module behaviour change, hosted by

chunk_1510.text:
the learners to an additional survey on post -module behaviour change, hosted by 
SurveyMonkey. The additional survey contained seven fixed -response questions relat ed to 
learners’ dem ographic information and pre -module RTD clinical practice. A series of open -
response questions were also used to gather data on how long it took the learner to complete 
166

chunk_1511.text:
the module, three things the learner liked or disliked about the module, and what learnings were 
taken from completing the module. The data from this four -month period are reported in the 
results.  
 
6.2.4 Results 
Between September 2015 and January 201 6, 204 learners completed the module assessment, 
and 12 completed the additional survey. The mean time spent doing the post -module 
knowledge test was 15.7 seconds (range: 3 -360 sec onds). Of those who completed the 
assessment (Table 6.2), 68% (n=139) scored 100%. Seven (3%) learners ’ responses  were 
incorrect for restriction periods following TIA, and 8 (4%) learners’ responses were incorrect for 
stroke. The most common incorrect responses in the post-module knowledge test were on the 
questions related to commercial licensing standards for a person experie ncing a stroke (17%, 
n=35) and TIA (12%, n=24).

Of the 12 learners who completed the additional survey (Table 6.3), all were allied health 
professionals and nine were occupational therapists. Three worked in acute hospitals and 7 were 
based in New South Wales. Four had provided education to 1-2 stroke survivors in the last four

weeks and five had worked in their chosen field for over 10 years. The mean co mpletion time 
for the entire module for these 12 individuals was 33 minutes (range: 20 -60 min utes). 
Respondents valued the education about timeframes for restrictions in driving and the 
responsibilities of health professionals. They commented that the module was clear, concise and 
easy to understand. They suggested that the pre-module knowledge test be different from the 
post-module knowledge test, that more in -depth information be provided about occupational 
therapy driving assessment processes , and that more audio-visual engagement in the module

private licensing standards for stroke ( n=10). After completing the module, respondents 
indicated they were taking more responsibility ( n=8) in managing RTD after stroke, providing 
clearer information to patients ( n=4), and supplementing verbal information with written 
information.
