chunk_1517.text:
6.2.5 Discussion 
The e -learning module was the first of its kind in Australia and was reported by learners to 
provide clear and concise education to health professionals about RTD after stroke and TIA. This 
module has the potential to bridge the current practice -evidence gap in complianc e with the 
statements and recommendations defined by Austroads’ guidelines and the Stroke Foundation’s 
Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management. It was not possible to determine whether a 
behaviour change had occurred as a result of completing the “Return to driving” module or 
whether this had translated to improved care in the management of RTD. However, health 
professionals now have ready access to a 30 -minute online continuing professional 
development opportunity on the topic of RTD.   
 
The fact that so few participants completed the additional survey was of concern. The link to the 
additional survey was placed after the feedback section in the e -module and may have led to

chunk_1518.text:
additional survey was placed after the feedback section in the e -module and may have led to 
the learners not seeing this link. Unfortunately, this was not identified in the p ilot. This should 
be a consideration in the development of future online modules. Also, it was predominately 
occupational therapists who completed the additional survey, highlighting a potential pattern 
that occupational therapists may be the main users of  this e-module. Consideration should be 
made as to how to increase participation of other health professionals. 
 
A suggestion was made by a learner that the questions used in the post-module knowledge test 
be different from the ones used in the pre -module knowledge test. However, the knowledge 
tests were directly linked to the learning objectives of the e -module and were used as an 
evaluation tool. Thus, it was appropriate that the pre- and post- knowledge tests remained the

chunk_1519.text:
evaluation tool. Thus, it was appropriate that the pre- and post- knowledge tests remained the 
same.  While it was anticipated that learners would achieve 100% in the post-module knowledge 
170

chunk_1520.text:
test, this was not the case. The post -module knowledge test revealed that gaps remained in 
knowledge of RTD after stroke and TIA. Although the incorrect response rate was low for private 
driver standards (less than 5% each for stroke and TIA), it was higher for commercial driver 
standards. This may have implications for those who rely on commercial licences for paid work, 
considering that commercial licences have a longer restriction period after stroke and TIA. More 
consideration needs to be given to better educat ion of health professionals, particularly those 
working in acute hospitals and in the community, on the commercial licensing standards for 
stroke and TIA survivors. 
 
The learners who responded to the additional survey suggested that more audio-visual content 
be added to the e -module. About 30% of health professionals who completed the e -module 
scored less than 100% in the post -module knowledge test, a result that may  indicate the

chunk_1521.text:
scored less than 100% in the post -module knowledge test, a result that may  indicate the 
learners’ “cognitive load” was too high (Lau, 2014 ) and they were unable to retain key 
information. More experimentation with learning styles to enhance learners’ experiences 
through electronic learning is recommended.     
 
 Limitations 
A design flaw in the e -learning platform meant that the authors were unable to obtain results 
from the pre-module knowledge test and, therefore, unable to compare these with the results 
of the post-knowledge test. Additional enhancements to the e-module, scheduled for 2016, will 
rectify this problem. A further limitation was the number of learners completing the additional 
survey and the limited information collected on the health profession background of the learner.  
171

chunk_1522.text:
Future directions 
While the content of this e-module was based on Australian RTD guidelines, the concept could 
be adopted in other countries. For example, as the clinical guidelines in Canada and the United 
Kingdom both recommend a one-month restriction in driving after stroke, this e-module could 
be easily adapted  for use in these countries  (Canadian Medical Association, 2012 ; Driver and 
Vehicle Licensing Agency, 2016 ). However, in countries such as the United States of America, 
where there are no mandated restrictions in driving after stroke (American Geriatrics Society, 
2016), the e-module would need to be adapted to reflect this significant difference.  
The “Return to driving” e-learning module should continue to be promoted, given its promising 
findings. A specific strategy to encourage doctors to complete this module should become a 
focus, given that occupational therapists were the main users. It is also important that the w ay

chunk_1523.text:
focus, given that occupational therapists were the main users. It is also important that the w ay 
information is presented be reviewed, particularly information relevant to the key e -module 
learning objectives. Adding more audio -visual components, as well as utilising a “spaced 
repeating” learning style, where information stands out on its own and is repeated throughout 
the module (Lau, 2014), may enhance the learner’s retention of key information.  
In 2017, the Stroke Foundation will release a new set of clinical guidelines . Therefore, it will be 
important that the module be updated in response to any changes that have been made to the 
original 2010 guidelines. The same would apply if there are any changes to Austroads’ guidelines 
in the future. As the responsibility for RTD also falls with stroke sur vivors, their education in 
managing RTD after stroke or TIA needs to be considered. Educational resources targeted at

chunk_1524.text:
managing RTD after stroke or TIA needs to be considered. Educational resources targeted at 
stroke survivors are available through the Stroke Foundation’s consumer website , EnableMe 
(Stroke Foundation, 2016 ), which includes a fact sheet on d riving. If stroke survivors are 
172

chunk_1525.text:
encouraged to access information about driving restrictions after stroke, they will be more fully 
informed on what they should or should not be doing and why. Education targeting the stroke 
survivor could also take the form of an e-learning module, perhaps using the existing EnableMe 
platform. This two-pronged approach in educating both the health professional and the stroke 
survivor could promote better patient -centred care, integrated care and compliance with all 
recommendations and guidelines. In turn, this would better protect all members of the 
community, particularly those using Australia’s roads and motorways.  
 
 Conclusion 
The authors developed, implemented and evaluated an e -learning module aimed at providing 
health professionals in Australia with education on how to manage RTD after stroke. E-learning 
provides the opportunity to reach a larger number of health professionals , compared with

chunk_1526.text:
provides the opportunity to reach a larger number of health professionals , compared with 
traditional face -to-face methods . H owever, the authors learn ed that this e -learning module 
needs ongoing promotion to ensure targeted learners are being reached. Occupational 
therapists appeared to be the main users of the e -learning module. The Stroke Foundation’s 
Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management recommend that all health professionals be involved 
in RTD after stroke. Therefore, health professionals other than occupational therapists need to 
be encouraged to complete the e-learning module. The authors found that the use of pre - and 
post e-learning knowledge tests can help identify gaps in learning to ensure the learning module 
achieves its objectives. Despite this e -learning module targeting health professionals working 
with stroke survivors in an Australian context, with adaptation, this e -learning module has 
potential for clinical utility in other countries.

chunk_1527.text:
potential for clinical utility in other countries.  
 
  
173

chunk_1537.text:
6.3 Chapter synopsis 
This chapter presented the development and implementation of an electronic learning (e -
learning) module on the management of RTD after stroke. It is available via the Stroke 
Foundation’s InformMe website (Figure 6.1 ) for all health professionals working in stroke in 
Australia.  
 
Figure 6.1 Return to driving e-learning module 
 
The initial results of the post-module-completion knowledge test revealed there were still gaps 
in the knowledge of commercial licensing standards follow ing stroke and TIA, and a review of 
the e-learning module is needed to ensure the learning objectives continue to be met (Frith et 
al., in press) . As identified previously, the role occupational therapists play in the management 
of RTD in the acute hospital setting is highlighted. However, local doctors also play an essential 
179

chunk_1538.text:
role once the patient with stroke and TIA is discharged home from the acute hospital setting 
(Frith et al., 2017). There is a need to continually promote the e -learning module to ensure all 
stroke-related health professionals, particularly local doctors, complete it. The development and 
implementation of the e -learning module has translated evidence into practice by providing 
health professionals with evidence -based education on how to manage RTD after stroke and 
TIA. This was not previously available to health professionals in Australia.  
 
This thesis identified a practice -evidence gap in the management of RTD in the acute hospital 
setting for patients with stroke and TIA. This gap was researched and a solution was 
implemented to translate evidence into practice. Chapter seven will draw toge ther the key 
findings from the four studies presented in this thesis , explore the clinical implications for the 
management of RTD, and provide recommendations for future research.

chunk_1539.text:
management of RTD, and provide recommendations for future research.

chunk_1542.text:
7.1  Introduction 
After a person experiences a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) or stroke, there are two-week and 
four-week restrictions in driving respectively (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 
2016). The Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management recommend that 
those with stroke and TIA receive both verbal and written information regarding the 
management of return to driving (RTD) (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a). People who have 
mild stroke and whose impairments do not warrant further inpatient rehabilita tion need to 
receive RTD management plans prior to discharge home from the acute hospital setting. There 
is little evidence regarding how well RTD is managed in the acute hospital setting. In the absence 
of this evidence, concerns exist as to whether strok e and TIA survivors are receiving education 
about restrictions in driving and , in turn, are able to make informed decisions about RTD. This

chunk_1543.text:
about restrictions in driving and , in turn, are able to make informed decisions about RTD. This 
means that those with recent stroke or TIA may be driving motor vehicle s in contravention of 
current recommendations.  
This thesis explored the management of RTD in patients with stroke and TIA who were 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting. The research conducted as part of this 
thesis contributes new knowledge regarding how education about driving restrictions after 
stroke and TIA are managed (or not managed, as the case may be) in the acute hospital setting 
and how this education impacts the return to driving of the person with TIA or stroke. This new 
knowledge was translated into the development of an electronic learning module which aimed 
to educate health professionals about the clinical guidelines and legislation concerning RTD after 
stroke and TIA. 
183

chunk_1544.text:
A literature review (Chapter two) identified inconsistencies in the provision of RTD education for 
stroke survivors in a rehabilitation context and the fact that their local doctors are often relied 
upon to advise them on their ability to drive. The research then asked six questions regarding 
RTD after stroke and TIA for those discharged home from the acute hospital setting. A systematic 
review, a medical record audit (Appendix 1) and a patient survey (Appendix 2), a national survey 
of Australian health professionals  (Appendix 3), and an electronic learning module were the 
methods used to answer these questions. Table 7.1 summarises the answers to the six research 
questions and the key data supporting the findings. The systematic review (Chapter three) 
revealed a lack of research into the management of RTD in patients discharged from the acute 
hospital setting. It captured only three studies , which were all based in the United Kingdom. It

chunk_1545.text:
hospital setting. It captured only three studies , which were all based in the United Kingdom. It 
also revealed that occupational therapists play a key role in the provision of education on driving 
restrictions prior to discharge from the acute inpatient setting (Frith et al., 2015). 
 
 
184

chunk_1554.text:
In response to the findings of the systematic review, an audit of documentation (Chapter four) 
in the inpatient medical records regarding RTD management plans was conducted for patients 
with stroke or TIA who were discharged directly home from one acute hospital setting. Following 
discharge, this same cohort was sent an anonymous survey about their recall of education 
provided about RTD and their RTD behaviours (Appendix 2). The findings of the audit and survey, 
contained in the first Australian study  of its kind,  provided evidence that RTD is not well -
managed in this acute hospital setting. In response to the audit and survey findings, a national 
survey on the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines was conducted with health professionals 
working in the field of stroke across Australia (Appendix 3) (Chapter five). The results from the 
analysis of quantitative and qualitative data identified  that health professionals are uncertain

chunk_1555.text:
analysis of quantitative and qualitative data identified  that health professionals are uncertain 
about their role s and responsibilities regarding the management of RTD after stroke and that 
health professionals defer to others to manage RTD. 
 
When the findings of all three studies are combined, the picture that emerges is one of 
inconsistencies in clinical practice , with health professionals working with Australian survivors 
of stroke and TIA need ing education about, and ready a ccess to, Austroads’ and the Stroke 
Foundation’s guidelines about RTD after stroke. In the translational component of this thesis 
and in response to the combined findings of the three studies, an initiative has been developed 
and implemented that provides a freely-available electronic learning module on RTD to all health 
professionals working in stroke in Australia (Chapter six). Again, this is another Australian -first

chunk_1556.text:
initiative. The e -module, entitled “Return to driving ”, is available via the Stroke Found ation’s 
website and on its “InformMe” website. This website is specially designed to meet the 
educational needs of Australian health professionals who have an interest in stroke.    
189

chunk_1557.text:
7.2  Key findings 
The provision of education on restrictions in driving , and RTD management plans , in patients 
with stroke and TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting is not well-
managed. Here are the key findings of this thesis: 
1. Return to driving may not be well-managed in the acute hospital setting 
2. Stroke survivors are more likely to adhere to driving restrictions if informed about them 
3. Health professionals are deferring responsibility in managing RTD after stroke to others 
4. An electronic e-learning module may translate evidence into practice. 
 
7.2.1 Return to driving may not be well-managed in the acute hospital setting 
This thesis generated new knowledge demonstrating that only 1 in 2 stroke survivors may be 
receiving education on RTD through standard care in the acute hospital setting. The  literature 
review revealed inconsistencies in the provision of RTD advice for stroke survivors in a

chunk_1558.text:
review revealed inconsistencies in the provision of RTD advice for stroke survivors in a 
rehabilitation context, raising concerns about the management of RTD in the acute setting. Fisk 
et al. (1997) conducted a study 20 years ago and revealed that in a cohort of 290 stroke survivors 
who received rehabilitation in an American rehabilitation centre, only 50% were provided with 
education on RTD. The results of this thesis provide new knowledge that, regardless of whether 
a stroke survivor only has an acute admission or, due to the severity of their stroke, progresses 
through a rehabilitation program, only half in the research setting received advice from a health 
professional about RTD. This evid ence indicates that for at least 20 years, little has changed in 
the management of RTD after acute stroke and TIA. In their study of 22 community -dwelling 
stroke survivors, White et al. (2012)  recommended that due to the value placed on driving by

chunk_1559.text:
stroke survivors, White et al. (2012)  recommended that due to the value placed on driving by 
stroke survivors, education on the management of RTD should commence as early as the acute 
phase post-stroke. However, the results of this thesis reveal ed that this is still not happening 
190

chunk_1560.text:
consistently. This thesis also revealed that an acute-care patient with stroke or TIA is more likely 
to receive education on RTD if seen by an occupational therapist. The literature review revealed 
that occupational therapy has a well-documented role in the management of RTD after stroke, 
particularly in the assessment and retraining of stroke survivors with impairments that impact 
their ability to drive. A study by McCluskey and Middleton (2010)  revealed that occupational 
therapists are more likely to be aware of RTD guidelines. This thesis provides evidence that, 
compared with other health professionals, Australian occupational therapists are more likely to 
discuss RTD with stroke survivors, in both acute and rehabilitation contexts.   
 
7.2.2 Stroke survivors are more likely to adhere to driving restrictions if informed about 
them  
A review of the literature revealed that up to one-third of survivors of st roke or TIA who are

chunk_1561.text:
A review of the literature revealed that up to one-third of survivors of st roke or TIA who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting will return to driving (Allen et al., 2007; 
Lee et al., 2003 ; Tan et al., 2011 ). This is more likely to occur in those with milder functional 
impairments (Fisk et al., 2002; Fisk et al., 1997). However, the research conducted as part of this 
thesis indicates that 60% (almost twice as many) of acute patients with stroke or TIA who were 
driving prior to their stroke and were discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting 
will return to driving (Frith et al., 2015 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). As hypothesised, this novel finding 
indicates that those who are discharged directly home from the acute setting after stroke are 
more likely to return to driving than those who are discharged from the sub -acute setting. Of 
the  acute-care cohort in this thesis, approximately 60% waited four weeks before returning to

chunk_1562.text:
the  acute-care cohort in this thesis, approximately 60% waited four weeks before returning to 
driving (Frith et al., 2015; Frith et al., 2017). This finding is encouraging as it demonstrates that 
survivors are concerned about the impact th at stroke or TIA has had on their driving ability. 
Another finding from this thesis is t hat those who return to driving within a month are more 
likely to be men (Frith et al., 2017). This new knowledge could guide health professionals when 
191

chunk_1563.text:
selecting effective strategies and developing evidence -based processes to manage RTD in the 
acute hospital s etting. It has significant implications for clinical practice and needs to be 
considered when protocols are being developed to better manage RTD in the acute hospital 
setting.  
 
7.2.3 Health professionals are deferring responsibility for the management of return to 
driving after stroke to others  
Health professionals are devolving the responsibility to provide education to patients with 
stroke or TIA and to manage their RTD to either occupational therapists or doctors. The literature 
indicates that occupational therapists have an established role in the assessment and retraining 
of stroke survivors’ RTD (Korner-Bitensky et al., 2006) and that they are more likely to be aware 
of RTD guidelines (McCluskey & Middleton, 2010). The research conducted for this thesis implies 
that occupational therapists have assumed a role in the management of RTD after stroke across

chunk_1564.text:
that occupational therapists have assumed a role in the management of RTD after stroke across 
the entire spectrum of stroke recovery (Frith et al., 2015; Frith et al., 2016a; Frith et al., 2017), 
but the issue is that in the acute hospital setting, only 50% of stroke or TIA survivors will see 
occupational therapists (Frith et al., 2015 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). These results significantly impact 
clinical practice because they highlight the possibility that, for acute inpatients in Australia , 
adhering to clinical guidelines may not be consistently achievable if there is ongoing reliance on 
occupational therapists to manage RTD after stroke and TIA.  
Once the stroke or TIA patient is discharged home from the acute hospital setting, management 
of RTD is transferred to the local doctor. The literature review revealed that doctors may lack 
the skills and experience to manage RTD after stroke (Jang et al., 2007 ; S. Marshall & Gilbert,

chunk_1565.text:
the skills and experience to manage RTD after stroke (Jang et al., 2007 ; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 
1999) and can even avoid the issue in order to maintain therapeutic relationships with patients 
(Liddle et al., 2014; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ). However, in the absence of other solutions, 
local doctors may need to be more proactive , as stroke and TIA survivors may no longer have 
192

chunk_1566.text:
contact with any othe r health professionals once discharged from the acute hospital setting. 
This also has implications for the safety of local families and communities if stroke survivor s 
unknowingly return to driving at a time when they are potentially putting others at risk . 
Therefore, strategies need to be implemented to better support local doctors in this role  in 
Australia. 
 
7.2.4 An electronic learning module may translate evidence into practice  
The development of the electronic learning (e-learning) module through the Stroke Foundation 
was the first of its kind in Australia and is proving successful in translating evidence into practice 
for the management of RTD after stroke. The preliminary findings of the e -module revealed 
improvements to knowledge about RTD after stroke, b ut a lack of knowledge of commercial 
licensing standards after stroke and TIA. There are very few studies on the management of RTD

chunk_1567.text:
licensing standards after stroke and TIA. There are very few studies on the management of RTD 
after stroke and TIA for those who own Commercial Driver’s licences (Rabadi et al., 2010). More 
research is recommended in the field of commercial driving standards  and RTD management 
after stroke.  
 
7.3   Clinical implications  
7.3.1 Clinical practice in the acute setting 
Clinical practice in the acute hospital setting needs to change to ensure that everyone with a 
Private and/or Commercial Driver’s licence who is diagnosed with stroke or TIA receives 
education on the nationally-agreed clinical guidelines for the management of RTD after stroke 
and TIA and that this education is easily recalled. If the clinical practice of RTD management in 
the acute hospital setting does not change, this has significant implications for various groups of 
people:  
193

chunk_1568.text:
(i) The health professional: Failure to take responsibility for the management of RTD 
after stroke and TIA has implications for the health professional’s duty of  care 
(Marshall et al., 2012 ). A lack of documentation in medical records regarding the 
provision of education on dri ving restrictions after stroke and TIA , and a n RTD 
management plan, may leave individual health professionals and/or health services 
liable in the event of a survivor of stroke or TIA being involved in a motor vehicle 
incident at a time  when he or she was not supposed to be driving. In most States 
and Territories in Australia this is, at present, an ethical issue only . H owever, in 
South Australia and the Northern Territory, where there is mandatory reporting, this 
may be a legal issue (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016).  
 
(ii) The stroke/TIA survivor: In Australia, if survivors of stroke and TIA are not aware of

chunk_1569.text:
(ii) The stroke/TIA survivor: In Australia, if survivors of stroke and TIA are not aware of 
their responsibilities when managing RTD, there are potential implications relating 
to driver’s licences and vehicle  insurance. The survivor s have a responsibility to 
inform the licensing authorities of their medical condition and need to receive 
medical clearance prior to returning to driving  (Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2016). If survivors of stroke and TIA fail to do either of these and if they 
are subsequently involved in a motor vehicle accident, their licence and insurance 
may be invalidated (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016). This may 
have long -term ramifications for stroke survivor s who wish to continue driving.  
However, perhaps more importantly, they are potentially putting others at risk of 
harm. Conversely, a lack of education and RTD management plans for stroke and

chunk_1570.text:
harm. Conversely, a lack of education and RTD management plans for stroke and 
TIA patients may result in survivors being restricted in driving longer than required, 
thus having implications for the drivers’ confidence, activities of daily living and 
occupational roles.  
194

chunk_1571.text:
(iii) The road user : If health professionals and/or survivors of stroke or TIA do not
adequately manage RTD, there are potentially harmful implications for other road
users. If a stroke survivor is driving on the road when he or she is not medica lly fit
to do so, this places others at risk of motor vehicle incidents and harm from other
road users (Fisk et al., 1997 ). Improved practice  in the management of RTD after
stroke and TIA would not only reduce the risk of harm in survivors of stroke or TIA;
it would also reduce the risk of harm in the community of road users.
As demonstrated in this thesis, an element important for the management of RTD after 
stroke or TIA is the recall of education provided in the acute hospital setting. The Stroke 
Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management recommend that the stroke or TIA 
patient receive written as well as verbal information on RTD. Therefore, the clinical practice

chunk_1572.text:
patient receive written as well as verbal information on RTD. Therefore, the clinical practice 
in the provision of written education needs to be improved. A “Driving Fact Sheet” on the 
management of RTD after stroke and TIA is already available from the Stroke Foundation. 
While this three-page fact sheet provides a useful overview of driving after stroke and TIA, 
it does not indicate the recommended driving restrictions. 
A recommendation from this thesis is that processes should be put in place within the 
hospital system to ensure that all patients with stroke or TIA who are discharged home from 
the acute hospital setting receive, in writing, information about the restriction periods after 
stroke or TIA and information about managing their RTD. A possible solution, authored by 
one of the researchers (JF), is the use of an RTD “Traffic Light” card which has a clear, concise 
summary o f the driving restriction timeframes, complementing the Driving  after Stroke 
195

chunk_1573.text:
factsheet. Figure 7.1 is an example of what the RTD Traffic Light card could look like. In this 
example, it is a two-sided postcard-sized card that could be placed on a person’s refrigerator 
as a highly visual reminder of the driving restriction timeframe. 
Figure 7.1 Return-to-driving Traffic Light card 
Another aspect of ensuring consistent clinical practice is to implement a reliable process 
outlining the steps health profession als working in the acute hospital setting (emergency 
department or acute inpatient ward) must follow to ensure patients with stroke and TIA 
receive RTD management plan s prior to discharge home. Figure 7.2 outlines a 
recommended process. 
196

chunk_1576.text:
7.3.2  Local doctors 
Local doctors (also known in Australia as general practitioners) have a key role  in the 
management of RTD after stroke and TIA and are involved in the process of providing clearance 
to return to driving. To adequately fulfil this role, greater supp ort should be provided to local 
doctors to ensure they gain the skills and expertise required to appropriately assist a stroke or 
TIA survivor through the transition back to driving. An important element of this support is the 
education of local doctors on RTD clinical guidelines. The electronic learning module, which was 
an outcome of this thesis, forms part of the educational support. However, as already identified, 
ongoing promotion is required to ensure health professionals involved with stroke  and TIA 
survivors access the module. Local doctors are one of the key health professionals who would 
benefit from accessing this e-learning module.

chunk_1577.text:
benefit from accessing this e-learning module. 
Many stroke survivors come under the care of neurologists while in hospital, but upon discharge, 
the remainder of their care is placed in the hands of local doctors. The local doctor may receive 
a detailed medical discharge summary following the hospital admission of the patient. However, 
in order for the local doctor to adequately assess a person’s fitness  to drive, greater 
collaboration between the local doctor and the acute hospital treating team needs to occur (Van 
Walraven, Seth, Austin, & Laupacis, 2002 ). A detailed account of the impairments experienced 
during the acute admission, as well as details of the RTD management plan, need to form part 
of a discharge summary from the acute hospital. This currently is not part of the medical 
discharge summary. Modifications to the medical discharge summary to prompt the hospital 
doctor to provide details about the RTD plan may need to occur. Allied health professionals who

chunk_1578.text:
doctor to provide details about the RTD plan may need to occur. Allied health professionals who 
have seen the patient possess important information regarding the impairments the stroke or 
TIA patient was experiencing during the hospital admission. This important information needs 
to be conveyed to the local doctor upon discharge as this could help the doctor make decisions 
198

chunk_1579.text:
about the ability of the person with stroke or TIA to return to driving. Improved processes are 
required to ensure that the allied health professionals assessing patie nts in hospital have the 
opportunity to hand over their clinical findings to local doctors.    
7.3.3 Clinical guidelines 
Currently, the Stroke Foundation’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke have a small section on RTD that 
is contained in Chapter 8, “Community Par ticipation and Long Term Recovery ”. While the 
guidelines outline the driving restrictions after stroke and TIA, the placement of these guidelines 
at the rear of the document provides a possible perception that RTD is a longer-term issue. This 
perception fails to highlight the fact that this is an issue in the acute phase of the stroke or TIA 
survivor’s journey and misrepresents its relevance to health professionals working in acute care. 
Return to driving needs to feature more prominently in the Stroke Foun dation’s guidelines

chunk_1580.text:
Return to driving needs to feature more prominently in the Stroke Foun dation’s guidelines 
related to acute care and provide specific recommendations on how mild stroke survivors are 
cleared to return to driving at the end of the restriction period. The Stroke Foundation’s Clinical 
Guidelines for Stroke Management were under review in late 2016. Feedback was provided by 
the author of this thesis on the need to include RTD management plans into acute -care plans, 
and the updated guidelines are expected to be released in July 2017. 
199

chunk_1581.text:
7.4   Future research 
This thesis has identified four needs for future research. These are outlined below. 
7.4.1 Return-to-driving assessment process for local doctors 
This thesis identified that local doctors may be ill -equipped to provide clear and consistent 
recommendations on RTD after stroke or TIA. Currently, there are limited appropriate, evidence-
based assessment tool s available to local doctors who see patients in their own surgeries to 
assess fitness to drive. Future research should develop and evaluate the implementation of an 
office-based assessment tool to enable local doctors to adequately assess a person’s suitability 
to return to driving following stroke or TIA, as well as provide training in the use of existing tools. 
This tool would need to incorporate the person’s driving history, the impairments present during 
the acute hospital admission, and assessment of any residual neurological impairments and their 
impact on the driving task.

chunk_1582.text:
impact on the driving task.  
7.4.2 Return-to-driving education for stroke and transient ischaemic attack survivors 
The e-learning module on RTD after stroke and TIA , targeting health professionals, has proven 
useful in translating evidence into practice. In order to empower the stroke or TIA survivor to 
take control of his or her own recovery and make informed decisions about RTD, an e -learning 
module about RTD, targeting stroke and TIA survivors, is recommended. This module could be 
made available via the Stroke Foundation’s EnableMe website. As identified in this thesis, 
survivors often turn to family and friends for advice related to driving; thus, the content of this 
module should also be available to friends, families and carers of people with stroke and TIA.  
200

chunk_1583.text:
7.4.3 Driving performance after acute stroke or transient ischaemic attack 
For those stroke survivors who appear to have a complete resolution of impairments at the time 
of discharge from hospital, there is no existing evidence of the effects on driving performance 
during the transition from acute inpatient to community -dwelling acute -stroke survivor. 
Therefore, further research is required to ascertain to what extent driving ability is impaired for 
the person with stroke or TIA for whom there appears to be complete resolution of impairment 
and who is discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting. The results of this research 
would then inform clinical guidelines and legislation regarding restrictions in driving after acute 
stroke and TIA.  
 
7.4.4 A national approach to the implementation of clinical guideline recommendations 
The Austroads’ (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016) and Stroke Foundation’s

chunk_1584.text:
The Austroads’ (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016) and Stroke Foundation’s 
clinical guidelines for RTD after stroke and TIA (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a) are national 
guidelines representing the whole of Australia. However, Australia’s DLA are governed by each 
individual State or Territory. As revealed throughout this thesis, there already exists differences 
in RTD management across these States and Territories  in mandatory reporting requirements 
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016), therefore differences in how each State 
and Territory implement s these guidelines  may exist . To increase compliance with the 
nationally-agreed guidelines, a national and integrated approach needs to be applied to ensure 
that management of RTD after stroke and TIA is consistent across the entire patient cohort. This 
would reduce variances in the clinical management of people with stroke or TIA and would

chunk_1585.text:
would reduce variances in the clinical management of people with stroke or TIA and would 
equate to a stroke or TIA survivor receiving the same advice and RTD management plan 
regardless of where he or she resides within Australia. 
 
201

chunk_1586.text:
7.5   Limitations 
As the focus of this thesis was on patients with stroke who are discha rged directly home from 
the acute hospital setting, some findings cannot necessarily be applied across the entire 
continuum of stroke care. The research for this thesis was conducted in a country where there 
are nationally-agreed recommendations limiting RTD after stroke or TIA. Other research would 
need to be undertaken to assess what does or does not occur in countrie s where there are no 
nationally-agreed recommendations. This thesis identified that the key roles and responsibilities 
in the management of RTD after stroke and TIA fall to occupational therapists and doctors, and 
these professions were well -represented among the study respondents . However, what 
requires further investigation is whether they are the right professions to be managing RTD, and 
why.  
7.5.1 Study design 
Due to the anonymous nature of the patient survey presented in Chapter four, the results of the

chunk_1587.text:
Due to the anonymous nature of the patient survey presented in Chapter four, the results of the 
medical record audit (Appendix 1) were not able to be linked with the results of the patient 
survey (Appendix 2). If this study were to be replicated in the future, consideration would need 
to be given to linking each individual audit with each patient survey.   
During the implementation of the e-learning module, two design flaws became apparent. Firstly, 
the e -learning platform used was not able to retain data from the pre -module completion 
knowledge test. Therefore, a comparative analysis of the pre - and post -module completion 
knowledge tests could not occur. Secondly, the additional survey was located at the end of the 
e-module and was  not well sign-posted. This may have contributed to the low response rate.
Such learnings are beneficial for the development of future electronic learning modules. 
202

chunk_1588.text:
7.5.2 Sample size and recruitment 
The medical record audit was conducted at only one site, a regional hospital in New South Wales, 
Australia. T herefore, the results may not be transferrable to other inpatient facilities where 
patients with stroke and TIA are treated. In order to draw firm conclusions about research 
questions on e and two, a study design involving multiple sites across Australia needs to be 
considered. Considerations for the selection of multiple sites would include equal 
representation across all States and Territories, recruitment of subjects in hospitals that h ave 
acute stroke units and hospitals without them, and equal representation of regional, rural and 
metropolitan areas. 
 
The sample size for the anonymous patient survey was low, with a possible bias to wards those 
who had adhered to the advice provided whil e in hospital. This bias could have resulted in an 
inaccurate representation of the RTD behaviours of persons with stroke and TIA recently

chunk_1589.text:
inaccurate representation of the RTD behaviours of persons with stroke and TIA recently 
discharged from the acute hospital setting. Therefore, future studies would need to consider 
ways to increase the response rate as well as remove any bias from the survey sample. Methods 
include sending reminders to complete the survey, offering interviews over the phone or in 
person (Pit, Vo, & Pyakurel, 2014), and even offering incentives to complete the survey, such as 
entry into a prize draw (Cho, Johnson, & Vangeest, 2013).  
 
There was a bias towards health professionals in the States of New South Wales and Queensland 
completing the national survey, as well as a bias towards occupational therapists. Therefore, the 
results may not reflect health professionals other than occupational therapists , or those who 
reside in other States and Territories in Australia. In order to remove these biases and obtain

chunk_1590.text:
reside in other States and Territories in Australia. In order to remove these biases and obtain 
increased clarity regarding the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines among Australian health 
professionals, future studies need to have increased representation from the remaining States 
203

chunk_1591.text:
and Territories of Australia. Ways to achieve this may include a “travelling roadshow” which 
involves intensive local promotion of the survey to health professionals at local health facilities 
and conferences, as well as hosting of forums.  
7.6 Conclusion 
The findings of this thesis provide new knowledge demonstrating that the provision of education 
on restrictions in driving, and RTD management plans, for patients with stroke and TIA who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting are not well-managed. They indicate 
that half of the patients with stroke or TIA may be discharged home without having received any 
documented education on restrictions in driving after stroke and , even more  concerning, 
without documented RTD management plan s. The risk of this occurring was lessened if they 
were seen by an occupational therapist, had a document ed cognitive impairment , and were

chunk_1592.text:
were seen by an occupational therapist, had a document ed cognitive impairment , and were 
male. Three out of every five patients who were diagnosed with a recent mild stroke or TIA and 
who recalled receiving education on driving restrictions while inpatient s waited at least four 
weeks before driving. Whether the management of returning to driving after stroke should fall 
to occupational therapists and doctors is yet to be adequately established . H owever, it is  
imperative that whoever takes on this task is fully educated on the advice and recommendations 
they should be providing. One means of doing this is a readily accessible, nationally available 
learning module, as this thesis has demonstrated such a module can effectively educate health 
professionals working with patients diagnosed with stroke or TIA.  
The results of this thesis provide evidence that RTD after stroke is not only an issue for those

chunk_1593.text:
The results of this thesis provide evidence that RTD after stroke is not only an issue for those 
who have already been discharged home, but also is  an issue that has significant clinical 
relevance for health professionals working in acute st roke management. In f uture, strategies 
need to be developed and implemented to ensure that all patients with stroke and TIA, who are 
204

chunk_1594.text:
discharged home from the acute hospital setting, receive nationally -recommended education 
on driving restrictions and RTD management plans. To do otherwise places entire communities 
of road users at potential risk of harm.  
 
  
205

The skills required to maintain control of a motor vehicle can be affected by stroke. 
If, as a result of your participation in this study, you have concerns about your 
ability to drive, you should discuss these immediately with your GP and/or treating 
specialist. Every driver has a legal obligation to report permanent or long term 
injury or illness that can adversely affect their ability to drive, to the Driver License 
Authority. For more information on returning to driving following illness please 
contact the Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) on 13 22 13 or www.rta.nsw.gov.au; 
or  Australian and New Zealand Road Transport and Traffic Authorities (Austroads)

chunk_1614.text:
You are invited to participate in an anonymous on­line survey which is part of the research project Shifting Gears: 
Returning to Driving After Stroke. It is being conducted by Janet Frith, an Occupational Therapist in the Hunter New 
England Local Health District. It is part of Janet's research higher degree program at the University of Newcastle and 
is supervised by Associate Professor Helen Warren­Forward, Dr Carole James and Ms Isobel Hubbard from the 
University of Newcastle. 
This survey aims to investigate the knowledge that health professionals have about the nationally legislated and 
recommended clinical guidelines concerning return­to­driving following stroke. 
If you would like a copy of the study information sheet, please contact Janet Frith via 
janet.frith@hnehealth.nsw.gov.au. 
Thank you for taking the time to complete this survey.

returning to driving after stroke?

chunk_1638.text:
Returning to driving post-stroke:  
Identifying key factors for best practice decision making over the recovery 
trajectory 
 
Annabel McNamara 
Bch. App. Sc. (OT), MHsc., MBA 
 
 
For the degree of Doctor of Philosophy 
 
 
Department of Rehabilitation, Aged and Extended Care 
School of Health Sciences 
Flinders University 
Adelaide, Australia 
July, 2016 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Word Count: 52,781

chunk_1660.text:
vi  
 
Summary 
 
The purpose of this thesis is to examine the process of returning to driving post-stroke in 
order to contribute to best practice decision making.  A decision tree is suggested to build 
patient-centred procedures for returning to driving along the post-stroke recovery trajectory.   
 
Part one reviews literature on the return to driving process post-stroke and identifies gaps in 
knowledge.  The stroke recovery trajectory’s three main phases of recovery (acute, 
rehabilitation and community care) are outlined and act as a framework for the thesis 
structure.  Part two of the thesis describes five separate but related studies carried out to 
address the research gaps identified. 
 
The first study is a qualitative study that examines attitudes and perceptions of stroke 
survivors from one to 16 weeks post-stroke.  Independence was found to be the primary 
motivator in stroke survivors’ decisions about fitness to drive.  However, during the acute

chunk_1661.text:
motivator in stroke survivors’ decisions about fitness to drive.  However, during the acute 
phase stroke survivors were focused on their physical recovery, not returning to driving.  
Study participants had little knowledge of return to driving procedures or legislation, despite 
information being available.  Gender differences were apparent in factors affecting the return 
to driving decision making.   
 
The second study examines the psychometric property of practice effect on the Useful Field 
of View (UFOV, Ball & Owsley, 1993) a pre-driving screening assessment.  UFOV scores 
have been found to be associated with on-road driving assessment scores (George & Crotty, 
2010) and used in medical recommendations.  Study participants were all stroke survivors 
with a control group performing the UFOV at three months and assessment group at one, two 
and three months post-stroke.  Findings suggest there was no practice effect in relation to a

chunk_1662.text:
and three months post-stroke.  Findings suggest there was no practice effect in relation to a 
single three month post-stroke time point.  Timing of reassessment was also examined. 
 
The third study examined self-perceived driving confidence measured by the Adelaide 
Driving Self Efficacy Scale (ADSES, George et al., 2007; George & Crotty, 2010) and 
driving habits.  Results indicated there was a significant statistical association between low 
self-perceived driving confidence and lower kilometres driven per week, reduce driving 
scope, driving closer to home and avoiding challenging driving situations.

chunk_1663.text:
vii  
 
The fourth study explored self-perceived driving confidence of post-stroke drivers and their 
non-stroke, aged-matched driving peers measured by the ADSES.  No difference was found, 
suggesting once stroke survivors have returned to driving they have the same levels of self-
perceived driving confidence and potential driving scope as their non-stroke driving peers. 
 
The final study focused on decisions to relinquish a driver’s licence among the older 
Australian general population and used a novel Discrete Choice Experiment (DCE) 
methodological approach.  A general population was used to establish a norm with which 
future research on specific chronic conditions such as stroke could make comparison.  
Recommendation of General Practitioners’ (GPs), participants’ local doctors was found to be 
the primary influencing factor in the decision of older Australians to relinquish their driver’s

chunk_1664.text:
the primary influencing factor in the decision of older Australians to relinquish their driver’s 
licence.  Advice from family and friends, age and crash risk in the next year were also 
influencing factors.  The costs and availability of public transport options were not 
influencing factors. 
 
The last chapter of this thesis is the Discussion section which identifies the common themes 
emerging along with limitations and recommendations for future research directions.

Declaration 
 
I was involved in the design of the following research studies including the completion and 
submission of ethics approval applications.  
 
Literature reviews search strategies were developed in consultation with Nikki May, the 
Health Sciences consultant librarian at Flinders University. 
 
Upon commencement of the studies, I was solely responsible for screening potential patient 
participants for eligibility, recruitment and conducting the data collection, including; 
interviews in the qualitative study in the acute phase of stroke recovery, collecting UFOV 
Assessment scores for the rehabilitation phase study and telephone interviews for the Driving 
Habits Questionnaire (DHQ) for the community phase study.  The questions for the Discrete 
Choice Experiment (DCE) study were selected in consultation with my supervisors and an 
experienced rehabilitation physician, Professor Maria Crotty.  I was assisted in the statistical

chunk_1670.text:
experienced rehabilitation physician, Professor Maria Crotty.  I was assisted in the statistical 
design for the DCE study by my supervisors and Dr Gang Chen, Flinders University.   
 
I was responsible for the data entry of all studies data.  I was involved in all data analysis and 
interpretation of results with the advice of my supervisors and assistance from Dr Chris Ball, 
Flinders University, for the UFOV study and Dr Gang Chen for the DCE study.   
 
During these studies I was supported financially with a Flinders University Research 
Scholarship and had financial support from the Repatriation General Hospital Foundation for 
the UFOV practice effect research in the rehabilitation phase study.
